Every owner of real estate within the Village shall cut weeds on his property at all such times as may be necessary so that such weeds shall not exceed
eight inches (8") in height. If the owner neglects or refuses to so cut the weeds, the Director of Public Works shall cause the weeds to be cut on behalf of
the Village. (1989 Code)
4-4-3: WEED CUTTING LIEN:
A. Notice of Lien: If the Director of Public Works causes the weeds to be cut, a notice of lien for the cost and expenses thereof incurred by the Village shall
be recorded as provided in the 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-7 of the Illinois Municipal Code2, as amended from time to time. The Village or the
person performing the service by authority of the Village in its or his own name may file notice of lien in the office of Recorder of Deeds of Lake County.
The notice of lien shall consist of a sworn statement setting out: 1) a description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof, 2) the amount of
money representing the cost and expense incurred or payable for the service, and 3) the date or dates when the cost and expense was incurred by the
Village, and shall be filed within sixty (60) days after the cost and expense is incurred. Notice of such lien shall be mailed to the owner of the real
estate; provided, that failure to file the notice or to mail the notice, or failure of the owner to receive thenotice, shall not affect the right to foreclose the
lien as provided in subsection C below.
B. Payment of Weed Cutting Cost; Release of Lien: Upon payment of the cost and expense after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released by
the Village or person in whose name the lien has been filed and the release shall be filed of record in the same manner as filing notice of the lien.
C. Foreclosure of Lien: Real estate subject to a lien for unpaid cutting costs and expenses may be sold for nonpayment of the same (subject to the
statutory rights of bona fide purchasers or prior lienors), and the proceeds of such sale shall be applied to pay such costs and expenses, after
deducting court costs and legal fees, as in the case of the foreclosure of statutory liens. (1989 Code)
Footnote 1: See also subsection 4-2-1M of this Title.
Footnote 2: S.H.A. 65 ILCS.
Chapter 5
DUTCH ELM DISEASED TREES
4-5-1: INSPECTIONS AUTHORIZED:
The officers, agents and employees of the village may enter upon private property whereon there is located any elm tree having the appearance of or
suspected of being diseased with the Dutch elm disease for the purpose of inspecting the suspected tree and removing therefrom samples or portions
thereof to be tested to establish whether the tree is in fact diseased. (1989 Code)
4-5-2: NUISANCE DECLARED:
If it is determined by the village that the tree from which samples have been taken is in fact diseased or infected with the Dutch elm disease, the tree shall
be deemed a nuisance. (1989 Code)
4-5-3: REMOVAL AND DESTRUCTION OF DISEASED TREES:
The owner, occupant or agent of the parcel of land on which the diseased elm tree exists shall remove and destroy the elm tree within ten (10) days after
notification to such owner, occupant, or agent by the village that the elm tree situated on said parcel of land is in fact diseased and infected. (1989 Code)
4-5-4: ABATEMENT BY VILLAGE; COSTS:
In case the owner, occupant or agent of the parcel of land on which a diseased elm tree is located cannot be found, or if found and notified as aforesaid,
neglects or refuses to abate the nuisance, the village may abate the same by the removal and destruction of the diseased elm tree, and the owner,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 130/524
occupant and agent or any of them, shall be charged with those expenses which may be incurred by the village in the removal of the diseased elm tree,
which expense shall be collected by the village by suit or otherwise. In addition, the owner, occupant or agent shall be subject to the fine or penalty
provided in this chapter. (1989 Code)
4-5-5: ABATEMENT COSTS A LIEN:
The cost of removal and destruction of a diseased elm tree is a lien upon the real estate affected, superior to all other liens and encumbrances except tax
liens; provided, that notice has been given as hereinafter described; and further provided, that within sixty (60) days after such cost and expense is
incurred, the village or person performing the service by authority of the village, in his own name, files notice of lien in the office of the recorder of deeds of
Lake County. The notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out: a) a description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof, b) the amount
of money representing the cost and expense incurred or payable for the service, and c) the date or dates when such cost and expense was incurred by the
village. Upon payment of the cost and expense by the owner of or persons interested in such property, after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be
released by the village, or person in whose name the lien has been filed, and the release may be filed of record as in the case of filing notice of lien. The
cost of such tree removal shall not be a lien upon the real estate affected unless a notice shall be personally served or sent by registered mail to the
person to whom was sent the tax bill for the general taxes for the last preceding year on the property, such notice to be delivered or sent not less than
thirty (30) days prior to the removal of the tree or trees located thereon. The notice shall contain the substance of this chapter and identify the property, by
common description, and the tree or trees affected. (1989 Code)
4-5-6: PENALTY:
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter or who shall neglect or refuse to remove and destroy a diseased elm tree growing on any
parcel of land of which such person is owner, agent, occupant or person in possession, when ordered so to do, or who shall interfere with the removal and
destruction of such diseased elm tree, shall be subject to the penalty provided for violation of this code1. (1989 Code)
Title 5
POLICE REGULATIONS
Chapter 1
POLICE DEPARTMENT; PEACE OFFICERS
5-1-1: POLICE DEPARTMENT CREATED:
There is hereby created a Police Department of the Village which shall consist of a Chief of Police and such other members as the Board of Trustees may
from time to time prescribe. (1989 Code)
5-1-2: CHIEF OF POLICE:
A. Appointment; Serve As Village Marshal: The Chief of Police shall be appointed by the President by and with the consent of the Board of Trustees. He
shall also be the Village Marshal. (1989 Code)
B. Powers And Duties: The Chief of Police shall have the following powers and duties:
1. The Chief shall be in charge of the Police Department, and all members thereof shall be subject to the Chief's orders.
2. The Chief may make rules for the functioning of the Police Department, subject to the approval of the Board of Trustees.
3. The Chief may appoint to the position of Deputy Chief of Police one or more officers within the Police Department as may be specifically authorized
from time to time by the Board of Trustees.
4. The Chief shall keep such records and make such reports of the activities of the Police Department as may be required by statute or requested by
the Board of Trustees.
5. The Chief shall be the keeper of the Village Jail and shall have custody of all persons incarcerated therein. (Ord. 99-12-1013, 12-20-1999)
5-1-3: DUTIES OF DEPARTMENT MEMBERS:
Members of the Police Department shall enforce the ordinances of the Village and laws of the State effective in the Village. They shall preserve order,
prevent infractions of the law and arrest violators of the law or ordinances of the Village. (1989 Code)
5-1-4: POLICE PENSION FUND1:
A. Established: A Police Pension Fund is hereby established for the benefit of police, their widows, children and certain other dependents as provided and
required by law. The fund shall be administered by the Board of Trustees.
B. Financing:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 131/524
1. There shall be deposited in the Police Pension Fund the sums required by law which shall include seven percent (7%) per month deducted from the
salary of each member of the police force.
2. The Village Board of Trustees shall levy a tax, the proceeds of which shall also be deposited in the Police Pension Fund, which, when added to the
deductions from the salaries of the policemen and receipts from other sources, will equal a sum sufficient to meet the annual requirements of the
Police Pension Fund and of the reserves required therefor, all as provided by the Statutes of the State2.
C. Collection And Custody Of Proceeds: It is the duty of the Village Treasurer to collect the monies appropriated for this fund. He shall retain the custody of
said monies until it is drawn from him by order of the Board of Trustees of the Police Pension Fund. After said monies are invested by the Board of
Trustees, all securities or intangible choses in action purchased by them shall be deposited with the Village Treasurer and left in the Treasurer's
custody subject to the further control and order of the Board of Trustees of the Police Pension Fund. (1989 Code)
D. Reports Required: On the second Tuesday in January annually, the Treasurer and all other officials of the Municipality who have custody of any pension
funds as herein provided shall make a sworn statement to the Board of Trustees of the Police Pension Fund and also to the Village President and the
Board of Trustees relating to all monies received and paid out on account of the Pension Fund ending that year. The Police Pension Fund shall operate
on a fiscal year basis beginning January 1 and ending December 31. The Board of Trustees of the Police Pension Fund shall report to the Village
Board of Trustees annually upon the condition of the Police Pension Fund. Said report shall be made prior to the meeting of the Board of Trustees held
for the levying of taxes for the year for which such report is made. Said report shall be in the manner and form as required by law. (Ord. 2015-5-071, 5-
4-2015)
5-1-5: POLICE RESERVE OFFICERS:
(Rep. by Ord. 2018-02-246, 2-5-2018)
5-1-6: PRIVATE SECURITY GUARDS:
(Rep. by Ord. 2018-02-246, 2-5-2018)
5-1-7: COMPENSATION AND MEDICAL BENEFITS FOR POLICE DEPARTMENT:
A. Compensation For Injury In The Line Of Duty: The Village will provide salary compensation to any full time sworn member of the Police Department or
the Chief of Police who was injured in the line of duty in accordance with the provisions of the Public Employee Disability Act, 5 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 345/0.01 et seq. (Ord. 96-08-816, 8-5-1996)
B. Assumption Of Liability For Medical Expenses: In case of an accident resulting in an injury to or death of any full time sworn member of the Police
Department or the Chief of Police while in the employ of the Village while in the performance of his duties, the Village Manager may secure and provide
proper medical care and hospital treatment for any such full time sworn member of the Police Department or the Chief of Police, and to that end may
incur expense in connection therewith to be paid from funds budgeted or appropriated therefor by the Village Board or from proceeds of insurance
funds.
C. Investigation Of Facts: It shall be the duty of the Village Manager to make a complete investigation of all facts surrounding any accident resulting in an
injury to or death of any full time sworn member of the Police Department or the Chief of Police in the employ of the Village while in the performance of
his duties, to obtain the statements of all material witnesses and to present a report thereof. Such report shall also show the date and hour of any such
accident, the place of occurrence of same, the names and addresses of witnesses, the apparent nature and extent of the injury and whether the injury
or death was caused under circumstances creating a legal liability for damages on the part of some person other than the Village.
D. Payment Of Expenses: All bills showing the items of expense incurred for any medical care and hospital treatment referred to in subsection B of this
section shall be presented to the Village Manager who shall make a determination as to the reasonableness of the charges made for the services so
rendered and recommend payment to cover the items of expense.
E. Reimbursement By Third Person: If the Village Manager is of the opinion that any accident referred to in this section created a legal liability for damages
on the part of some person other than the Village, it shall be the duty of the Village Manager to demand from such person reimbursement to the Village
for the amount expended by the Village for the medical care and hospital treatment of any such full time sworn member of the Police Department or the
Chief of Police. In default of payment of such amount so expended, the Village Manager may cause proceedings to be filed to recover for the Village
the amount so expended. (Ord. 96-08-816, 8-5-1996; amd. Ord. 2012-10-861, 10-1-2012)
Chapter 2
ANIMALS AND ANIMAL CONTROL
5-2-1: CERTAIN ANIMALS PROHIBITED:
No person shall keep or raise any of the following animals or fowl within the Village: pigs, cattle, horses, goats, sheep or any other farm animals, or any
chickens, geese, ducks or other domestic fowl. (1989 Code)
5-2-2: DANGEROUS ANIMALS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 132/524
No person shall permit any dangerous or vicious animal within his care or custody to be kept at large or to be in any location where any person is
endangered thereby. (1989 Code)
5-2-3: RABIES CONTROL:
A. County Regulations Adopted: The Lake County Board of Health ordinance, article X, rabies control, effective December 1, 1976, is hereby adopted by
reference and made a part of this section as though fully set forth herein. A copy of such ordinance shall be kept on file in the Office of the Village
Clerk.
B. Joint Agreement With County: The Village shall enter into a joint agreement with the County of Lake as provided in agreement III on file in the Office of
the Village Clerk, and the Village President and Village Clerk are authorized to execute such agreement III on behalf of the Village. (1989 Code)
C. Penalties: The same penalties as provided in the Lake County Board of Health ordinance aforesaid shall apply to any violation of this section, said
penalties being herein restated as follows: Any person violating or aiding in or abetting the violation of any provision of this section, or counterfeiting
any certificate or tag, or making any misrepresentation in regard to any matter prescribed by this section, or resisting, obstructing or impeding the
Health Department or an authorized officer in enforcing this section shall be fined pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of this Code. Each
day a person fails to comply constitutes a separate offense. (1989 Code; amd. Ord. 2018-12-279, 12-3-2018)
5-2-4: SMALL ANIMAL DEALERS:
No person shall engage in the business of buying, selling or dealing in birds, dogs or other small animals used as household pets or used for domestic
purposes without first having obtained a license. (1989 Code)
5-2-5: KENNELS AND CATTERIES:
A. Licenses Required; Exemptions: No person shall engage in the business of operating a dog kennel or a cattery without first having obtained a license
therefor.
In case the business of buying, selling or dealing in birds, dogs and other small animals used as household pets or for domestic purposes is conducted
or carried on in connection with the business of a dog kennel or a cattery in the same premises, and by the same person, then only one license need
be obtained, and that license shall be that which requires the payment of the highest license fee under either of the two (2) license provisions of this
Code.
Any person licensed to operate a kennel shall be exempt from the payment of the dog registry fee for each and every dog which is kept in any licensed
kennel. (1989 Code; amd. Ord. 2009-06-621, 6-15-2009)
5-2-6: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
ANIMAL: Any live vertebrate creature except man.
ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER/WARDEN: Any employee of the village designated by the chief of police to exercise police powers in the enforcement of
this chapter. This includes: sworn police officers, community service officers, and marine officers.
AUTHORIZED PERSON: Any member of the police department, animal control officer/warden or any person under their supervision.
BITE: Seizure of a person with the jaws or teeth of any cat, dog or other animal capable of transmitting rabies so that the person so seized has been
wounded or pierced and further includes contact of the saliva of such cat, dog or other animal with any break or abrasion of the skin.
CAT: All members of the feline family.
CATTERY: Any establishment or premises wherein or whereon cats are kept for the purpose of breeding, boarding, sale or exchange or sporting.
CONTROL: Any owned animal that is secured by one or more of the following:
A. A leash or lead no longer than six feet (6') in length.
B. An electrical or mechanical device designed to keep an animal confined to the owner's property.
C. A fence, cage, crate or enclosure.
D. A vehicle.
DISEASED ANIMAL: Any animal affected with a disease contagious or infectious to both humans and animals.
DOG: All members of the canine family.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 133/524
ENCLOSURE: Any fence or structure of at least six feet (6') in height, forming or causing an enclosure suitable to prevent the entry of young children and
to confine a dog or other animal, designed with secure sides, top and bottom adequate to prevent escape.
IMPOUNDMENT: The removal and taking into custody of animals pursuant to this chapter.
KENNEL: Any establishment or premises where more than four (4) dogs or four (4) cats or any combination thereof, over four (4) months of age are
boarded or kept for any purpose whatsoever, or on which more than two (2) such animals are boarded for compensation or kept for sale, with the
exception of regularly established veterinary hospitals, pet shops, pounds or shelters.
LEASH: Any restraint, cord, thong or chain not more than six feet (6') in length, designed for the purpose of keeping the animal under control. The leash
must securely fasten to the collar or harness of the animal and must be of sufficient strength to restrain the animal.
POUND: Any facility licensed by the Illinois department of agriculture and approved by the chief of police for the purpose of enforcing this chapter and
used as a shelter for seized, stray, homeless, abandoned or unwanted animals.
SHELTER: Any establishment where dogs, cats or other animals are received, housed and distributed with or without charge.
STRAY ANIMAL: Any animal running at large in the public way or on private property other than that of the owner or keeper of such animal.
VICIOUS ANIMAL: A. Any individual animal that, when unprovoked, inflicts bites and attacks a human being or other animal either on public or private
property.
B. Any individual animal with a propensity, tendency, or disposition to attack without provocation, to cause injury or to otherwise do any act that might
endanger the safety of human beings, domestic animals or any property of another, including, but not limited to, a disposition to mischief or
fierceness which might lead to attack to the foregoing.
C. Any individual animal which attacks a human being or domestic animal without provocation, whether in play, anger or outbreak of untrained nature.
D. No animal shall be deemed vicious if it bites, attacks or menaces a trespasser on the property of its owner, or harms or menaces anyone who has
tormented or abused it, or is a professionally trained animal for law enforcement or guard duties.
VILLAGE: Village of Lake Zurich, Lake County, Illinois. (1989 Code; amd. Ord. 2009-06-621, 6-15-2009)
5-2-7: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
It shall be unlawful to:
A. Inhumanely beat, underfeed, overload or abandon any animal.
B. Fail to provide any animal with proper shelter, protection from weather or veterinary care when needed to prevent suffering.
C. Keep animals in violation of the "Illinois humane care for animals act1" or the "Illinois animal welfare act2".
D. Intentionally strike Canadian geese or other wildlife with a motor vehicle. Geese and other wildlife shall have the right of way when crossing streets
within the village. Any person who, as the operator of a motor vehicle, strikes an animal, shall stop at once and render such assistance as may be
possible, or shall immediately report such injury to the animal owner, if known; or to the appropriate law enforcement agency; or to the local humane
society.
E. Torment, shoot at with slingshots, BB or pellet type guns or other firearms, pelt with rocks or otherwise disturb any animals.
F. Poison or cause to be poisoned any domesticated animal. The only exception will be by written permit from the Illinois department of agriculture for the
purpose of controlling diseases transmissible to humans or other animals and only when all other methods and means have been exhausted. Any
drugs used for euthanasia shall be by or under the direction of a licensed veterinarian.
G. Leave any animal unattended in a motor vehicle or enclosed trailer when the outside temperature exceeds eighty six degrees Fahrenheit (86°F) (30°C)
or contain any animal in such manner that said animal does not have proper air circulation while confined in a motor vehicle, trailer, kennel, doghouse,
or any type of container or structure in which an animal may be confined.
H. Own any animal which is known to be infected with any disease transmissible to other animals or man, including severe parasitism, unless such animal
shall be confined in such a manner as not to expose other animals or man. (Ord. 2009-06-621, 6-15-2009)
5-2-8: CONTROL OF ANIMALS:
A. Unlawful: It shall be unlawful:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 134/524
1. Consent Required: For the owner or any person who has in his custody or control, any dog, cat, or other animal to enter upon the premises of
another within the village without the consent of the owners.
2. Public Body Of Water: To permit any animal, whether licensed or not, to enter any public body of water, pond, fountain or stream.
3. Food Establishment: To permit any animal to enter any place where food is stored, prepared, served or sold to the public, or any public building or
hall; provided however, that this section shall not apply to any visually impaired or hearing impaired person using a trained guide dog, to veterinary
offices or hospitals, or to animal shows or exhibitions.
4. At Large/Trespass: To permit any animal to run uncontrolled or trespass on private or public property.
5. Damage: To permit any animal to damage or destroy any property.
6. Vehicles: To permit any dog to chase, run after or jump at vehicles using the public thoroughfares.
7. Threatening Animal: To permit any dog to habitually snap, growl, snarl, jump upon or otherwise threaten persons lawfully using any common
thoroughfare, sidewalk, passageway, bypath, play area, park or any place where people congregate or walk.
8. Disturbance Of The Peace: To permit any dog or other animal to howl, yelp, whine, or bark or make noise in such a manner as to disturb any person
or neighborhood at any time of the day or night.
9. Unsanitary Conditions: To allow any places where any animal is or may be kept to become unclean or unsanitary or become offensive to those
residing in the vicinity.
10. Number Of Dogs Or Cats: To keep on a residentially zoned premises more than three (3) dogs and/or three (3) cats over four (4) months of age,
with the exception of regularly established and zoned veterinary hospitals, pet shops, pounds or shelters. (Reference: Lake County board of health,
ordinance X, animal/rabies control, section 2910.1 and 2910.2.)
11. Excrement Removal:
a. Device For Removal, Depository: For any person to cause or permit a dog to be on any property, public or private, not owned or possessed by
such person unless such person has in his immediate possession a device for the removal of excrement and a depository for the transmission of
excrement to a receptacle located upon property owned or possessed by such person.
b. Removal Required: For any person in control of, causing or permitting any dog to be on any property, public or private, not owned or possessed by
such person to fail to remove excrement left by such dog to a proper receptacle located on property owned or possessed by such person.
12. Bites: To fail to report an animal bite.
13. Animals Other Than Domestic Pets: To keep, harbor or maintain any animal which may endanger the safety of persons or property. This includes
animals other than commonly recognized domestic pets which may harm or injure humans or other animals by injection of toxins, by constriction or
suffocation, or by vicious biting, scratching or mauling. It is no defense to a violation of this subsection that the keeper of such animal prohibited
herein has attempted to domesticate such animal. Exceptions to this subsection are animals displayed or harbored in a zoo, carnival or circus.
14. Public Street Or Highway: To permit any dog, cat or other animal upon a public street or highway, or upon any premises other than that of the
person owning such dog, cat or other animal unless such dog, cat or other animal is on a leash securely fastened to a collar or harness. The overall
length of the leash including the handle shall not exceed six feet (6') and be held by its owner or other person able to control such dog, cat or other
animal and, while lawfully on the premises of the owner, shall not be allowed to come in contact with any person who is not a member of the
immediate household.
B. Exemptions: Guide dogs for visually impaired or hearing impaired persons, support dogs for persons with physical disabilities and sentry, guard, or
police owned dogs are exempt from this section, provided an attack or injury to a person occurs while the dog is performing duties as expected. To
qualify for exemption under this subsection, each such dog shall be currently inoculated against rabies. It shall be the duty of the owner of such
exempted dog to notify the police department of changes of address. In the case of a sentry or guard dog, the owner shall keep the police department
advised of the location where such dog will be stationed. (Ord. 2009-06-621, 6-15-2009)
5-2-9: IMPOUNDMENT AND REDEMPTION:
A. Nuisance Animals; Impoundment Authorized: Any dog or other animal doing any of the acts prohibited in section 5-2-8 of this chapter is hereby
declared to be a public nuisance, and such animal may be seized and impounded as provided herein.
B. Notice To Owner; Impoundment Period; Disposition Of Animals: After such animal is impounded, the Police Department, animal warden or authorized
representative shall ascertain whether the animal is licensed and, if so, shall, within a reasonable time, notify the person to whom the license was
issued that said animal has been impounded and may be redeemed. Impounded animals will be transferred to the Lake County Department of Public
Health the next business day. The owner of such a transferred animal will be responsible for all fees charged by the Lake County Department of Public
Health.
C. Redemption Of Impounded Animal: Any dog or other animal impounded pursuant to the provisions of this section may be redeemed upon payment of
the required redemption fee, fines, license and vaccination fees as provided herein. The animal shall be returned to the owner, provided he shall:
1. Show satisfactory proof of ownership.
2. Agree to pay any fines or penalties imposed for violation of this chapter.
3. Agree to pay the cost of keeping the animal while impounded by the Village at its pound. (Ord. 2009-06-621, 6-15-2009)
a. The fee for each day an animal is housed/transported by the Lake Zurich Police Department shall be pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee
Schedule", of this Code. (Ord. 2009-06-621, 6-15-2009; amd. Ord. 2018-12-279, 12-3-2018)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 135/524
4. Secure an animal license or rabies vaccination, if applicable and due.
D. Liability For Fines And Costs: If ownership of the animal is established and the owner refuses to redeem the same, he shall remain obligated to pay all
fines and impoundment expenses. (Ord. 2009-06-621, 6-15-2009)
5-2-10: VIOLATIONS; PENALTY:
A. Penalty: Any person who violates any provision of section 5-2-7 or 5-2-8 of this chapter shall be fined pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of
this Code for each offense.
B. Payments To Avoid Prosecution: For violations of section 5-2-7 or 5-2-8 of this chapter, any person that receives a citation for a violation of the
aforementioned sections of this chapter may avoid prosecution by paying a fine pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of this Code. (Ord.
2009-06-621, 6-15-2009; amd. Ord. 2018-12-279, 12-3-2018)
Chapter 3
GENERAL OFFENSES
5-3-1: DANGEROUS WEAPONS PROHIBITED ON OR WITHIN PUBLIC PROPERTY:
A. Definitions: For the purposes of this section, the following terms have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection A:
DANGEROUS WEAPONS: 1. A rifle, pistol, or any other type of gun, firearm, or device from which a projectile may be fired by means of an
explosive,
2. Any simulated firearm operated by gas or compressed air,
3. Metal knuckles or similar devices,
4. Any knife that has a spring blade, or that opens or is ejected by an outward or downward thrust or movement, or that has a blade in excess of
three inches (3") in length (excluding kitchen cutlery), and
5. Any instrument that can be used as a club or similar type of weapon and that poses a reasonable risk of injury.
VILLAGE OWNED PROPERTY OR FACILITY: Any real property or structure owned by the village, including, without limitation, any building owned,
leased, or operated by the village regardless of the occupancy of that building; any park; any park or accessory building; and any storage facility.
B. Possession Of Dangerous Weapons Prohibited: It is unlawful for any person to wear, carry, transport, store, or in any other way possess a dangerous
weapon while on or within any village owned property or facility.
C. Exceptions: The prohibition stated in subsection B of this section does not apply to: 1) any law enforcement official, public safety officer, or security
personnel engaged in his or her official duties, or 2) any properly authorized person engaged in military activities pursuant to authorization by the
federal government or the state of Illinois while engaged in his or her official duties, or 3) possession of a legal and properly permitted firearm in a
single-family residence owned by the village and leased as a single-family residence.
D. Signs: The police department will cause signs to be posted in appropriate locations on village owned property and within village owned facilities as
notice of the prohibition against dangerous weapons provided in this section. (Ord. 2008-12-592, 12-1-2008)
Chapter 4
SECURITY ALARM SYSTEMS
5-4-1: PURPOSES:
The purposes of this Chapter are to provide regulations that logically, efficiently and properly regulate the installation and use of security alarm systems,
and to reduce the number of unnecessary responses by the Lake Zurich Police Department to such alarm systems, and to provide for the imposition of
fees to be charged to that portion of the village residential and business population that maintains such alarm systems. The inherent difficulties and
malfunctions associated with mechanically or electronically activated alarm systems result in unnecessary or false alarm activation and consequently
require unnecessary responses by the Police Department. Such unnecessary responses severely impact and endanger the safety and welfare of the
residents of the Village. In addition to the significant cost involved in responding to such alarm system activations and the concurrent loss of manpower
and ineffective utilization of equipment, such alarm systems require emergency responses which may contribute to a high accident rate.
A system of graduated fees for Police Department responses to alarm systems serves the dual purpose of encouraging the cessation of non-bona fide
alarms and of charging the cost of the use of such alarm systems to that portion of the population wishing to use them. (Ord. 94-04-659, 4-18-94)
5-4-2: DEFINITIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 136/524
The following terms shall have the meanings herein ascribed to them:
ALARM OCCURRENCE: The activation of an alarm system, for any reason whatsoever, which notifies the Lake Zurich Police Department to respond to
the premises at which the alarm system is maintained.
ALARM SERVICE PROVIDER: That person or organization supplying alarm services to the Village as determined from time to time by the Board of
Trustees.
ALARM SYSTEM: Any single device or assemblage of mechanical or electrical equipment or devices arranged to signal the presence of or the occurrence
of an unauthorized intrusion or any other activity requiring the urgent and immediate attention of the Lake Zurich Police Department. The term "alarm
system" shall include elevator trouble systems or similar communications systems, automatic holdup alarm systems, burglar alarm systems, holdup alarm
systems, direct dial systems, on-premises alarm systems, and on-site ringers. The following alarm systems, however, are specifically excluded from the
provisions of this Chapter: alarm systems owned or operated by the Village, fire alarm systems, medical emergency alarm systems, motor vehicle alarm
systems, alarm systems arranged to signal police departments other than the Lake Zurich Police Department, and alarm systems that monitor
temperature, humidity or any other condition not directly related to either the detection of an unauthorized intrusion into a premises or an attempted
robbery or burglary at a premises.
ALARM USER: The person, family, household, firm, entity, partnership, association, corporation, company, organization or state, or subdivision thereof
other than the Village, in possession or control of any building, structure, facility or property in the Village where an alarm system is currently being
maintained or is hereinafter maintained.
DELAY MECHANISM: An electrical or mechanical feature of an alarm system that: a) provides a time delay between activation of the alarm system and
the annunciation of an audible alarm or the transmitting of a message or signal to the Lake Zurich Police Department; and b) allows for deactivation of the
alarm system prior to the annunciation of an audible alarm or the transmitting of a message or signal to the Lake Zurich Police Department or to an alarm
service or central station alarm.
DIRECT CONNECTION ALARM SYSTEM: An alarm system that, when activated, notifies the Lake Zurich Police Department to respond to the premises
at which the alarm system is maintained by means of a direct connection to an alarm monitoring panel maintained by the Village.
DIRECT DIALER: An alarm system that utilizes a telephone device or attachment to automatically select a telephone trunk line at the Lake Zurich Police
Department or at an alarm service or central station alarm and then reproduces a prerecorded message to report an alarm occurrence.
ON-SITE RINGER: A feature of an alarm system that, when activated, causes an audible and/or visual device to activate in, on, or near the premises
within which the alarm system is maintained.
SERVICE CHARGE: The amount of money determined by the Board of Trustees to be reasonable compensation for the services provided by the Village
in responding to alarm occurrences. (Ord. 94-04-659, 4-18-94)
5-4-3: ALARM SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS:
No person shall install or maintain in the Village any alarm system that does not meet the following standards:
A. Delay Mechanism Required: All alarm systems must be equipped with a delay mechanism that allows at least a thirty (30) second delay before
activation of the alarm with respect to ingress and egress of doorways.
B. Reset Mechanism Required: All alarm systems must be equipped with a mechanism that deactivates the alarm and resets the system within ten (10)
minutes after the initial activation of the system.
C. Direct Dialer to Lake Zurich Police Department Prohibited: No alarm system shall include a direct dialer or other device that automatically selects a
telephone trunk line at the Lake Zurich Police Department.
D. On-Site Ringers Limited: No alarm system shall include an on-site ringer unless 1) any audible sound emitting from such on-site ringer is not similar to
emergency vehicles of the Village or any other audible Village alert system; and 2) the on-site ringer is not designed to be audible outside of the
structure in which the alarm system is located; and 3) the alarm system is equipped with an automatic cut-off mechanism that deactivates the on-site
ringer within ten (10) minutes after the initial alarm.
E. Back-Up Power Required: Every alarm system shall be equipped with a battery pack back-up power supply or other alternative source of back-up
power capable of sustaining the operation of the alarm system for a minimum of six (6) hours.
F. Maintenance: Every alarm system shall be properly maintained at all times by the alarm user.
G. Nonresident Direct Connection Alarm Systems Prohibited: No direct connection alarm system shall be maintained or operated in any structure outside
of the Village's corporate limits. (Ord. 94-04-659, 4-18-94)
5-4-4: APPROVAL OF DIRECT CONNECTION ALARM SYSTEMS:
No person shall allow or cause a direct connection alarm system to be installed or maintained except after the approval of such system by the Lake Zurich
Chief of Police. (Ord. 94-04-659, 4-18-94)
5-4-5: ALARM USER INFORMATION:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 137/524
Every alarm user, promptly after a request therefor by the Village, shall provide accurate and up-to-date information on forms provided by the Village,
including without limitation: the name, address, and telephone number of the alarm user; the address and telephone number of the property where the
alarm system is located; and the names, addresses, and telephone numbers of at least two (2) persons who are regularly available and who have direct
means of access to the property and building at which the alarm system is located. Such information, if requested, shall be provided prior to any
authorization by the Chief of Police pursuant to section 5-4-4 of this chapter and shall be revised from time-to-time by the alarm user as necessary to keep
such information fully up to date. (Ord. 94-04-659, 4-18-1994)
5-4-6: ACCESS AND INDEMNIFICATION:
By installing and maintaining an alarm system, every alarm user authorizes the Lake Zurich Police Department to enter on and into every property and
structure serviced by an alarm system in the event of an activation of an alarm. Every alarm user shall indemnify and hold harmless the Village for all
claims, demands, judgments, liability, costs, damages and expenses, including attorneys' fees, that may arise from or out of or in any way relate to any
alarm connection, alarm occurrence, or any response thereto. (Ord. 94-04-659, 4-18-1994)
5-4-7: REQUIRED ALARM USER RESPONSE:
Each alarm user shall respond to and reset, or cause someone with access to the property to respond to and reset, that alarm user's alarm system,
immediately at the request of Lake Zurich Police Department. (Ord. 94-04-659, 4-18-1994)
5-4-8: CONNECTION AND MAINTENANCE FEE:
In addition to every other fee provided by law, every alarm user shall pay an annual fee established from time to time by the Board of Trustees. Such fee
shall be set at a rate necessary to reimburse the Village for all of its costs for an alarm service provider and other administrative, maintenance and
operations costs as determined by the Board of Trustees. Such fee shall be collected by the Village or by the Village's alarm services provider, as
determined by the Board of Trustees from time to time. (Ord. 94-04-659, 4-18-1994)
5-4-9: SERVICE CHARGES:
A. Basic Occurrence Charges: More than three (3) alarm occurrences in a calendar year from an alarm system shall result in the imposition of service
charges pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of this Code that shall be paid by the alarm user.
B. Nonresident Charge: Any owner of property outside of the Village corporate limits to whose property the Lake Zurich Police Department responds as a
result of the activation of a security alarm shall pay to the Village a fee pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of this Code for such response,
unless the Lake Zurich Police Department responds as a result of a request of another law enforcement agency. (Ord. 94-04-659, 4-18-1994; amd.
Ord. 2018-12-279, 12-3-2018)
C. Notification Of Charges: The Police Department shall notify the alarm user in writing of each alarm occurrence. After the third alarm occurrence in a
calendar year, the Police Department shall notify the alarm user of the fact that additional alarm occurrences will result in the imposition of service
charges in accordance with this section. After additional alarm occurrences, the Village shall invoice the alarm user for the service charges which have
been imposed.
D. Payment Of Service Charges: All service charges shall be paid by the alarm user within thirty (30) days after receipt of the invoice tendered pursuant to
subsection C of this section. (Ord. 94-04-659, 4-18-1994)
5-4-10: WAIVER OF SERVICE CHARGE/NULLIFICATION OF ALARM OCCURRENCE:
A. Authority: The Chief of Police shall have the authority, but not the obligation, to waive any service charge and to nullify the existence of any alarm
occurrence; provided, however, that every such waiver or nullification shall be made only after a finding, based on evidence and testimony presented
by the alarm user, that one or more of the following circumstances exist:
1. Actual Emergency: Evidence of an actual intrusion, of an obvious intrusion attempt, or of a fire or medical emergency.
2. Power Outage: Evidence of power utility outage conditions lasting eight (8) hours or longer and affecting a general neighborhood area.
3. Act Of Nature Or God: Evidence of a tornado, earthquake or other violent and extreme condition of nature or act of God, excluding thunder, snow,
ice and electrical storms.
4. Malicious Act: Evidence of a malicious act of someone not the alarm user or his or her agent, employee, servant or other person within the direction,
control or responsibility of the alarm user.
5. Thirty Day Grace Period: Alarm occurrences during the thirty (30) day period immediately after installation of an alarm system.
B. Request; Decision: Requests in writing for a waiver or nullification may be made by any alarm user to the Chief of Police. Within fourteen (14) days after
receipt of such a written request, the Chief of Police shall review the alarm user's request in accordance with this section and shall issue a decision.
(Ord. 94-04-659, 4-18-1994)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 138/524
C. Appeal: Within fourteen (14) days after receipt of such decision, the alarm user may appeal the Chief of Police's decision to the Village Manager, whose
determination in accordance with this section shall be final. (Ord. 94-04-659, 4-18-1994; amd. Ord. 2012-10-861, 10-1-2012)
5-4-11: REVOCATION OF DIRECT CONNECTION AUTHORIZATION:
A. Authority To Revoke: The Chief of Police shall have the authority, in the reasonable exercise of his or her discretion, to revoke authorization for a direct
connection alarm system for either of the following grounds:
1. Failure To Pay Service Charge: The failure to pay any service charge imposed pursuant to and in the manner described in section 5-4-9 of this
chapter (and which payment has not been waived pursuant to section 5-4-10 of this chapter).
2. Multiple Alarm Occurrences: Ten (10) or more alarm occurrences for one alarm system in one calendar year (none of which having been nullified
pursuant to section 5-4-10 of this chapter), regardless of whether the service charge for any of said alarm occurrences has been paid.
B. Notice And Hearing Prior To Revocation:
1. Notice Of Revocation: The Chief of Police, at least fifteen (15) days prior to the revocation of a direct connection alarm system authorization, shall
notify the alarm user in writing, by certified mail, return receipt requested, or by direct police service, of the grounds for revocation and of the Village's
intent to revoke.
2. Request For Hearing: Within ten (10) days after receipt of such notice, the alarm user may submit a written request to the Chief of Police for a
hearing before the Chief of Police, setting forth the reasons the authorization should not be revoked. The submission of such request shall suspend
the revocation of the authorization.
3. Revocation If No Request: If the alarm user fails to so submit a request for hearing within the stated time period, then the Chief of Police shall issue
a written statement of revocation, which written statement shall include an explanation of the consequences of revocation. Said written statement
shall be sent to the alarm user by certified mail, return receipt requested, or by direct police service. Revocation shall be effective immediately after
receipt by the alarm user of said written statement.
4. Notice Of Hearing: If a request for a hearing is submitted within the stated time period, then written notice of the time and place of the hearing shall
be served on the alarm user by the Chief of Police by first class mail at least ten (10) days prior to the date set for the hearing.
5. Hearing; Decision: At said hearing, the alarm user, or his or her authorized representative, shall have the right to confront and examine witnesses
and to present evidence on his or her own behalf. After the hearing, the Chief of Police either may support revocation or may cancel the notice of
revocation. If the Chief of Police supports revocation, then he or she shall notify the alarm user in writing by certified mail, return receipt requested, or
by direct police service explaining the consequences of revocation. Revocation shall be effective immediately after receipt by the alarm user of said
written notice. (Ord. 94-04-659, 4-18-1994)
5-4-12: ALARM SERVICE PROVIDER:
The Chief of Police, after approval by the Board of Trustees, may contract with an alarm service provider to provide all such alarm services as the Chief of
Police and the Board of Trustees may determine are necessary from time to time. (Ord. 94-04-659, 4-18-1994)
5-4-13: PENALTIES:
Any person found guilty of violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of this Code for each
offense. Each day on which a violation occurs or continues shall constitute a separate offense. Any penalty provided pursuant to this section shall be in
addition to any other service charge, fee, assessment, or penalty provided in this chapter. (Ord. 94-04-659, 4-18-1994; amd. Ord. 2018-12-279, 12-3-2018)
Chapter 5
FIRE ALARM SYSTEMS
5-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following terms shall have the meanings herein ascribed to them:
DIRECT DIALER: A fire alarm system that utilizes a telephone device or attachment to automatically select a telephone trunk line at the Lake Zurich
Fire/Rescue Department or at an alarm service or central station alarm and then reproduces a prerecorded message to report an alarm.
FALSE ALARM: The activation of a fire alarm system by one or more of the following causes when no fire or other emergency circumstance exists:
A. Mechanical failure of any element of the fire alarm system;
B. Malfunction of any element of the fire alarm system;
C. Improper installation, maintenance, repair or operation of the fire alarm system; or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 139/524
D. Any other cause, except as provided herein.
This definition shall not include activation of a fire alarm system by natural causes such as tornadoes, severe wind storms, earthquakes and the like,
and also shall not include the malicious act of any person not the fire alarm user or any agent, employee, servant or other person within the direction,
control or responsibility of the fire alarm user.
FIRE ALARM SYSTEM: Any assemblage of mechanical or electrical equipment or devices (or any single device) arranged to signal the existence, or
supposed existence, of a fire or other emergency requiring the response of the Lake Zurich Fire/Rescue Department.
FIRE ALARM USER: The person, family, household, firm, entity, partnership, association, corporation, company, organization or state, or subdivision
thereof other than the Village, in possession or control of any building, structure, facility or property in the Village where a fire alarm system is currently
being maintained or is hereinafter maintained.
FIRE ALARM USER PERMIT: A permit issued by the Village for the privilege and ability to operate a fire alarm system within the Village. No person, entity,
or fire alarm user shall be issued a fire alarm user permit unless a) an application thereof is completed and submitted in a form satisfactory to the Fire
Chief, b) the applicable fire alarm user permit fee is paid, and c) the fire alarm system complies with the fire alarm system requirements set forth in this
Chapter. (Ord. 94-04-659, 4-18-94)
5-5-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person, firm, corporation, or other entity shall install, maintain or operate a fire alarm system within the Village without first obtaining a valid and
effective fire alarm user permit. The installation, maintenance, and operation of a fire alarm system at any time without a fire alarm user permit shall
constitute an offense punishable as provided in this chapter. (Ord. 94-04-659, 4-18-1994)
5-5-3: PERMIT APPLICATION:
Every application for a fire alarm user permit shall be filed with the Fire Chief on a form approved by the Village. Every such application shall include,
among other things, plans and specifications for the fire alarm system sufficient for the Fire Chief to review all elements of such system. Every such
application also shall include, among other things, the written certification of the fire alarm user that the fire alarm user will properly maintain, or will cause
to be properly maintained, the fire alarm system at all times. (Ord. 94-04-659, 4-18-1994)
5-5-4: POSTING REQUIREMENT:
Each fire alarm user shall post and maintain, or cause to be posted and maintained, a notice in a form acceptable to the Fire Chief including the name,
address, and telephone number of a person responsible for the maintenance and repair of the fire alarm system. Such notice shall be posted at or
adjacent to the location where the fire alarm system can be deactivated. (Ord. 94-04-659, 4-18-1994)
5-5-5: DIRECT DIALERS PROHIBITED:
No fire alarm system shall include a direct dialer or other device that automatically selects a telephone trunk line at the Lake Zurich Fire/Rescue
Department; provided, however, that nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit direct dialers otherwise authorized by the Village Manager. (Ord.
94-04-659, 4-18-1994; amd. Ord. 2012-10-861, 10-1-2012)
5-5-6: ACCESS AND INDEMNIFICATION:
By installing and maintaining a fire alarm system, every fire alarm user authorizes the Lake Zurich Fire/Rescue Department to enter on and into every
property and structure serviced by a fire alarm system in the event of an activation of an alarm. Every fire alarm user shall indemnify and hold harmless the
Village for all claims, demands, judgments, liability, costs, damages, and expenses, including attorney fees, that may arise from or out of or in any way
relate to any alarm connection, any alarm activation, or any response thereto. (Ord. 94-04-659, 4-18-1994)
5-5-7: FALSE ALARMS PROHIBITED:
No person shall transmit or cause to be transmitted any false alarm when such person knows at the time of such transmission that there is no fire or other
emergency or when such person has no reasonable grounds at the time of such transmission to believe that there is a fire or other emergency. (Ord. 94-
04-659, 4-18-1994)
5-5-8: FALSE ALARM RESPONSE CHARGES:
A. False Alarm Service Charges: More than three (3) false alarms in a calendar year from a fire alarm system shall result in the imposition of the service
charges pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of this Code that shall be paid by the fire alarm user. (Ord. 94-04-659, 4-18-1994; amd. Ord.
2018-12-279, 12-3-2018)
B. Notification Of Charges: After the Lake Zurich Fire/Rescue Department has recorded three (3) false alarms within a calendar year from any fire alarm
system, it shall notify the fire alarm user in writing, by first class mail or by direct service, of such fact and of the fact that additional false alarms will
result in the imposition of response charges in accordance with this section. After additional false alarms, the Village shall invoice the fire alarm user for
the response charges which have been imposed.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 140/524
C. Payment Of Response Charges: All response charges shall be paid by the fire alarm user within thirty (30) days after receipt of the invoice tendered
pursuant to subsection B of this section. (Ord. 94-04-659, 4-18-1994)
5-5-9: WAIVER OF RESPONSE CHARGE:
A. Authority: The Fire Chief shall have the authority, but not the obligation, to waive any response charge; provided, however, that every such waiver shall
be made only after a finding, based on evidence and testimony presented by the fire alarm user, that one or more of the following circumstances exist:
1. Actual Emergency: Evidence of an actual fire or other emergency.
2. Power Outage: Evidence of power utility outage conditions lasting eight (8) hours or longer and affecting a general neighborhood area.
3. Act Of Nature Or God: Evidence of a tornado, earthquake or other violent and extreme condition of nature or act of God.
4. Malicious Act: Evidence of a malicious act of someone not the fire alarm user or his or her agent, employee, servant, or other person within the
direction, control or responsibility of the fire alarm user.
5. Thirty Day Grace Period: A false alarm occurred during the thirty (30) day period immediately after installation of an alarm system.
B. Request; Decision: Requests in writing for a waiver may be made by any fire alarm user to the Fire Chief. Within fourteen (14) days after receipt of such
a written request, the Fire Chief shall review the fire alarm user's request in accordance with this section and shall issue a decision. (Ord. 94-04-659, 4-
18-1994)
C. Appeal: Within fourteen (14) days after receipt of such decision, the fire alarm user may appeal the Fire Chief's decision to the Village Manager, whose
determination in accordance with this section shall be final. (Ord. 94-04-659, 4-18-1994; amd. Ord. 2012-10-861, 10-1-2012)
5-5-10: PENALTIES:
Any person found guilty of violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of this Code for each
offense. Each day on which a violation occurs or continues shall constitute a separate offense. Any penalty provided pursuant to this section shall be in
addition to any other service charge, fee, assessment, or penalty provided in this chapter. (Ord. 94-04-659, 4-18-1994; amd. Ord. 2018-12-279, 12-3-2018)

ARTICLE B. DEFINITIONS; PENALTY
6-1B-1: TERMS DEFINED:
ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLE: Any motorized off highway device fifty inches (50") or less in width, having a manufacturer's dry weight of nine hundred (900)
pounds or less, traveling on three (3) or more low pressure tires, designed with a seat or saddle for operator use, and handlebars or steering wheel for
steering control.
ALLEY: A public way within a block generally giving access to the rear of lots or buildings, and not used for general traffic circulation.
ANTIQUE VEHICLE: A motor vehicle that is more than twenty five (25) years of age or a bona fide replica thereof and which is driven on the highways
only going to and returning from an antique auto show or an exhibition, or for servicing or demonstration, or a firefighting vehicle more than twenty (20)
years old which is not used as firefighting equipment but is used only for the purpose of exhibition or demonstration.
BICYCLE: Every device propelled by human power upon which any person may ride, having one or more wheels, except for scooters and similar devices.
BUSINESS DISTRICT: The territory contiguous to and including a highway when within any six hundred feet (600') along the highway there are buildings
in use for business or industrial purposes, including, but not limited to, hotels, banks or office buildings, railroad stations and public buildings that occupy at
least three hundred feet (300') of frontage on one side or three hundred feet (300') collectively on both sides of the highway.
COMMERCIAL VEHICLE: Any vehicle operated for the transportation of persons or property in furtherance of any commercial or industrial enterprise, for
hire or not for hire, but not including a commuter van, a vehicle used in a ride sharing arrangement when being used for that purpose, or a recreational
vehicle not being used commercially.
CROSSWALK: A. That part of a roadway at an intersection included within the connections of the lateral lines of the sidewalks on opposite sides of the
highway measured from the curbs or, in the absence of curbs, from the edges of the traversable roadway, and in the absence of a sidewalk on one side of
the highway, that part of the highway included within the extension of the lateral line of the existing sidewalk to the side of the highway without the
sidewalk, with the extension forming a right angle to the centerline of the highway;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 142/524
B. Any portion of a roadway at an intersection or elsewhere distinctly indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on the surface placed
in accordance with the provisions in the manual adopted by the department of transportation as authorized in section 11-301 of the Illinois vehicle
code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-301.
DRIVER: Every person who drives or is in actual physical control of a vehicle.
EMERGENCY VEHICLE: Police vehicles, vehicles of the fire department, ambulances, vehicles carrying a federal, state, county, or municipal officer or
employee in response to an emergency call, the emergency vehicles of public service corporations on an emergency call, and vehicles of the Illinois
emergency management agency and the department of nuclear safety.
EXPLOSIVE: Any chemical compound or mechanical mixture that is commonly used or intended for the purpose of producing an explosion and that
contains any oxidizing and combustive units or other ingredients in such proportions, quantities, or packing that an ignition by fire, by friction, by
concussion, by percussion, or by detonator of any part of the compound or mixture may cause such a sudden generation of highly heated gases that the
resultant gaseous pressures are capable of producing destructible effects on contiguous objects or of destroying life or limb.
FARM TRACTOR: Every motor vehicle designed and used primarily as a farm implement for drawing wagons, plows, mowing machines and other
implements of husbandry, and every implement of husbandry that is self-propelled, excluding all-terrain vehicles and off highway motorcycles as defined in
the Illinois vehicle code.
FIRE LANE: Any street, alley, driveway, or other area designated and posted as a fire lane on private or public property.
FLAMMABLE LIQUID: Any liquid that has a flash point of seventy degrees Fahrenheit (70°F) or less, as determined by a Tagliabue or equivalent closed
cup test device.
GOLF CART: A vehicle specifically designed and intended for the purposes of transporting one or more persons and their golf clubs or maintenance
equipment while engaged in the playing of golf, supervising the play of golf, or maintaining the condition of the grounds on a public or private golf course.
HIGHWAY: The entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for
purposes of vehicular travel.
HOLIDAY: The term holiday shall include the following days only: January 1, the last Monday of May, July 4, the first Monday in September, December 25,
and the day designated and set aside by the president of the United States as a day of thanksgiving.
IMPROVED HIGHWAY: A roadway of concrete, brick, asphalt, macadam, and crushed stone or gravel.
INTERSECTION: The area embraced within the prolongation or connection of the lateral curb lines, or, if none, then the lateral boundary lines of roadways
of two (2) highways that join one another at, or approximately at, right angles or the area within which vehicles traveling upon different roadways joining at
any other angles may come in conflict.
Where a highway includes two (2) roadways forty feet (40') or more apart, then every crossing of each roadway of the divided highway by an intersecting
highway shall be regarded as a separate intersection.
LANED HIGHWAY: A street, the roadway of which is divided into two (2) or more clearly marked lanes for vehicular traffic.
LOADING ZONE: The space adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers or materials.
METAL TIRE: Every tire the surface of which in contact with the roadway is wholly or partly of metal or other hard, nonresilient material.
MOTOR VEHICLE: Every vehicle that is self-propelled, and every vehicle which is propelled by electric power obtained from overhead trolley wires, but not
operated upon rails, except for vehicles moved solely by human power and motorized wheelchairs.
MOTORCYCLE: Every motor vehicle having a saddle for the use of the rider and designed to travel on not more than three (3) wheels in contact with the
ground, but excluding a tractor.
MOTORIZED PEDALCYCLE: A motor driven cycle whose speed attainable in one mile is thirty (30) miles per hour or less, that is equipped with a motor
that produces two (2) brake horsepower or less. If an internal combustion engine is used, the displacement shall not exceed fifty (50) cubic centimeter
displacement and the power drive system shall not require the operator to shift gears.
PARK: To stand a vehicle, whether occupied or not, for a period of time greater than is reasonably necessary for the actual loading or unloading of
passengers and/or materials.
PEDESTRIAN: Any person afoot.
PERSON WITH A DISABILITY: A natural person who, as determined by a licensed physician: a) cannot walk without the use of, or assistance from, a
brace, cane, crutch, another person, prosthetic device, wheelchair, or other assistive device; b) is restricted by lung disease to such an extent that his or
her forced (respiratory) expiratory volume for one second, when measured by spirometry, is less than one liter, or the arterial oxygen tension is less than
sixty (60) mm/hg on room air at rest; c) uses portable oxygen; d) has a cardiac condition to the extent that the person's functional limitations are classified
in severity as class III or class IV, according to standards set by the American Heart Association; e) is severely limited in his or her ability to walk due to an
arthritic, neurological, or orthopedic condition; or f) cannot walk two hundred feet (200') without stopping to rest because of one of the above conditions.
PNEUMATIC TIRE: Every tire in which compressed air is designed to support the load.
PROPERTY LINE: The line marking the boundary between any street and the lots of property abutting thereon.
PUBLIC BUILDING: A building used by the village, county, any park district, school district, township, the state of Illinois, or the United States government.
RESCUE VEHICLE: Any publicly or privately owned vehicle that is specifically designed, configured, and equipped for the performance of access and
extrication of persons from hazardous or life endangering situations, as well as for the emergency transportation of persons who are sick, injured,
wounded or otherwise incapacitated or helpless.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 143/524
RESIDENCE DISTRICT: Any territory not comprising a business district, contiguous to and including a highway, when the property on the highway is in the
main improved with residences or residences and buildings in use for business for a distance of three hundred feet (300') or more.
RIGHT OF WAY: The right of one vehicle or pedestrian to proceed in a lawful manner in preference to another vehicle or pedestrian approaching under
such circumstances of direction, speed, and proximity as to give rise to danger of collision unless one grants precedence to the other.
ROAD TRACTOR: Every motor vehicle designed and used for the drawing of other vehicles and not so constructed as to carry any load thereon either
independently or any part of the weight of a vehicle or load so drawn.
ROADWAY: That portion of the street designed or ordinarily used for vehicular traffic, exclusive of the berm or shoulder.
SAFETY ZONE: The area or space officially set apart within a roadway for the exclusive use of pedestrians and that is protected or is so marked or
indicated by adequate signs as to be plainly visible at all times while set apart as a safety zone.
SCHOOL VEHICLE: Every motor vehicle of the second division operated by or for a public or governmental agency or by or for a private or religious
organization solely for the transportation of its pupils in connection with school activities.
SEMITRAILER: Every vehicle without motor power designed for carrying persons or property and for being drawn by a motor vehicle and so constructed
that some part of its weight and that of its load rests upon or is carried by another vehicle.
SHOULDER: That portion of the highway adjacent to the roadway for accommodating stopped vehicles or for emergency use.
SIDEWALK: That portion of the street between the curb line or roadway and the adjacent property line designated for pedestrian use.
SNOWMOBILE: A self-propelled device designed for travel on snow or ice or natural terrain steered by skis or runners, and supported in part by skis,
belts, or cleats.
SOLID TIRE: Every tire of rubber or other resilient material that does not depend upon compressed air for the support of the load.
STREET OR HIGHWAY: The entire width between the property lines of every way or place of whatever nature when any part thereof is open to the use of
the public, as a matter of right, for the purpose of vehicular traffic.
THROUGH HIGHWAY: Every highway or portion thereof on which vehicular traffic is given preferential right of way, and at the entrances to which vehicular
traffic from intersecting highways is required by law to yield right of way to vehicles on such through highway in obedience to either a stop sign or a yield
sign, when such signs are erected as provided in this title. Only those streets, or parts of streets, that have been or may be designated as through streets
by the village board of trustees shall be considered as such for the purpose of this title.
TRAFFIC: Pedestrians, ridden or herded animals, vehicles, and other conveyances whether singly or together while using any highway for the purpose of
travel.
TRAILER: Every vehicle without motor power designed for carrying passengers or property and for being drawn by a motor vehicle and so constructed that
no part of its weight rests upon the towing vehicle.
TRUCK TRACTOR: Every motor vehicle designed and used primarily for drawing other vehicles and not so constructed as to carry a load other than a part
of the weight of the vehicle and load so drawn.
URBAN DISTRICT: Any area developed primarily for residential and/or business purposes.
VEHICLE: Every device, in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, except devices moved by human
power, devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks, and snowmobiles as defined in the snowmobile registration and safety act.
VEHICLE CODE: The Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-100 et seq. (Ord. 2005-02-333, 2-7-2005; amd. Ord. 2008-06-570, 6-16-
2008)

Every vehicle that is self-propelled and every vehicle that is propelled by electric power obtained from overhead trolley wires, but not operated upon rails,

First division: Those motor vehicles that are designed for the carrying of not more than ten (10) persons.
Second division: Those motor vehicles that are designed for carrying more than ten (10) persons, those motor vehicles designed or used for living
