post-tow appeal pursuant to subsection A of this section.
C. Post-Tow Hearing:
1. Scheduling Of Hearing; Waiver: The Police Chief shall schedule, in consultation with the registered owner of the towed vehicle, a post-tow hearing
no later than three (3) days, excluding weekends and holidays, after the Police Chief receives the notice of post-tow appeal pursuant to subsection A
of this section, or on such later day as is mutually agreed by the parties. The registered owner shall be deemed to have waived the right to a posttow
appeal if the registered owner fails to appear for the post-tow hearing without prior notice of absence and good cause shown therefor.
2. Conduct Of Hearing; Burden: The Police Chief may conduct the post-tow hearing or may appoint a Hearing Officer to conduct the hearing. The
Enforcement Officer responsible for the decision to tow the vehicle shall not serve as the Hearing Officer. The Hearing Officer may be the same
Hearing Officer as presided over the pre-tow hearing regarding the same vehicle. The registered owner of the vehicle must appear in person at the
hearing. To invalidate the tow, the registered owner must submit evidence that conclusively demonstrates that the towing of the vehicle was not
authorized pursuant to this article or was otherwise invalid. The Police Chief or Hearing Officer shall have the authority to require the presence of the
Enforcement Officer who was responsible for the tow and any other Village personnel, and to request the presence of other witnesses at the hearing.
3. No Determination Of Violations: A post-tow appeal and hearing shall not be determinative of, and shall not be used or construed to adjudicate, any
citation or violation of any Village ordinance relating to the vehicle in question.
D. Decision On Post-Tow Appeal:
1. Decision: Based on the hearing record, the Police Chief shall issue a written decision: a) affirming, in whole or in part, the validity of the tow or any
related fines and fees, or b) invalidating, in whole or in part, the tow or any related fines and fees. The Police Chief shall deliver a copy of the Police
Chief's decision to the registered owner of the vehicle in question within three (3) days after the conclusion of the post-tow hearing. The decision of
the Police Chief on a post-tow appeal shall be final.
2. Action If Affirmation: If the Police Chief affirms the validity of the tow of a vehicle that has been released pursuant to section 6-8D-10 of this article,
then the Village shall retain all amounts paid pursuant to subsection 6-8D-10A of this article. If the Police Chief affirms the validity of the tow of a
vehicle that has not been released pursuant to section 6-8D-10 of this article, then the Police Chief shall include in the Police Chief's decision: a) an
explanation that the registered owner may secure the release of the towed vehicle pursuant to the provisions set forth in section 6-8D-10 of this
article, and b) the total amount of fines and fees, accrued to that date, that must be paid prior to release of the vehicle in question.
3. Action If Invalidated: If the Police Chief invalidates in whole the subject tow, then the Village shall, in the case of a previously released vehicle, return
to the registered owner all amounts received pursuant to section 6-8D-10 of this article, or, if the vehicle has not been released, authorize the
immediate release of the vehicle. (Ord. 2017-3-186, 3-20-2017)
6-8D-12: DISPOSITION IF NO RELEASE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 178/524
If the registered owner of a towed vehicle does not secure the release of the vehicle pursuant to the procedures set forth in this article within thirty (30)
days if the vehicle is seven (7) years old or newer or within ten (10) days if the vehicle is older than seven (7) years old after the delivery or mailing of the
post-tow notice, then the vehicle may be sold or otherwise disposed of pursuant to the Vehicle Code and all other applicable State and local statutes,
codes, ordinances, and regulations. (Ord. 2017-3-186, 3-20-2017)
6-8D-13: FEES:
A. Towing Fee: The fee for towing any vehicle pursuant to this article shall be pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of this Code.
B. Impoundment Fee: The fee for impounding any vehicle towed pursuant to this article shall be pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of this
Code.
C. Nonresident Emergency Lock Out Service Fee: The fee for entry into a locked vehicle by the Police Department is pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee
Schedule", of this Code for nonresidents. This fee will not be imposed: (Ord. 2017-3-186, 3-20-2017; amd. Ord. 2018-12-279, 12-3-2018)
1. On a Village resident requesting entry to a locked vehicle that he or she has a current right to operate; or
2. On an operator of a vehicle owned by any Federal, State, County, or Municipal agency if the operator is engaged in the course of his or her Federal,
State, County, or Municipal duties; or
3. For entry into a vehicle owned and currently being operated by a Village employee; or
4. On an operator of a vehicle when that vehicle or its contents poses an immediate hazard and the vehicle therefore must be removed immediately
from its current location; or
5. On an operator, regardless of Village residency, of a locked vehicle that is occupied by a person who cannot unlock the vehicle and there is a
potential health or safety risk; or
6. For other exigent circumstances as determined by the responding police officer. (Ord. 2017-3-186, 3-20-2017)
6-8D-14: PARKING INOPERATIVE VEHICLES:
A. No person shall stand or park a vehicle upon any roadway, Municipally owned parking lot, or on property owned by the Village in an inoperative
condition for more than ten (10) hours.
B. An inoperative vehicle parked as described in subsection A of this section may be towed away at the owner's expense after ten (10) hours, unless the
parking of the vehicle constitutes an immediate safety hazard, in which case the vehicle may be towed away immediately at the owner's expense. The
Police Department shall make an effort to notify the registered owner of the vehicle of the intent to tow the vehicle prior to its towing. If the Police
Department attempts to locate the owner of the vehicle at the address the vehicle is registered at, and the owner could not be located, the Police
Department has complied with this section. (Ord. 2005-02-333, 2-7-2005)
6-8D-15: LIABILITY FOR DAMAGES:
Any police officer, towing service owner, operator, or employee shall not be held to answer or be liable for damages in any action brought by the registered
owner, former registered owner, a legal representative of the registered owner or former registered owner, or any other person legally entitled to the
possession of a motor vehicle or other vehicle when the vehicle was processed and sold or disposed of as provided by this article. (Ord. 2005-02-333, 2-7-
2005)
ARTICLE E. PENALTIES; IMPOUNDMENT
6-8E-1: PRIMA FACIE PROOF:
The fact that an automobile that is illegally operated or parked is registered in the name of a person shall be considered prima facie proof that the person
was in control of the automobile at the time of the violation. (Ord. 2005-02-333, 2-7-2005)
6-8E-2: PENALTIES:
A. Citation Fine: Any person to whom a parking citation has been issued under this article, other than for a violation of subsection 6-8A-5A of this chapter,
who has removed the offending vehicle from the place where it had been illegally parked (before the vehicle had been removed or impounded by police
order) may avoid prosecution for the citation by paying the sum pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of this Code. (Ord. 2005-02-333, 2-7-
2005; amd. Ord. 2018-12-279, 12-3-2018)
At any time after twenty (20) days after such citation is issued, the fine shall be as prescribed in subsection C of this section.
B. Disabled Persons Parking Spaces: Any person violating subsection 6-8A-5A of this chapter shall be penalized in accordance with the Illinois Vehicle
Code.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 179/524
C. Fines Forwarded For Collection: If the Village of Lake Zurich does not receive payment pursuant to subsection A of this section, then the Village may
implement collection proceedings to recover the payment in accordance with the following procedure: (Ord. 2005-02-333, 2-7-2005)
1. The Village shall issue notice to the registered owner of the offending vehicle by first class postage prepaid U.S. mail, which notice shall state that
the owner may pay pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of this Code to the Village within ten (10) days after the date of that notice in full
satisfaction of the citation, and that, if the payment is not received within the ten (10) day period, then the fine applicable to the violation shall
increase pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of this Code, and that the Village may initiate collection proceedings if payment is not
received within the ten (10) day period. (Ord. 2005-02-333, 2-7-2005; amd. Ord. 2018-12-279, 12-3-2018)
2. If payment is not received within the ten (10) day period, then the Village shall issue a second notice to the registered owner of the offending vehicle
by first class postage prepaid U.S. mail, which notice shall state the following: (Ord. 2005-02-333, 2-7-2005)
a. The fine for the violation is pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of this Code; and
b. The fine may be paid on or before a date certain not less than ten (10) days after the date of the second notice; and (Ord. 2005-02-333, 2-7-2005;
amd. Ord. 2018-12-279, 12-3-2018)
c. If payment is not received, then the Village shall immediately implement collection proceedings against the owner. (Ord. 2005-02-333, 2-7-2005)
D. Exceptions: The procedures established in this section shall not apply to the following circumstances:
1. Persons parking a vehicle so as to obstruct the entrance or exit of any place where police, fire, or other emergency apparatus or vehicles are
located; or
2. Persons parking a vehicle so as to block any emergency entrance to any hospital or other medical facility; or
3. Persons parking a vehicle so as to entirely obstruct traffic in any street or alley or so as to reduce traffic on any arterial street to one-way traffic only;
or
4. Persons who refuse to move a vehicle parked illegally at the request of any member of the Lake Zurich Police Department.
The department shall take such actions under these circumstances as may be authorized by law. (Ord. 2005-02-333, 2-7-2005; amd. Ord. 2009-10-
666, 10-5-2009)
6-8E-3: IMPOUNDING VEHICLES:
A. Members of the Police Department of this Village are hereby authorized to remove a vehicle from a private parking space or lot to the nearest Village
vehicle pound or authorized garage as determined and designated by the Chief of Police, under the following circumstances:
1. When the private space or lot is clearly marked or posted with a sign containing a warning "Private Parking, No Trespassing, Violators Will Be Towed
Away At Their Expense", or words to that effect; and
2. When the owner or proprietor of the space or lot, or his authorized agent, signs a written complaint for trespassing, as defined by the Illinois Criminal
Code; and
3. When the owner or proprietor of the space or lot, or his duly authorized agent, deposits with the Police Department a sum of money sufficient to
cover the minimum towing and storage charges to be incurred by the Village in removing and storing the vehicle.
Vehicles shall also be impounded when required by the Vehicle Code, such as for operating a motor vehicle without a license.
B. Any person seeking to redeem a vehicle impounded pursuant to this title shall first pay all towing and storage charges incurred by the Village, as a
condition precedent to the right to redeem the vehicle. (Ord. 2005-02-333, 2-7-2005)
Chapter 9
VEHICLE IMPOUNDMENT
6-9-1: VEHICLES SUBJECT TO IMPOUNDMENT:
Pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-208.7 a motor vehicle may be impounded upon probable cause to believe that an individual has used a
motor vehicle in the commission of any of the following offenses:
A. Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit, an offense for which a motor vehicle may be seized and forfeited
pursuant to 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/36-1; or
B. Driving under the influence of alcohol, another drug or drugs, an intoxicating compound or compounds, or any combination thereof, in violation of 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-501; or
C. Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit, a felony or in violation of the Cannabis Control Act1; or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 180/524
D. Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit, an offense in violation of the Illinois Controlled Substances Act2;
or
E. Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit, an offense in violation of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-1,
Unlawful Use of Weapons; 5/24-1.5, Reckless Discharge of a Firearm; or 5/24-3.1, Unlawful Possession of Firearms and Firearm Ammunition; or
F. Driving while a driver's license, permit, or privilege to operate a motor vehicle is suspended or revoked pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-
303; except that vehicles shall not be subjected to seizure or impoundment if the suspension is for an unpaid citation (parking or moving) or due to
failure to comply with emission testing; or
G. Operation or use of a motor vehicle while soliciting, possessing, or attempting to solicit or possess cannabis or a controlled substance, as defined by
the Cannabis Control Act3 or the Illinois Controlled Substances Act4; or
H. Operation or use of a motor vehicle with an expired driver's license, in violation of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-101, if the period of expiration is
greater than one (1) year; or
I. Operation or use of a motor vehicle without ever having been issued a driver's license or permit, in violation of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-101, or
operating a motor vehicle without ever having been issued a driver's license or permit due to a person's age; or
J. Operation or use of a motor vehicle by a person against whom a warrant has been issued by a Circuit Clerk in Illinois for failing to answer charges that
the driver violated 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-101, 5/6-303, or 5/11-501; or
K. Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit, an offense in violation of article 16, Theft and Related Offenses,
or article 16A, Retail Theft, of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes; or
L. Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit, any other misdemeanor or felony offense in violation of 720 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/1-1 et seq., when so provided by this Code. (Ord. 2012-01-806, 1-16-2012)
6-9-2: SEIZURE AND IMPOUNDMENT:
A. Whenever a police officer has probable cause to believe that a motor vehicle is subject to seizure and impoundment pursuant to section 6-9-1 of this
chapter, the police officer may cause the vehicle to be towed to a facility approved by the Chief of Police. A reasonable administrative fee pursuant to
title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of this Code may be imposed by the Village upon the owner of record or the agents of the registered owner. For
purposes of this chapter, owner of record is the person or entity recorded with the Illinois Secretary of State as the vehicle owner or listed in the registry
of motor vehicles of another state. It is not necessary for criminal charges to be filed, prosecuted or proven in order to seize and impound a motor
vehicle pursuant to this section. An administrative fee shall not be assessed if verifiable proof is presented confirming that the motor vehicle was stolen
at the time the motor vehicle was impounded. (Ord. 2016-7-141, 7-5-2016; amd. Ord. 2018-12-279, 12-3-2018)
B. Any administration fee imposed shall be in addition to: 1) any other penalties that may be assessed by a court of law for the underlying violations; and
2) any towing or storage fees, or both, charged by the towing company.
C. The administrative fee assessed shall be uniform for all similarly situated motor vehicles. (Ord. 2016-7-141, 7-5-2016)
6-9-3: NOTICE OF HEARING:
The registered owner or lessee of the vehicle and any lienholder of record shall be provided with a notice of hearing. The notice shall:
A. Be served upon the owner, lessee and any lienholder of record either by personal service or by first class mail to the interested party's address as
registered with the Secretary of State;
B. Be served upon interested parties within ten (10) days after a vehicle is impounded by the Village; and
C. Contain the date, time and location of the administrative hearing. An initial hearing shall be scheduled and convened no later than forty five (45) days
after the date of the mailing of the notice of hearing. (Ord. 2012-01-806, 1-16-2012)
6-9-4: IMPOUNDMENT HEARING PROCEDURES:
A. The Chief of Police shall designate the Hearing Officer for hearings pursuant to this section. The Hearing Officer may not determine or adjudicate any
citation issued relative to the vehicle. The Hearing Officer shall be an attorney licensed to practice law in the State of Illinois for no less than three (3)
years and shall, at all times, be in good standing with the Illinois Attorney Registration and Disciplinary Commission.
B. All interested persons must be given a reasonable opportunity to be heard at an impoundment hearing pursuant to this section. The formal rules of
evidence will not apply at the hearing. The hearing shall be recorded.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 181/524
C. A violation citation is prima facie evidence that a motor vehicle was used in violation of section 6-9-1 of this chapter, and the burden of proof is on the
owner of record of the vehicle to prove that a violation was not committed.
D. After reviewing all relevant evidence presented at an impoundment hearing, the Hearing Officer must determine, based on a preponderance of the
evidence, whether lawful cause existed for the seizure and impoundment of the vehicle. The Hearing Officer must record this determination and the
basis for the determination in writing, and must provide the owner of record with a copy of the written determination.
E. If the Hearing Officer determines that lawful cause existed for seizure and impoundment of the motor vehicle, then the written determination of the
Hearing Officer must state that the vehicle was being used in violation of section 6-9-1 of this chapter and indicate the administrative penalty due in
accordance with section 6-9-6 of this chapter. Any administrative fee posted with the Village shall be forfeited to the Village upon entry of an order that
lawful cause existed for seizure and impoundment of the motor vehicle.
F. If the Hearing Officer determines that lawful cause did not exist for seizure and impoundment of the motor vehicle, then the written determination of the
Hearing Officer must direct that the vehicle be released. The written determination is an order for release that entitles the owner of record to release of
the vehicle without payment of any administrative penalty or towing or storage charges. If the Hearing Officer finds that the Village exceeded its
authority in impounding a vehicle, the Village shall be liable to the registered owner or lessee of the vehicle for the costs of storage fees and
reasonable attorneys' fees. The motor vehicle shall be released to the owner, lessee or lienholder of record upon full payment of the administrative fee
and all towing and storage charges. (Ord. 2017-2-173, 2-6-2017)
6-9-5: UNPAID PENALTIES:
Unless stayed by a court of competent jurisdiction, any fine, penalty or administrative fee imposed under this chapter which remains unpaid in whole or in
part after the expiration of the deadline for seeking review under section 6-9-11 of this chapter, may be enforced in the same manner as a judgment
entered by a court of competent jurisdiction. (Ord. 2012-01-806, 1-16-2012)
6-9-6: ADMINISTRATIVE PENALTY:
The owner of record of a motor vehicle seized and impounded pursuant to section 6-9-1 of this chapter must pay an administrative penalty pursuant to title
13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of this Code plus applicable towing and storage costs, unless otherwise determined by the Hearing Officer. An
administrative penalty imposed pursuant to this section constitutes a debt due and owing the Village, and is due immediately. In the event of a hearing
before the Hearing Officer or an appeal of the Hearing Officer's decision, payment of an administrative penalty under this section will be deemed due on
the date of issuance of the Hearing Officer's decision or the final court order. (Ord. 2017-2-173, 2-6-2017; amd. Ord. 2018-12-279, 12-3-2018)
6-9-7: DISPOSITION OF IMPOUNDED VEHICLE:
A vehicle impounded pursuant to this chapter will remain impounded until:
A. The owner pays the amount of the penalty due in accordance with section 6-9-6 of this chapter; or
B. The owner posts a bond in accordance with section 6-9-8 of this chapter; or
C. The Hearing Officer issues a written determination pursuant to subsection 6-9-4F of this chapter directing that the vehicle be released, in which case
the Village will be responsible for towing and storage fees due to the towing service; or
D. The vehicle is deemed abandoned pursuant to section 6-9-9 of this chapter, in which case the vehicle may be disposed of in the manner provided by
law for the disposition of abandoned vehicles. (Ord. 2012-01-806, 1-16-2012)
6-9-8: POSTING OF BOND:
A. A vehicle seized and impounded pursuant to section 6-9-1 of this chapter will be released to the owner of record if a bond in the amount of four hundred
dollars ($400.00) is posted with the Police Department.
B. All bond money posted pursuant to this section will be held by the Village until the Hearing Officer issues a decision pursuant to section 6-9-4 of this
chapter, or if judicial review is sought, until the court issues its decision.
C. An individual posting the prescribed bond may waive his right to a hearing by indicating such in writing any time prior to the assigned hearing date/time.
(Ord. 2017-2-173, 2-6-2017)
6-9-9: ABANDONMENT:
If a penalty due under section 6-9-6 of this chapter is not paid within thirty five (35) days, then the vehicle is deemed abandoned and may be disposed of in
the manner provided by law for the disposition of abandoned vehicles. (Ord. 2012-01-806, 1-16-2012)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 182/524
6-9-10: MONIES DEPOSITED:
All penalties collected and retained by the Village for a violation of this chapter must be deposited with the Finance Director. (Ord. 2012-01-806, 1-16-
2012)
6-9-11: ADMINISTRATIVE REVIEW:
Any owner of record, lienholder or other person with a legal interest in the motor vehicle, shall have the right to appeal the decision of the Hearing Officer
to the 19th Judicial Circuit Court, pursuant to the Administrative Review Act, 735 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-101 et seq., as amended. Any respondent
seeking review of a final decision shall be required to reimburse the Village for the costs of preparing and certifying the record of proceedings. Failure of
the respondent to reimburse the Village shall be grounds for the dismissal of a complaint for administrative review pursuant to 735 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/3-109. In the event the reviewing court reverses the findings, decision and order of the Administrative Law Judge, the Village will reimburse the
respondent for the costs for preparing and certifying the record of proceedings. Any administrative fee posted with the Village to secure the release of a
motor vehicle prior to a hearing shall be held by the Village until the Hearing Officer issues a decision or, if there is judicial review of the Hearing Officer's
decision, until a reviewing court issues a final decision. (Ord. 2012-01-806, 1-16-2012)
Title 7
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
Chapter 1
STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC WAYS
7-1-1: DATUM AND BENCH MARK:
A permanent base or datum for the village is hereby established as 863.80 USGS sea level datum and is established as a cross cut in the top of the
anchor bolt on the northwest leg of the water tower on Route 22 (Main Street) behind the village hall. (1989 Code)
7-1-2: DEPOSITS ON PUBLIC WAYS:
A. No person shall deposit or drop any dirt, clay or garbage on any street within the village. Any person depositing or spilling dirt, clay, garbage or any
foreign substance on a village street or right of way shall immediately stop and remove the same.
B. It is required that any person engaged in construction work and using the village roadways and rights of way shall remove from the village roadways
and rights of way, at least twice each day, or more often if so directed by the police department, all foreign materials deposited by such person on the
roadways and rights of way. "Twice each day" shall mean twelve o'clock (12:00) noon and four thirty o'clock (4:30) P.M. Scraping the road surface and
depositing the material on the shoulder of the road may be permitted in the intervals prior to the specified removal times, and the material deposited on
the shoulder of the road shall then be removed as specified above or as directed by the police department. Such direction by the police department
shall be exercised in its discretion to maintain driving safety in cases of extremely heavy deposits, extremely light deposits or construction projects
carried on during hours other than the normal eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. to four thirty o'clock (4:30) P.M., five (5) day workweek. (1989 Code)
7-1-3: USE OF PUBLIC WAYS RESTRICTED:
A. Merchandise On Sidewalks: Goods, wares and merchandise may be placed on sidewalks for such reasonable time as may be necessary while loading
and unloading; provided pedestrian traffic is not obstructed.
B. Storage Of Building Materials: Any person not holding a building permit shall not store any materials on any street, sidewalk or public place without a
permit therefor from the village. (1989 Code)
7-1-4: ENCROACHMENTS:
A. Permit Requirements: No person shall erect or maintain any structure or thing on, over or under any street, alley, sidewalk or public way except by
permit from the board of trustees. Application for such permit shall describe the nature of the encroachment in such detail as the board shall require.
The board in its discretion may issue or deny the permit and may impose any conditions to such permit it deems appropriate.
B. Exemption From Permit: Awnings made of a pliable substance attached to a building and extending not less than eight feet (8') above the surface of the
sidewalk may be erected and maintained without a permit.
C. Maintenance Of Encroachment: Any encroachment on any street, alley, sidewalk or public way shall be maintained so that it does not endanger or
obstruct the public.
D. Violations Declared A Nuisance: Any encroachment maintained in violation of this section is declared a nuisance and may be abated by the village.
(1989 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 183/524
7-1-5: PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
A. Obstructing Public Ways: No person shall obstruct or endanger the free passage or proper use of the public of any street, sidewalk, alley or public
place, except as may be permitted by this code.
B. Damaging Public Ways And Property: No person shall damage or deface any street, alley, sidewalk, public way, park or other public property, or any
post, wire, lamp, street sign, traffic sign, tree, grass, vegetation, gutter, drain, manhole or any other appurtenance thereon, except as may be
authorized by the village. (1989 Code)
C. Games On Sidewalks: No person shall engage in any game, sport or amusement of any kind upon any sidewalk in any commercial or industrial zone in
such a manner as to interfere with the passage of persons using same. (Ord. 90-03-378, 3-19-1990)
D. Metal Detectors: No person shall use or operate on public property a metal detector, or any other similar sensing device, for the purpose of locating or
removing objects from below the grass or the surface of the soil, and no person shall, as a corollary of such use, damage, dig into, or otherwise injure
or alter any public property. (Ord. 97-08-868, 8-4-1997)
7-1-5-1: OBSTRUCTIONS IN PUBLIC RIGHTS OF WAY:
A. Obstructions Prohibited: No person shall place, keep, or maintain any "obstruction", as that term is defined in subsection B of this section, in any public
right of way except only as provided in this section or as otherwise specifically provided by village code or ordinance.
B. Definition Of Obstruction: For purposes of this section, the word "obstruction" shall mean all of the following objects located within the public right of way
if such objects are within nine feet (9') of the paved portion of the right of way:
1. Every boulder or large stone or rock; and
2. Every pole, post, or similar object laid on, or set into, the ground which protrudes or extends more than four inches (4") above the ground; and
3. Any other object which protrudes or extends more than eight inches (8") above the ground, except as otherwise provided in this section.
The term "obstruction" shall not include: streetlights, traffic signs and signals, and similar objects and devices authorized by law; or fire hydrants and
other public utility devices and equipment authorized by law; or parkway trees authorized by the village; or flowers and small shrubs not exceeding
eighteen inches (18") in height. (Ord. 95-04-727, 4-17-1995)
C. Removal Of Obstructions: Except as provided in subsection D of this section, all obstructions shall be removed as soon as reasonably practical, but in
no event later than October 31, 1997. (Ord. 96-09-828, 9-16-1996)
D. Exceptions To Removal Requirement:
1. Retaining Walls: Notwithstanding the provisions of subsections A, B, and C of this section, retaining walls constructed prior to the effective date of
this section shall not be required to be removed. (Ord. 95-04-727, 4-17-1995)
2. Other Exceptions: The village manager may grant additional exceptions to the application of this section, but only after written application
establishing, to the satisfaction of the village manager, all of the following factors: a) the obstruction does not pose, and will never pose, a threat to
the public health or safety, and b) removal of the obstruction poses a hardship on the applicant, and c) the grant of an exception does not create a
special privilege to the applicant not generally available to residents of the village. No exception shall be granted for reasons of aesthetics. The
village manager may impose such conditions on the grant of an exception hereunder as the village manager determines are reasonable and
necessary to protect the public health and safety. (Ord. 95-04-727, 4-17-1995; amd. Ord. 2012-10-861, 10-1-2012)
E. Village Removal If Violation: The village shall remove obstructions in accordance with the following standards: (Ord. 95-04-727, 4-17-1995)
1. Immediate Removal: The village manager shall cause the immediate removal of any obstruction that the village manager determines poses a threat
to the public health or safety.
2. Removal After Notice: In the case of any other obstruction placed, kept, or maintained in violation of this section, the Village Manager shall cause
notice of the violation to be given to the owner of the property abutting the right-of-way on which such obstruction is located, which notice shall state
that the violation shall be cured within ten (10) days after the date of such notice. If the violation is not cured within such ten (10) day period, then the
Village Manager shall cause the obstruction to be removed promptly. (Ord. 95-04-727, 4-17-1995; amd. Ord. 2012-10-861, 10-1-2012)
7-1-5-2: MAILBOXES ON PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY:
A. Placement Restricted:
1. Except as provided in this sentence and in subsection A2 of this section, no mailbox shall be placed or maintained within any Village right-of-way
except when required by Federal laws or regulations for delivery of U.S. mail. When so required, only one mailbox per residence or per
nonresidential lot may be placed within the Village right-of-way except multiple user mailboxes approved by the United States Postal Service. All
mailboxes placed within Village right-of-way shall conform to the requirements of this section.
2. A mailbox placed in a Village right-of-way prior to September 1, 1997, may remain in the right-of-way subject to the following conditions: a) the
mailbox is maintained by the property owner in good condition at all times, including prompt repair of any element of such mailbox needing repair; b)
the mailbox may not be rebuilt, enlarged, or moved at any time except only if such mailbox is moved out of the right-of-way; c) the mailbox shall be
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 184/524
removed from the right-of-way immediately if the building it serves has closed or been removed or relocated; d) the mailbox shall be removed from
the right-of-way immediately if the Village determines in the exercise of its sole discretion that such mailbox poses a particular threat to public safety.
(Ord. 97-10-879, 10-6-1997)
B. Location: No mailbox shall be placed so that it extends to a point within eight inches (8") of the edge of the pavement. Every mailbox shall be placed at
a height consistent with Federal laws and regulations. (Ord. 95-04-727, 4-17-1995)
C. Support Structure: Every mailbox permitted within the Village right-of-way pursuant to subsection A1 of this section shall be mounted either on a
wooden post no smaller than four inches by four inches (4" x 4") and no larger than six inches by six inches (6" x 6") or on a light gauge hollow pipe no
smaller than one and one-half inches (11/2") in diameter and no larger than three inches (3") in diameter. The Village Manager may approve a different
support structure, but only if the Village Manager finds that such support structure is as safe as the structures provided herein. The support structure
shall be firmly secured in the ground. Under no circumstances shall any support structure constructed, reconstructed, replaced, moved, or repaired (if
damaged to the extent of 50 percent of its value at the time of repair) after September 1, 1997, include a masonry column, concrete, railroad rails or
ties, a tractor wheel, a plow blade, a milk can, a barrel, a lawn tractor, or any similar object or device. (Ord. 97-10-879, 10-6-1997; amd. Ord. 2012-10-
861, 10-1-2012)
D. Removal Of Nonconforming Mailboxes: Except as provided in subsection A2 of this section, all mailboxes that do not comply with the provisions of this
section shall be removed on or before October 31, 1997. (Ord. 97-10-879, 10-6-1997)
E. Damage By Village: If a mailbox located within the Village's right-of-way is damaged by the Village, then the Village shall be required to, but only to: 1)
repair such mailbox, or 2) replace such mailbox with a standard U.S. Postal Service box and support structure complying with the standards set forth in
the first sentence of subsection C of this section, or 3) reimburse the owner for damages in amounts limited as follows: not more than thirty dollars
($30.00) for replacement of a post; or not more than twenty dollars ($20.00) for replacement of a mailbox; or not more than fifty dollars ($50.00) for
replacement of both a post and a mailbox. (Ord. 2007-05-497, 5-21-2007)
F. No Reconstruction, Repair Or Replacement: No mailbox that does not conform to the requirements of this section shall be reconstructed, replaced,
moved, or repaired if deteriorated or damaged to the extent of fifty percent (50%) of its value at the time of repair, unless such resulting mailbox shall
fully conform to the requirements of subsections B and C of this section. (Ord. 95-04-727, 4-17-1995)
G. Penalty: Any person violating any provision of this section shall be fined pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of this Code for each offense. A
separate offense shall be deemed to have been committed for each violation and for each day on which such violation occurs or continues.
H. Payments To Avoid Prosecution: A person charged with a violation of this section may avoid prosecution by paying to the Village the amounts pursuant
to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of this Code for each violation within the time specified. (Ord. 95-04-727, 4-17-1995; amd. Ord. 2018-12-279, 12-
3-2018)
After twenty five (25) days, the fine must be paid in full or a court appearance will be required. (Ord. 95-04-727, 4-17-1995)
7-1-5-3: DAMAGE TO PUBLIC WAYS OR PROPERTY:
No person shall damage or deface any street, alley, sidewalk, public way, park, or other public property or any post, wire, lamp, street sign, traffic sign,
tree, grass, vegetation, gutter, drain, manhole, or any other public property, except as may be specifically authorized in advance by the Village. (Ord. 95-
04-727, 4-17-1995)
7-1-6: STREET NAMES:
All streets of the Village shall be known and designated by the names applied hereto, respectively, on the map of the Village kept on file in the Office of the
Village Clerk and the street names designated on said map shall continue to be the names of streets unless and until changed by ordinance of the Board
of Trustees. (1989 Code)
7-1-7: NUMBERING BUILDINGS:
Buildings located along the streets of the Village shall be numbered in accordance with a chart kept by the Village Clerk showing the proper street number
of each lot. The owner of any such building shall place such number on his building so as to be visible from the street. (1989 Code)
7-1-8: MOTORIZED SKATEBOARDS:
A. Definition: For the purposes of this section, "motorized skateboard" means any device that has a deck or platform on which a person may stand or sit,
with two (2) or more wheels, and that is self-propelled by any type of motor or engine; provided, however, that the term "motorized skateboard" shall
not include the following: 1) a motor vehicle1; 2) a motorcycle2; 3) a motor driven cycle3; 4) a motorized pedalcycle4; or 5) a motorized wheelchair5 or
other device designed and used to transport a person with a disability.
B. Limitation On Use: With the exception of authorized employees and officers of the Village of Lake Zurich, United States Postal Service employees, and
other authorized governmental employees, no person shall operate or ride a motorized skateboard on or within any of the following places within the
Village: private streets and rights-of-way, public streets and rights-of-way, public sidewalks, public parking lots or areas, public parks, and any other
public property. (Ord. 2002-12-205, 12-2-2002)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 185/524
C. Fine; Impoundment And Redemption: Any person violating this section may be subject to a citation and imposition of a fine pursuant to the general
penalty provisions set forth in section 1-3-2 of this Code. Additionally, any person who has been issued three (3) or more citations for violations of this
section within any twelve (12) month period will be required to surrender, at the time of issuance of a citation, the motorized skateboard to the police
officer or other authorized official who issues the citation. The surrendered motorized skateboard will be impounded and held by the Lake Zurich Police
Department and will be returned to its owner only after one of the following sets of conditions has been met: (Ord. 2010-02-697, 2-1-2010)
1. The person against whom the citation was issued shall have paid or caused to be paid: a) all outstanding fines and b) the fees and costs of the
Village in the amount pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of this Code; or (Ord. 2002-12-205, 12-2-2002; amd. Ord. 2018-12-279, 12-3-
2018)
2. The person against whom the citation was issued shall have: a) paid or caused to be paid all outstanding fines and b) presented to the Village proof
that a determination of not guilty was made for the cited offense. (Ord. 2002-12-205, 12-2-2002)
D. Payments To Avoid Prosecution: A person charged with a violation of this section may avoid prosecution by paying to the Village the amounts pursuant
to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of this Code for each violation within the time specified.
After thirty (30) days, the fine must be paid in full or a court appearance will be required. This subsection shall not affect the redemption fee set forth in
subsection C1 of this section. (Ord. 2002-12-205, 12-2-2002; amd. Ord. 2018-12-279, 12-3-2018)
ARTICLE A. EXCAVATIONS
7-1A-1: PERMIT REQUIRED; APPLICATION:
A permit shall be required to open or tunnel or to make any excavation in the street, alley or public space within the Village.
Application for such permit shall be made to the Director of Building and Zoning. The application shall describe the location of the intended excavation or
tunnel, size, purpose, contractor and owner of the property affected by said street crossing. (1989 Code; amd. Ord. 95-02-712, 2-21-1995)
7-1A-2: ISSUANCE OF PERMIT; FEES:
The Director of Building and Zoning shall issue such permit upon compliance with applicable sections of this article. (1989 Code; amd. Ord. 95-02-712, 2-
21-1995)
The fee for such permit, excluding public and quasi-public utilities operating under franchise with the Village, shall be pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee
Schedule", of this Code for excavation not in excess of three feet (3') in width and as determined for those in excess of three foot (3') widths.
The fee for street surface replacement shall be as set forth pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of this Code. (1989 Code; amd. Ord. 2018-12-
279, 12-3-2018)
7-1A-3: BOND AND DEPOSIT REQUIREMENTS:
A. Bond: Each person applying for such a permit shall file a bond conditioned that he will suitably guard or protect any excavation or obstruction
maintained or created by him, and will indemnify the Village for any loss or damage resulting from injury to any person or property caused by such
excavation or obstruction. For excavations not exceeding one hundred (100) square feet, the bond shall be in the amount of ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00) for each excavation open at one time.
B. Deposit: No such permit shall be issued unless and until the applicant therefor has deposited with the Clerk a cash deposit in the amount of one
hundred dollars ($100.00) to insure the proper restoration of the ground and laying of the pavement, if any. From this deposit shall be deducted the
expense to the Village of relaying the surface of the ground or pavement and of making the refill if this is done by the Village or at its expense, and the
balance shall be returned to the applicant without interest after the tunnel or excavation is completely refilled and the surface or pavement is restored.
(1989 Code)
7-1A-4: MANNER OF EXCAVATION:
A. General: All excavations within the street, public properties under pavement, curbing, sidewalk or other public improvement shall be by tunnel or boring,
unless otherwise authorized by the Board of Trustees.
It shall be unlawful to make any such excavation or tunnel in any way contrary to or at variance with the terms of the permit therefor. Proper bracing
shall be maintained to prevent the collapse of adjoining ground, and in excavations, the excavation shall not have anywhere below the surface any
portion which extends beyond the opening of the surface.
No injury shall be done to any pipe, cables or conduits in the making of such excavation or tunnel, and notice shall be given to the persons maintaining
any such pipes, cables or conduits or to the Village department or officer charged with the care thereof, which are or may be endangered or affected by
the making of any such excavation or tunnel before such pipes, cables or conduits shall be disturbed.
No unnecessary damage or injury shall be done to any tree or shrub or the roots thereof.
B. Sidewalks: If any sidewalk is blocked by any such work, a temporary sidewalk shall be constructed or provided which shall be safe for travel and
convenient for users. (1989 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 186/524
7-1A-5: BARRICADES AND LIGHTS:
Any person making or maintaining any tunnel or excavation in any street, alley or other public place shall keep the same adequately guarded by
barricades and lights to protect persons and property from injury. (1989 Code)
7-1A-6: RESTORATION OF EXCAVATED SITE:
A. Unpaved Areas: Any person making an excavation or tunnel in or under any public street, alley or other public place in the Village shall restore the
surface thereof to its original condition if there is no pavement there.
Refills shall be made of fresh clean gravel properly watered and tamped down, and any bracing in such tunnel or excavation shall be left in the ground.
B. Paved Areas: Any opening in a paved or improved portion of a street shall be repaired and the surface relaid by the applicant within seventy two (72)
hours, in compliance with all applicable ordinances.
If the excavation or opening has necessitated an opening in a pavement, the refill shall be properly made so that the surface pavement can be relaid by
the Village in the same manner and thickness and character as the surrounding pavement. Notice shall be given to the Clerk when such opening is
prepared for pavement, and the pavement shall be laid by the Village, either by contract or by Village employees. In either event, the surface relaid
may extend for at least one foot (1') in every direction beyond the original opening.
An accurate account of the expense and the cost of relaying such pavement shall be kept, and this amount shall be deducted from the cash deposit
mentioned in subsection 7-1A-3B of this article before the balance shall be returned. (1989 Code)
7-1A-7: SUPERVISION AND INSPECTION:
The Director of Public Works and the Director of Building and Zoning shall, from time to time, inspect all excavations and tunnels being made in or under
any public street, alley or other public place in the Village to see to the enforcement of the provisions of this article. Notice shall be given to them at least
ten (10) hours before the work or refilling of any such excavation or tunnel commences. (1989 Code; amd. Ord. 95-02-712, 2-21-1995)
7-1A-8: EXEMPTIONS FROM PROVISIONS:
The provisions of this article relative to securing permits shall not apply to officers or employees of the Village engaged in doing work for the Village, nor to
persons or corporations doing work for the Village under contract, nor to persons or corporations which are operating under a franchise or grant from the
Village if such franchise provides for the making of excavations and tunnels without securing a permit therefor. (1989 Code)
ARTICLE B. DRIVEWAYS
7-1B-1: PERMITS REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to construct a new driveway or to resurface, extend or enlarge an existing driveway without having first secured a Village permit
therefor, issued by the Village Director of Building and Zoning.
If the proposed driveway originates at a State highway or a County highway, a permit when applicable shall also be obtained from the State of Illinois,
Division of Highways, or the County Highway Commissioner. (1989 Code; amd. Ord. 95-02-712, 2-21-95)
7-1B-2: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT; FEE:
Application for such a Village permit, if the driveway is to be constructed in connection with construction of a new building or the extension of an existing
building, shall be accompanied by a plat or sketch showing the length and width of the driveway and its location with respect to adjacent street and
buildings. If a driveway or its resurfacing, extension or enlarging provides for work to be done in the Village street beyond the lot line, the permit shall be
made subject to the approval of the Director of Public Works.
The fee for all driveway permits shall be the sum provided for permits as set forth in this Municipal Code, said fee paid to the Village Collector before
permit is granted. (1989 Code)
7-1B-3: CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS AND SPECIFICATIONS:
A. Grade of Driveway:
1. No driveway shall be so constructed or graded as to leave a step, projection or sharp depression between the street pavement and the lot line of the
property; provided, however, that where an existing street pavement includes a combination concrete curb and gutter, the curb section may remain in
place if approved by the Director of Public Works in order to preserve the gutter section of the storm water raceway.
2. If a driveway crosses an existing or proposed sidewalk, the elevation of the surface of the driveway at the sidewalk shall be coincident with the
sidewalk.
3. Where permissible by the grade of the lot, all driveways shall slope toward the street at a grade of not more than four percent (4%).
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 187/524
4. The surface of the driveway shall have a uniform slope from the sidewalk or lot line to the intersection with the curb or street surface.
B. Culverts: When a driveway is constructed from a street having no curbs or gutters, but where surface drainage is cared for by a depressed swale or
ditch, a corrugated iron pipe culvert shall be installed below the surface of the driveway and at an elevation and slope to provide proper raceway for
surface water without obstructing the flow along the swale or ditch. Said culvert shall be not less than twenty feet (20') long and not less than ten inches
(10") in diameter, but such culvert shall be large enough to permit the drainage of all storm water so as to protect the street and other public property
from flooding or from stagnant water; provided, however, no culvert need be installed if in the opinion of the Director of Public Works no culvert will be
required where storm water can drain adequately without flooding, and without the creation of stagnant pools when no culvert is installed.
Culverts shall be installed before construction of or excavation for a building being served by the driveway in question is started.
C. Design and Materials of Construction:
1. That part of the driveway between pavement and lot line for driveways originating from State highways or County highways shall be designed by the
State Division of Highways or County Highway Commissioner, if required when State or County permit has been obtained by the applicant. Such
driveways shall be constructed and curbs, gutters, manholes and appurtenances provided as required by the design submitted by the State Division
of Highways or County Highway Commissioner.
2. The materials to be used and the construction detail of driveways beyond lot line (except the section of those originating at State or County highways
between the State or County highway pavement and the lot line as aforesaid), including the size and shape of culverts and the reconstruction of
sidewalks if necessary, shall be determined by the Director of Public Works before permit is granted or work started.
3. Driveways for business or industrial establishments shall be provided with substantial concrete curbs on each side of the driveway from the
intersection of the street pavement to the lot line or sidewalk in such manner as to provide adequate drainage to street gutter or swale and so as not
to obstruct pedestrian traffic on the sidewalk. (1989 Code)
7-1B-4: TEMPORARY DRIVEWAYS:
No temporary driveway will be permitted unless authorized by the Board of Trustees who shall designate type of construction and length of time that the
driveway will be permitted and how all such temporary work shall be removed. (1989 Code)
7-1B-5: INSPECTIONS:
The Director of Public Works will make inspections of driveways and culverts beyond the lot line to provide for proper construction and adequate drainage
of storm water and the Director of Building and Zoning will make the inspections within the lot lines. (1989 Code; amd. Ord. 95-02-712, 2-21-95)
Chapter 2
PARADES AND OPEN-AIR MEETINGS
7-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
OPEN-AIR MEETING: Any assemblage, demonstration or any congregation of citizens held outdoors and upon any public property for the purpose of
hearing speakers or discussing some matter of common interest where the number of participants expected may reasonably be assumed to exceed fifty
(50).
PARADE: Any parade, march, ceremony, show, exhibition, pageant or procession of any kind, or any similar display, in or upon any street, park or other
public place in the Village. (1989 Code)
7-2-2: PERMITS REQUIRED:
No person shall participate in a parade or open-air meeting held on any public way or on any public property unless a written permit therefor shall first be
obtained from the Village Clerk. (1989 Code)
7-2-3: APPLICATION FOR PERMITS:
An application to conduct a parade or open-air meeting shall be made in writing to the Village Clerk at least seventy two (72) hours prior to the event, by a
representative of the group seeking the permit, and shall set forth the following information: (1989 Code; amd. Ord. 2018-12-279, 12-3-2018)
A. The name, address and telephone number of the person, firm, organization or corporation seeking to conduct such a parade or open-air meeting.
B. If the parade or open-air meeting is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the
headquarters of the organization.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 188/524
C. The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the parade chairman or chairman of the open-air meeting.
D. The date when the parade or open-air meeting is to be conducted.
E. The amount of any admission or attendance charge expected to be required from those participating or attending.
F. The route to be traveled, the starting point, the termination point, the location of speakers' platforms and the total time and distance expected.
G. The approximate number of persons who will and, animals and vehicles which will constitute such parade or open-air meeting and the type of animals,
and description of the vehicles.
H. The hours when such parade or open-air meeting will start and terminate.
I. A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed.
J. The location by streets of any assembly areas for such parade or open-air meeting.
K. The time at which units of the parade will begin to assemble at any such assembly areas. (1989 Code)
7-2-4: PERMIT FEES:
(Rep. by Ord. 2018-12-279, 12-3-2018)
7-2-5: ACTION ON PERMITS:
Following receipt of an application or reapplication, the Village Clerk shall refer it to the Chief of Police. The Chief of Police shall either, within twenty four
(24) hours, recommend issuance of a permit for the holding of a parade or open-air meeting or recommend rejection of the application. Permits may be
rejected on the basis of incomplete application or application not in compliance with this chapter. The reasons for rejection shall be made known to
applicant, in writing, at the time of rejection. The applicant shall be allowed to correct or complete said improper application and resubmit it to the Village
Clerk for referral to the Chief of Police; the original seventy two (72) hour required advance notification time being still valid if a corrected application is
resubmitted within twenty four (24) hours will be imposed prior to which the event may not be held. Such forty eight (48) hour period shall commence upon
receipt of the corrected application. (1989 Code)
7-2-6: MULTIPLE PERMITS:
If the Village Clerk shall receive more than one application for a parade or open-air meeting at the same time and the same place, or on the same day, the
applications filed first in time shall take precedence. An application shall be considered to be "at the same time" if the event is scheduled to commence
within two (2) hours before or after the holding of another event at the same place. An application shall be considered to be "at the same place" if the
open-air meeting is to be conducted within one-half (1/2) mile of another open-air meeting. If the Village Clerk receives an application for more than one
parade or open-air meeting in a single day, the Clerk may set a time for the duration of each parade or open-air meeting, which time shall not, without the
consent of the group seeking the permit, be less than three (3) hours.
The Village Clerk shall issue permits for more than a single parade during one day in accordance with the requirements of this section and section 7-2-5 of
this chapter; provided, however, that he may not issue multiple permits beyond the point at which the issuance of an additional permit would require the
continuing diversion of so great a number of police officers or other Village personnel so as to prevent normal police protection or other service to the
Village. A single permit may cover more than one group or person if their identities are properly reported on the application. (1989 Code)
7-2-7: HOURS:
All parades shall be held during daylight hours at times other than peak traffic periods (7:30 A.M. to 9:00 A.M. and 4:30 P.M. to 6:00 P.M., Monday through
Saturday), and not before twelve o'clock (12:00) noon on Sundays. All open-air meetings shall conclude by twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight and shall not
be held before twelve o'clock (12:00) noon on Sunday. (1989 Code)
7-2-8: TRAFFIC LIMITS:
Parades and open air meetings shall be limited to such numbers as will not obstruct traffic either vehicular or pedestrian, in an unreasonable manner. The
Chief of Police may request reasonable regulations as to spacing of paraders, length of parade, duration of time so police manpower will not be diverted
for too long a period of time from its other duties, giving consideration to the day of the week, the expected amount of vehicle and pedestrian traffic,
weather conditions and the holiday conditions, if any. The time requested may be reset or diminished if necessary to avoid relocating or re-routing overly
large amounts of vehicles or pedestrian traffic covered by peak periods of traffic. The Village Clerk may then issue a permit with those conditions. (1989
Code)
7-2-9: DISTRIBUTING LITERATURE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 189/524
Literature may be passed from person to person, but may not be put upon or affixed to any property. (1989 Code)
Chapter 3
PUBLIC PARKS
7-3-1: GENERAL RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The following rules and regulations shall apply to all persons using any village park:
A. Hours Of Operation: Unless otherwise specifically authorized by permit issued by the village for Breezewald or Paulus Parks, following proper
application for a private event and approval therefor by the village (provided however that no permit shall authorize park use beyond 12:00 midnight on
any day), village parks shall be open daily to the public as provided by the village from time to time, generally during the hours between six o'clock
(6:00) A.M. and dusk. It shall be unlawful for any person, other than village employees conducting village business, to occupy or be present in any
village park at any time when such park is not open to the public. (Ord. 2013-09-909, 9-3-2013)
B. Cleanliness: It shall be unlawful for any person to litter or otherwise deposit trash or debris of any kind in any village park. Every person shall leave the
premises used by that person in a neat and clean condition, free from all litter, trash, and debris.
C. Use Of Vehicles: It shall be unlawful for any person other than an authorized village employee to operate any automobile or other motor driven vehicle
in any area of any park other than designated roadways, driveways, and parking lots. (Ord. 99-12-1004, 12-6-1999)
D. Pets And Other Animals: All pets and other animals are prohibited in all village parks except only guide dogs for visually disabled persons or animals
specifically authorized by the village to perform activities in a park that are beneficial to the public health, benefit, and welfare. (Ord. 2003-03-222, 3-3-
2003)
E. Restricted Areas: It shall be unlawful for any person to enter into any part of any village park or building where entry is forbidden as indicated by sign or
notice.
F. Closings: The village may close any village park at any time for any reason. It shall be unlawful for any person, other than village employees conducting
village business, to occupy or be present in any village park at any time when such park has been closed by the village.
G. Prohibited Activities: The following activities are prohibited in all village parks unless specifically authorized by the village in a specifically designated
area: skating, sledding, tobogganing, skiing, sliding, golf, and skateboarding.
H. Swimming: It shall be unlawful for any person to swim except only in swimming areas designated by the village, and only at the times and in the manner
set forth in the rules and regulations of the village.
I. Vendors And Peddlers: All vendors and peddlers are prohibited in all village parks at all times except only with the specific prior written approval of an
authorized village officer.
J. Signs: It shall be unlawful for any person to place or maintain any signs in any village park at any time.
K. Weapons: It shall be unlawful for any person to bring or possess any gun, firearm, knife, explosive device, or any other weapons of any kind in any
village park at any time. It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, cast, or shoot any stone, arrows, or other projectile or missile in any village park at
any time. (Ord. 99-12-1004, 12-6-1999)
7-3-2: SPECIFIED PROHIBITED ACTS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to perform or permit to be performed any of the following acts in any village park at any time:
A. To operate any aircraft of any type and kind in any village park at any time.
B. To wilfully mark, deface, disfigure, injure, tamper with, displace, or remove any building, bridge, table, bench, fireplace, railing, sign, notice, placard, or
other village property.
C. To throw, discharge, or otherwise place or cause to be placed in the water of any fountain, pond, lake, stream, bay or other body of water in or adjacent
to any park, any substance, matter, or thing, liquid or solid, that will or may result in the pollution of said water.
D. To bring in or to dump, deposit, or leave any rubbish, waste, garbage, trash, or refuse of any kind, except only in designated waste containers.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 190/524
E. To disturb the peace or use any profane, obscene, or blasphemous language.
F. To endanger, by any conduct or act, the safety of any person.
G. To commit any assault or battery or to engage in fighting.
H. To violate any village rule or regulation regarding the use of the village park.
I. To prevent or interfere with the use of park facilities by any person.
J. To swim, bathe, or wade in any water except as specifically authorized by the village.
K. To dress or undress, whether at the beach or in a vehicle, toilet, or any other place except only in a bathing house or structure provided by the village for
changing clothes.
L. To dig into, damage, or remove any soil, landscaping, or any other property of the village.
M. To camp and to erect or use any tent, shelter, motor home, trailer, or other such equipment or device.
N. To light or maintain any fire except only as specifically authorized by the village in a place specifically designated for that purpose by the village.
O. To use or operate a metal detector, or any other similar sensing device, for the purpose of locating or removing objects from below the grass or the
surface of the soil or sand. (Ord. 99-12-1004, 12-6-1999)
7-3-3: LAUNCHING OF WATERCRAFT:
A. Motorized Watercraft Prohibited: No motorized watercraft may be launched into the lake of Lake Zurich from any village park.
B. Nonmotorized Watercraft: Nonmotorized watercraft may be launched into the lake of Lake Zurich only from Paulus Park, but only after a permit
authorizing such launch has been issued by the village. Such a launching permit shall be issued by the park and recreation department after proper
application therefor and compliance with all regulations applicable to operation of watercraft within the village. (Ord. 99-12-1004, 12-6-1999)
7-3-4: GROUP ACTIVITIES:
No organized group shall use any village park facility for an organized purpose, including, but not limited to, a picnic, a party, or a theatrical performance,
unless such group shall first have obtained a permit therefor from the village and paid the fee established therefor from time to time by the board of
trustees.
A. Application for such permit shall be made to the village park and recreation director at least thirty (30) days prior to any such organized group use,
providing such information as may be requested by the village.
B. The issuance of any permit hereunder to allow the use of a village park facility shall remain subject to the termination of such permit, up to and including
the day of use, if in the sole discretion of the chief of police of the village, or his or her designee, it is in the best interests of the village to further
regulate, to designate or limit the area being used, or to terminate the permit and revoke the permission of the organized group to use the village park
facility for their specified purpose.
C. The hours of use for such permit shall be as provided (or approved) hereinabove at section 7-3-1 of this chapter.
D. An additional fee may apply to a request for a permit by an organized group to use a village park facility if such request exceeds a certain number of
participants or involves extended hours of use.
E. The possession or service of any alcoholic beverages as part of any organized group activity authorized by permit in Breezewald or Paulus Park is
strictly prohibited unless such group first qualifies for and has been issued a liquor license by the local liquor commissioner, after proper application for
and approval of such a request under the liquor control requirements set forth in this code.
F. No consumption or possession of alcohol is allowed in the water, on the beach or in the children's play or playlot areas. (Ord. 2013-09-909, 9-3-2013)
7-3-5: PAULUS PARK AND BREEZEWALD PARK BEACHES:
A. Paulus Park Beach Entry Requirement: No person shall use the beach at Paulus Park without first having obtained a season pass or having paid the
daily entry fee in accordance with this section. (Ord. 2007-01-475, 1-15-2007)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 191/524
B. Breezewald Park Beach: A resident of the village must provide proof of that residency to use the beach at Breezewald Park without a pass. No entrance
pass or fee is required for residents to use the beach at Breezewald Park. No person who lives outside the corporate limits of the village may use the
beach at Breezewald Park without first having obtained a nonresident beach season pass in accordance with this section. Breezewald Park does not
accept a daily entry fee for use of the beach at Breezewald Park. (Ord. 2009-03-619, 3-16-2009)
C. Beach Season Passes For Residents: Residents may purchase either a beach season pass for a family or individual beach season passes by
completing a form provided by the village and paying the required fee. The form provided by the village shall require identification of all family members
living at the resident address. Individual identification passes will be issued to each such family member. Only one beach season pass form may be
completed for each individual or family. (Ord. 2007-01-475, 1-15-2007)
D. Resident Daily Guests: A resident who has purchased a beach season pass for the beach at Paulus Park may bring guests to the beach at Paulus Park
by purchasing guest passes or by paying the daily fee therefor. Resident daily guest passes are not available for access to the beach at Breezewald
Park; a nonresident beach season pass is required for nonresident access to the beach at Breezewald Park. (Ord. 2009-03-619, 3-16-2009)
E. Entry Fees For Residents: The fees applicable to residents for: 1) beach season passes, 2) guest passes, and 3) daily admissions shall be as
established from time to time by the board of trustees.
F. Beach Season Passes For Nonresidents: Persons who live outside the corporate limits of the village may secure nonresident beach season passes by
registering on a form provided by the village and paying the required fee. Individual identification passes will be issued to each person living at the
registered nonresident address. Only one nonresident beach season pass form may be completed for each nonresident individual or family.
G. Nonresident Daily Guests: All nonresidents who have purchased a nonresident beach season pass may bring guests to the beach by paying the daily
fee therefor. Guest passes shall not be issued to nonresidents.
H. Entry Fees For Nonresidents: The fees applicable to nonresidents for: 1) beach season passes and 2) daily admissions shall be as established from
time to time by the board of trustees. (Ord. 2007-01-475, 1-15-2007)
7-3-6: SPECIAL REGULATIONS FOR LION'S PARK PARKING LOT:
The following regulations apply to the municipal parking lot south of U.S. Route 22 adjacent to Lion's Park (the "lot"):
A. Parking Hours: No vehicle shall be parked in the lot at any time between two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. on any day.
B. Parking Restricted: No vehicle shall be parked in the lot other than in designated parking areas. No vehicle shall block the flow of traffic or be parked in
any drive aisle, driveway, entranceway or exit.
C. Speed Limit: The maximum speed in the lot shall be five (5) miles per hour.
D. One-Way Traffic: The flow of traffic through the lot shall be one way from U.S. Route 22 to the public alley adjacent to 20 South Old Rand Road.
E. Weight Limit: No vehicle with a gross weight of more than eight thousand (8,000) pounds shall use the lot.
F. Towing For Violation: Any vehicle violating any provision of this section shall be towed away at the vehicle owner's expense by authority of the Chief of
Police or his or her designee. (Ord. 99-12-1004, 12-6-1999)
G. Fines: Any person violating any provision of this section shall be fined pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of this Code for each offense.
(Ord. 99-12-1004, 12-6-1999; amd. Ord. 2018-12-279, 12-3-2018)
7-3-7: VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES:
A. Penalty: Any person who violates any provision in section 7-3-1 or 7-3-2 of this chapter shall be fined pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of
this Code for each offense.
B. Payments To Avoid Prosecution: Any person who receives a citation for a violation of any provision in section 7-3-1 or 7-3-2 of this chapter may avoid
prosecution by paying a fine pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of this Code. (Ord. 2010-07-723, 7-6-2010; amd. Ord. 2018-12-279, 12-3-
2018)
Chapter 4
LAKE OF LAKE ZURICH AND BEACHES
7-4-1: TITLE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 192/524
This chapter shall be known as, and may be cited as, the SAFE USE OF THE LAKE AND BEACHES. (Ord. 2010-01-689, 1-18-2010)
7-4-2: PURPOSE:
This chapter establishes specific regulations affecting the operation of watercraft on the lake of Lake Zurich, the equipment that watercraft must maintain,
and the recreational and sporting activities on and in the lake and the beaches, including ice fishing, skiing, swimming, and similar activities. (Ord. 2010-
01-689, 1-18-2010)
7-4-3: DEFINITIONS:
Terms used in this chapter, unless the context clearly requires a different meaning, mean as follows:
AIRBOAT: Any vessel (but not including airplane or hydroplane) propelled by machinery applying force against the air rather than the water as a means of
propulsion.
BEACH FLOAT DEVICES: Includes tire tubes, inflatable floats, floating chairs, inflatable boats, etc.
DEPARTMENT: The Department of Conservation of the State of Illinois.
DESIGNATED SWIMMING AREA: The area within fifty feet (50') of a swimming buoy.
OPERATE: To navigate or otherwise use a vessel.
OWNER: A person, other than lienholder, having title to a vessel or structure.
SAILBOAT: Any watercraft propelled by sail or canvas. For the purpose of this chapter, any watercraft propelled by both sail or canvas or machinery of any
sort shall be deemed a vessel when being so propelled.
STRUCTURE: Any shelter which is placed on or used on such water or ice of any waterway in the Village shall be a portable structure vessel for fishing
purposes only and may be constructed of a framework of metal or wood covered with canvas, paper, plastic material or any similar fabric.
SWIMMING BUOY: A buoy placed in a public waterway by the Village for the purpose of marking a designated swimming area.
VESSEL OR WATERCRAFT: Every description of watercraft, other than a seaplane on the water, used or capable of being used as a means of
transportation on water. (1989 Code; amd. Ord. 90-06-389, 6-18-1990; Ord. 91-09-478, 9-3-1991; Ord. 2008-05-564, 5-19-2008)
7-4-4: MARINE UNIT OFFICERS:
The Chief of Police, with the consent of the Village Manager, may appoint marine unit officers to enforce the provisions of this chapter. The compensation
of the marine unit officers shall be set by the Board of Trustees. The duties of the marine unit officers shall be to enforce the provisions of this chapter and
the applicable laws and regulations of the State. The marine unit officers shall have the authority to board and inspect any watercraft at any time it is being
used on any waterway in the Village to determine whether such watercraft complies with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 2018-02-247, 2-5-2018)
7-4-5: VESSELS AND WATERCRAFT:
7-4-5-1: LAKE WATERCRAFT MAINTENANCE AND USE PERMIT:
A. Lake Watercraft Maintenance And Use Permit Required: No watercraft may be moored or operated on the lake of Lake Zurich without first obtaining
and displaying a lake watercraft maintenance and use permit from the Lake Property Owners' Association of Lake Zurich (the "LPOA") and paying the
fee required by section 7-4-5-2 of this section 7-4-5.
B. Applications: Each person seeking a lake watercraft maintenance and use permit must apply for that permit on a form approved by the Village and
provided by the LPOA. That application form will be available from the LPOA. The completed form must be submitted to the LPOA by mail or at the
location stated on the application form. The Village may post the location on the Village's website. Each person submitting an application for a lake
watercraft maintenance and use permit must provide the following information with the application:
1. The name, address, telephone number, and other pertinent contact information related to the owner of the watercraft for which the permit is sought.
2. The make, model, and Illinois Department of Natural Resources registration number for the watercraft for which the permit is sought.
3. For motorized watercraft, three (3) copies of proof of liability insurance establishing the existence of coverage for not less than the full length of the
operating season for which the permit is sought.
4. Documentation regarding the right of legal access to the lake of Lake Zurich.
C. Display Of Permit: No watercraft may be moored or operated on the lake of Lake Zurich at any time unless a current, valid lake watercraft maintenance
and use permit is affixed to that watercraft at the lower starboard stern.
D. Liability Insurance: The holder of a lake watercraft maintenance and use permit for a motorized watercraft must notify the LPOA if the liability insurance
coverage for the permitted motorized watercraft lapses or otherwise is no longer in force or effect during the term of the permit. It is unlawful to operate
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 193/524
a motorized watercraft on the lake of Lake Zurich at any time without liability insurance.
E. Lake Access For Multiple Mooring Sites: For any mooring site on the lake of Lake Zurich that includes moorings for more than two (2) watercraft owned
by unrelated parties (a "multiple mooring site"), each application for a lake watercraft maintenance and use permit for a watercraft moored at that
multiple mooring site must include: 1) the name and contact information of the deeded lake rights owner or authorized representative of that multiple
mooring site and 2) a statement that the owner or authorized representative has approved the submission of the application. No application will be
processed that does not include that information.
F. Exception For Village Parks And Official Business: The provisions of this section do not apply to Village operated watercraft programs at Village owned
parks, official lake maintenance watercraft, or other government agency watercraft. (Ord. 2017-7-208, 7-17-2017)
G. Violation: A violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of this Code. (Ord. 2017-7-208, 7-17-
2017; amd. Ord. 2018-12-279, 12-3-2018)
7-4-5-2: LAKE WATERCRAFT MAINTENANCE AND USE PERMIT FEE; FINANCIAL REVIEWS; RESERVE FUND:
A. Annual Budget: The Lake Property Owners' Association of Lake Zurich (the "LPOA") must submit to the Village, on or before March 15 each year, its
detailed budget for maintenance and protection of the lake of Lake Zurich during the upcoming boating season, including matters such as weed control;
fish stocking; police services; insurance costs; supplies, postage, and third party administrative costs related to the Lake Watercraft Maintenance and
Use Permit Program; and a reserve fund for extraordinary maintenance.
B. Uniform Fee: For each boating season the LPOA will establish a fee structure that is reasonably related to the costs of the budgeted maintenance and
protection activities for that season.
