The Village Engineer may allow or may require that all or part of the proposed storm sewerage system be laid with open joints. The method of preventing
material from entering any open-joint pipe at the joints shall be subject to the approval of the Village Engineer.
2. Manholes and Catch Basins (See Exhibit Nos. 3 and 73):
a. Manholes and catch basins shall have precast reinforced concrete barrel sections conforming to ADSTM C478 with preformed bituminous joints
and with integral precast-in-place bottoms. Precast slab bottoms may be used for manholes to be built in existing storm sewerage system lines.
b. Manholes shall have offset access holes. Catch basins shall have concentric access holes.
c. Manholes and catch basins for storm sewerage system pipes thirty six inches (36") or less in diameter shall be designed in accordance with
Exhibit Nos. 3 and 74. For pipes larger than thirty six inches (36") in diameter, the manholes and catch basins shall have large enough bottom
sections to fit the pipes or, for pipes over forty eight inch (48") diameter riser seated on a slab if a manhole bottom section is used or on a tee if no
bottom section is used. The required structure size shall be increased if warranted by the number and size of pipes entering the structure.
d. No more than two (2) precast concrete adjusting rings shall be allowed for a maximum height adjustment of eight inches (8").
e. Each manhole shall have a poured Class X concrete bench carefully shaped to drain to the outlet pipe.
3. Inlets (See Exhibit No. 95):
a. Inlets shall be constructed of precast reinforced concrete conforming to ASTM C478 with "O"-ring or preformed bituminous joints and with precastin-
place bottom. Inlets shall have a wall thickness of no less than four inches (4").
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 422/524
b. Inlets shall be twenty four inches (24") in diameter and between two feet (2') and four feet (4') deep.
c. No more than two (2) precast concrete adjusting rings shall be allowed for a maximum height adjustment of eight inches (8").
d. No more than one major pipe connection is allowed per inlet.
e. A Class X concrete bench shall be poured in the bottom of each inlet and shaped to drain to the outlet pipe. The fall across the inlet shall be no
less than four inches (4").
4. Castings:
a. All grates in paved areas shall be bicycle-safe.
b. Frames and lids equivalent to Neenah Foundry Company R-1712 shall be used where structures fall in pavement and require solid lids. Castings
for structures falling in landscaped areas and requiring solid lids shall be equivalent to Neenah Foundry Company R-1772-A frames and lids. Lids
shall be embossed with "Storm Sewer".
c. Casting for structures falling in pavement and requiring grated lids shall be equivalent to Neenah Foundry Company R-2504-C frames and grates.
d. Castings for structures falling in curb shall be equivalent to Neenah Foundry Company R-3281-C (B-6.12) or R-3277 (B6.24) frames, grates and
boxes.
e. Castings for structures falling in driveway depressed curb shall be equivalent to Neenah Foundry Company R-3505-A frames and grates. The
curb, gutter and adjacent driveway apron (if necessary) shall be carefully shaped to drain to the grate flow line.
f. Castings shall not be allowed in sidewalk handicap ramps.
g. Inlets falling in landscaped areas where clogging will not be a problem shall have grates equivalent to Neenah Foundry Company R-4340-B. Catch
basins falling in landscaped areas where clogging will not be a problem shall have frames and grates equivalent to Neenah Foundry Company R-
2502-A. In areas where clogging may be a problem, Neenah Foundry Company R-2561 equivalent frames and grates shall be required for both
inlets and catch basins. The choice of casting shall be subject to the approval of the Village Engineer.
h. Manhole steps shall be equivalent to Neenah Foundry Company R-1981-S.
5. Standard pipe bedding shall be crushed stone or crushed gravel conforming to IDOT CA-6 100% Crushed.
6. Structures falling in pavement of any kind shall include provision for the prevention of particles from entering the structure below the casting. A
chimney seal or geotextile fabric wrapping may be required by the Village Engineer. Low point structures in pavement shall include at least four (4)
one inch (1") diameter weep holes just below sub-base level protected by two (2) layers of geotextile filter fabric over a stiff, noncorrodible screen.
Q. Construction:
1. Bedding shall be placed as shown in Exhibit No. 16. The bedding surface shall be adjusted to support the bottom of the pipe at all points.
2. If a significant amount of water enters the trench during pipe laying, it shall be removed before operations may continue.
3. If soft, spongy or other unsuitable soils are encountered at the bottom of the trench, all such material shall be removed and replaced with well
compacted crushed limestone bedding material. If rock is encountered, it shall be removed to at least six inches (6") below the bottom of the pipe to
allow the proper thickness of bedding to be installed.
4. Adequate provision shall be made for the safety, storage and protection of all pipe prior to actual installation in the trench. Proper equipment shall be
used for the safe handling, conveying and laying of the pipe. All pipe shall be careful lowered into the trench, piece by piece by means of suitable
tools or equipment so as to prevent damage to sewerage system materials, protective coatings or linings.
5. All portions of the joining materials, the socket and the spigot of the joining pipes shall be wiped or brushed clean of all foreign materials at the time
the joints are assembled. Assembly shall be in accordance with the manufacturer's installation instructions and as instructed in writing by the Village
Engineer. If required by the Village Engineer, the open end of the installed pipe shall be sealed with a plug until the next pipe is added.
6. Cutting of pipe for any purpose shall be done in a neat, workmanlike manner without damage to any lining. Pipe cutting shall result in a smooth end
at the proper angle to the axis of the pipe. A bevel shall be neatly filed or ground around the outside circumference of any ductile cast iron pipe to
minimize damage to the gasket material at that joint. All debris from the cutting operation shall be removed from the inside of the pipe and from the
joint area. Flame cutting of pipe shall not be allowed.
Structures shall not be broken to provide a hole for pipe but shall be neatly saw cut with the proper equipment.
7. The trench shall be carefully backfilled as shown in section 10-8-1, "Exhibit No. 1", of this title except as follows:
Trenches in or within two feet (2') of a roadway, parking area, curb, sidewalk or any other paved area shall be backfilled with trench backfill in
accordance with the pertinent sections of the "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction". See section 10-8-1, "Exhibit No. 2", of
this title.
8. The trench shall be backfilled and compacted in accordance with section 502.11 of the "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction",
except the backfill material shall be compacted everywhere, not just near and under pavements or sidewalks.
If jetting is used as a compaction method, the jetting tube shall not be allowed within two feet (2') of the pipe. The jetting tube shall be inserted along
the trench at six foot (6') intervals.
R. Inspection And Testing:
1. All storm sewers and appurtenances shall be thoroughly cleaned prior to final inspection and prior to testing.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 423/524
2. The developer or owner shall have an employee in charge on site at all times that construction of the storm sewerage system is under way. The
developer or owner shall be fully responsible for the quality of the materials and methods of the construction work and shall bear full responsibility for
ensuring that the storm sewerage system shall meet the stated requirements of the village in every way.
3. Upon completion of construction and prior to the beginning of the maintenance guarantee period and again approximately one year after the
commencement of the warranty period, a videotaped television inspection shall be performed on the sections or portions of the sewer as directed by
the village engineer. Videotapes and written reports for all television inspections shall be provided to the village prior to the initial acceptance
provided for in this title. The form of the report and the format of the videotape shall be approved by the village engineer. All fees and costs involved
in this television inspection shall be borne by the developer or owner.
4. The village engineer shall inspect the storm sewerage system under construction during construction as he deems necessary. The village engineer
shall not be responsible to direct the work of the contractor but shall be responsible only to assess the acceptability of the improvement as
constructed. In no case shall the village engineer be responsible for day to day quality control at the site of construction.
5. The developer or owner shall ensure that work done over a shallow storm sewer is done carefully. Pavement undercutting, especially, shall be done
so as not to damage a shallow storm sewer. The developer or owner shall require that any storm sewer pipes damaged as a result of construction
activity shall be immediately replaced by the contractor responsible for the damage. The village engineer shall not approve any storm sewerage
system containing damaged components regardless of who or what damaged them. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-1989)
S. Subbase Relief Underdrains: A six inch (6") diameter subbase relief underdrain shall be installed one foot (1') from the back of curb and shall be
connected into the lower inlet fifty feet (50') on each side away from the inlet. See section 10-8-1, "Exhibit No. 11", of this title. (Ord. 93-10-615, 10-4-
1993)
10-6-5: STORMWATER MANAGEMENT REGULATIONS:
The Lake County watershed development ordinance, as most recently amended by the county of Lake on October 13, 2015, is hereby adopted by
reference and is in full force and effect within the village of Lake Zurich and is found in its own compilation. (Ord. 2015-12-095, 12-7-2015)
10-6-6: SANITARY SEWERAGE SYSTEM:
A. Intent: It is the intent of this standard to provide for the safe and efficient disposal of sanitary sewage and that the public health be protected from the
negative aspects of sanitary sewage by the proper separation of sanitary sewage from the environment until such time that it is rendered harmless. All
developments shall include a sanitary sewerage system meeting the approval of the Village Engineer. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-89)
Sanitary sewer systems shall be constructed in accordance with the "Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois" unless
otherwise modified in this Section. Materials shall be as specified in Exhibit 147. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-89; amd. Ord. 93-10-615, 10-4-93)
B. Service Areas: All sanitary sewers shall be designed to accommodate an ultimate service area as identified by the Village Engineer. If extending the
ultimate service area beyond the limits of the proposed development results in additional construction costs within the development, the Village may
provide an agreement for the recapture by the developer or owner of the additional cost when future system extensions are made. Recapture
payments will be made to the developer or owner only after those benefiting from the extended service area have made payment to the Village.
C. System Extension: The location of proposed extensions to the existing sanitary sewerage system shall be approved by the Village Engineer.
D. Design Standards:
1. Design flows for residential developments, single and multiple, shall be based upon full development of the service area with the population served.
Design flow assumptions shall be subject to the approval of the Village Engineer.
2. The formula to be used for residential developments to determine the maximum daily per capita design flow is as follows:
Q(max)
=
Q(avg)
18 + V P
4 +
where:
Q = design flow, gpcpd
P = population served in thousands (1000's)
3. Design flows for nonresidential developments shall be based on full development of the service area with the daily average design flow calculated as
follows:
Q = (0.10) (AF)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 424/524
where:
Q = design flow, gpd
AF = floor area in square feet
or
Q = (1500) (AS)
where:
Q = design flow, gpd
AS = site area in acres
Add to the calculated figure, the estimated process water requirements to arrive at a final design flow.
Design flow shall include total allowable infiltration at any point based on one hundred (100) gallons per inch diameter per miles per day at any time for any
section of the sanitary sewerage system.
For nonresidential developments where the details of the development are not established, domestic design flows shall be approved by the Village
Engineer. The developer or owner shall, however, be ultimately responsible for the provision of enough sanitary sewerage system capacity to serve any
and all future requirements within the development.
4. The required capacity of sanitary sewers shall be computed using Manning's formula:
1.486
Q = (A)-------(R) (S)
n
where:
Q =Flow capacity in cubic feet per second
A =Area of flow cross section in square feet
R =Hydraulic radius in feet (R = area of flow divided by the length of the wetted perimeter)
S =Slope of the hydraulic energy line, typically the same as the conduit slope, in feet per foot
n =Roughness coefficient
For circular conduit (pipe), the formula takes the form:
0.463
Q = (A)---------(D) (S)
n
where:
D =diameter of pipe in feet
5. The coefficient n shall be as follows:
Concrete pipe 0.013
Ductile iron pipe 0.013
PVC pipe 0.012
6. Design mean velocity (design flow rate divided by cross sectional area) flowing full shall not be more than six feet (6') per second nor be less than
two feet (2') per second. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-1989; amd. per letter dated 1-10-1990)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 425/524
E. Minimum Diameter: Sanitary sewerage system main line pipes shall not be less than eight inches (8") in diameter. Sanitary service connection pipes
shall not be less than six inches (6") in diameter. Sanitary service connection pipes shall be laid at a gradient of at least one percent (1%). Sanitary
service connection pipe shall not be permitted to connect to a manhole. (Ord. 2001-02-91, 2-20-2001)
F. Between Manholes: Sanitary sewerage system pipes shall be laid straight and at a uniform gradient between manholes unless otherwise approved by
the village engineer.
G. Different Diameters: Sanitary sewerage system pipes of different diameters shall joint only at manholes. Ideally, invert elevations shall be adjusted to
match the eighty one-hundredths (0.80) depth points of the differing diameter pipes.
H. Manholes:
1. Manholes shall be located at the end of all sewers; at all changes in pipe size, shape direction or gradient; and at all junctions with other sanitary
sewerage system lines. An inspection manhole shall be required within ten feet (10') of any commercial, industrial, or multi-family building. Manholes
shall be located so that the following maximum intervals are not exceeded:
Pipe Size
(Inches)
Maximum Interval
(Feet)
8 - 16 250
18 - 54 400
2. Whenever possible, pipe of uniform size, direction and gradient passing through a manhole shall be laid through the manhole and later cut out to the
horizontal diameter line or as appropriate for other pipes entering the manhole. In any case, a smooth, well formed invert shall be provided across
the manhole.
3. An outside drop manhole shall be provided for manholes with any pipe entering the manhole twenty four inches (24") or more above the invert of the
outlet pipe.
4. Special manholes or junction chambers shall be designed and constructed to the satisfaction of the village engineer where flows and other
conditions dictate.
I. Depth And Outfall: Sanitary sewers shall be constructed at a minimum depth of six feet (6') and shall provide an outfall for all sanitary sewage within the
ultimate service area, both existing and future.
J. Lift Stations:
1. Whenever possible, sanitary sewerage facilities shall be designed to avoid the necessity of lift stations.
2. Lift stations and force main designs shall be submitted for review and approval to the village engineer and the Illinois environmental protection
agency.
3. Lift stations shall be subject to the approval of the village engineer and the village public works department.
4. Where feasible, a dual connect to the power supply system shall be required. A receptacle and switching for the connection of a portable generator
shall be required.
5. Air- and vacuum-release valves shall be installed in vaults at appropriate places in the force main. Cleanouts shall be installed at convenient points
in the force main.
6. An emergency alarm system approved by the village engineer and village public works department must be installed.
K. Pipe Class: Sanitary sewerage system pipe class shall be determined by using ASTM rigid or flexible pipe design strength formulas as applicable.
L. Pipe In Inaccessible Areas: Main-line sanitary sewerage system pipe laid in relatively inaccessible areas outside the right of way shall be class 52
ductile iron pipe. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-1989; amd. per letter dated 1-10-1990)
M. Materials: All sanitary sewerage system elements shall conform to exhibit no. 13 in section 10-8-1 of this title and to the following specifications: (Ord.
2001-02-91, 2-20-2001)
1. Sanitary Sewerage System Pipes:

If the soil report for the development indicates the possibility of corrosive soils, a manufacturer-approved polyethylene wrap shall be specified for all
ductile cast-iron pipes. Installation shall be done in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations. If the soil can have a deleterious effect on
concrete pipe, concrete pipe shall not be used.
2. Manholes (See Exhibit No. 3 In Section 10-8-1 Of This Title):
a. Manholes shall be precast reinforced concrete barrel sections conforming to ASTM C478 with preformed bituminous or O-ring joints and with
integral precast-in-place bottoms. The precast-in-place bottom requirement may be waived for manholes to be built in existing sanitary sewer
system lines, where precast slab bottoms may be used.
b. Manholes shall have offset cones.
c. Manholes with pipes thirty six inches (36") or less in diameter shall be designed in accordance with exhibit no. 3 in section 10-8-1 of this title. For
pipes larger than thirty six inches (36") in diameter, the manhole shall have a large enough bottom section to fit the pipe. The required manhole
diameter shall be increased if warranted by the number and size of pipes entering the structure.
d. No more than two (2) precast concrete adjusting rings shall be allowed for a maximum height adjustment of eight inches (8").
e. All pipe connection openings shall be precast with resilient rubber watertight pipe-to-manhole sleeves or seals except for manholes installed in an
existing live sanitary sewerage line. Flexible watertight sleeves (chimney seals) shall be installed from the manhole cone to the manhole casting.
See exhibit no. 4 in section 10-8-1 of this title.
f. Manholes shall include a poured class X concrete bench carefully shaped to drain to the outlet pipe.
3. Castings:
a. Frames and watertight solid lids with machined horizontal-bearing surfaces equivalent to Neenah Foundry Company R1712 shall be used where
manholes fall in pavement. Castings for manholes falling in landscaped areas shall be equivalent to Neenah Foundry Company R-1772-A frames
and watertight solid lids with machined horizontal-bearing surfaces. The lids shall be embossed with "Sanitary Sewer".
b. Manhole steps shall be equivalent to Neenah Foundry Company R-1981-S.
4. Standard Pipe Bedding: Standard pipe bedding shall be crushed stone or crushed gravel conforming to IDOT A6-100% crushed.
5. Release Valves: Air- and vacuum-release valves shall be equivalent to Apco series 400 SAVV or as approved by the village engineer.
N. Construction:
1. No construction shall begin until copies of all the required permits from the pertinent public agencies are filed with the village engineer.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 427/524
2. No construction shall begin until at least forty eight (48) hours after the village engineer and public works has been notified of the intention to begin
construction.
3. The installation of the sanitary sewerage system and appurtenances shall conform to the requirements of this section and to the following:
a. For reinforced concrete pipe, section 603 of the "Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction".
b. For ductile iron pipe, AWWA C600.
4. The proposed outlet pipe to the existing sanitary sewerage system shall be plugged at the lowest new manhole with a masonry or mechanical
plumber's plug to prevent any flow from the new sanitary sewerage system from reaching the existing sanitary sewerage system. The plug shall not
be removed without the permission of the village engineer.
5. Bedding shall be placed as shown in Exhibit 1. The bedding surface shall be adjusted to support the bottom of the pipe at all points. Where deemed
necessary by the Village Engineer based on site and load conditions, concrete cradle or encasement shall be required.
6. If a significant amount of water enters the trench during pipe laying, it shall be removed before operations may continue.
7. If soft, spongy or other unsuitable soils are encountered at the bottom of the trench, all such material shall be removed and replaced with well
compacted crushed limestone bedding material. If rock is encountered, it shall be removed to at least six inches (6") below the bottom of the pipe to
allow the proper thickness of bedding to be installed.
8. Adequate provision shall be made for the safety, storage and protection of all pipe prior to actual installation in the trench. Care shall be taken to
prevent damage to any pipe castings, both inside and out. The inside of the pipe shall be kept clean throughout its storage period. Proper equipment
shall be used for the safe handling, conveying and laying of the pipe. All pipe shall be carefully lowered into the trench, piece by piece, by means of
suitable tools or equipment so as to prevent damage to sewerage system materials and protective coatings and linings.
9. All portions of the joining materials, the socket, and the spigot of the joining pipes shall be wiped clean of all foreign materials at the time the joints
are assembled. Assembly shall be in accordance with the manufacturer's installation instructions and as instructed in writing by the Village Engineer.
If required by the Village Engineer, the open end of the installed pipe shall be sealed with a watertight plug until the next pipe is added.
10. Cutting of pipe for any purpose shall be done in a neat, workmanlike manner without damage to any lining. Pipe cutting shall result in a smooth end
at a right angle to the axis of the pipe. A bevel shall be neatly filed or ground around the outside circumference of any ductile iron pipe so as to
minimize damage to the gasket material at that joint. All debris from the cutting operation shall be removed from the inside of the pipe and from the
joint area. Flame cutting of pipe shall not be allowed.
Structures shall not be broken to provide holes for pipe but shall be neatly saw-cut using the proper equipment.
11. All joints in force main requiring the use of a fitting shall be blocked as shown in the details for water main thrust blocking where undisturbed earth
is available to spread the reaction forces. Where undisturbed earth is not available, the plans shall include a detail of a tie-rod system to absorb
reaction forces and to transmit them to undisturbed earth or to concrete anchors. The tie-rod system shall be subjected to the approval of the Village
Engineer.
Blocking of fittings shall be done so that the blocking does not interfere with access to the adjacent joints.
12. The trench shall be carefully backfilled as shown in Exhibit No.1 except as follows:
Trenches in or within two feet (2') of a roadway, parking area, curb, sidewalk or any other paved area shall be backfilled with trench backfill in
accordance with the pertinent sections of the "Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction". See Exhibit No. 2.
13. The installation of sanitary service connections shall conform to this Section and to Exhibit No. 14.
14. The trench shall be backfilled and compacted in accordance with section 502.11 of the "Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction",
except the backfill material shall be compacted everywhere, not just near and under pavements or sidewalks.
If jetting is used as a compaction method, the jetting tube shall not be allowed within two feet (2') of the pipe. The jetting tube shall be inserted along
the trench at six foot (6') intervals.
15. The developer or owner shall deliver to the Village Engineer and Public Works a record of all sanitary service connections, each wye located by a
measurement to the nearest downstream manhole. The end of each sanitary service connection stub shall be marked with a four inch by four inch
(4" X 4") timber extending vertically from two feet (2') above the end of the stub to three feet (3') above the finished grade. The timber marker
locations shall be recorded with measurements to nearby lot corners and to the back of curb or other permanent structure. Final Village acceptance
of the sanitary sewerage system shall not be given until this report is received and approved by the Village Engineer.
O. Inspection and Testing: All sanitary sewers and appurtenances shall be thoroughly cleaned prior to final inspection and prior to testing.
1. Inspection:
a. The developer or owner shall have an employee in charge on-site at all times that construction of the sanitary sewerage system is under way. The
developer or owner shall be fully responsible for the quality of the materials and methods of the construction work and shall bear full responsibility
for insuring that the sanitary sewerage system shall meet the stated requirements of the Village in every way.
b. Upon completion of construction and prior to the beginning of the maintenance warranty period and again approximately one year after the
commencement of the warranty period, a video taped television inspection shall be performed on the sections or portions of the sewer as directed
by the Village Engineer. Video tapes and written reports for all television inspections shall be provided to the Village prior to the acceptance of the
sanitary sewerage system. The report shall include the footage traveled by the camera recorded as each stub is passed. The form of the report
and the format of the videotape shall be approved by the village engineer. All fees and costs involved in this television inspection shall be borne by
the developer or owner.
c. The village engineer shall inspect the sanitary sewerage system under construction during construction as deemed necessary. The village
engineer shall not be responsible to direct the work of the contractor but shall be responsible only to assess the acceptability of the improvement
as constructed. In no case shall the village engineer be responsible for day-to-day quality control at the site of construction.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 428/524
2. Testing: It is the intent of this provision to ensure a sanitary sewerage system with a minimum amount of infiltration. The maximum allowable
infiltration shall be one hundred (100) gallons per inch diameter per mile per day at any time of the year and for any section of the system. The joints
shall be tight and any joint with visible leakage or any section of sanitary sewerage system with infiltration in excess of that specified above shall be
sufficient cause for village rejection of the system.
Repairs made to the sanitary sewerage system in order to fulfill the requirements of this section shall be permanent and shall be equal in quality to
new work constructed in accordance with this section. All such repairs shall be at the expense of the developer or owner.
The sanitary sewerage system testing program shall be paid for by the developer or owner.
The village engineer shall choose one of the following methods of testing the integrity of the sanitary sewerage system:
a. Infiltration Test: Immediately after backfilling, the entire length of the sewer trench including stubs shall be inundated to normal ground water level
or to eighteen inches (18") above the top of the pipe, whichever is higher. At that time, infiltration tests shall be made to determine compliance with
the allowable infiltration criteria. To measure the amount of infiltration, the contractor shall furnish, install and maintain a V-notch, sharp, crested
wire in a metal frame tightly secured at the lower end of each sewer test section as directed by the village engineer or by a representative of the
Lake Zurich department of public works. The wire shall be installed twenty four (24) hours before the test is to be made. Infiltration will be
measured by measuring the flow over the wire. When infiltration is demonstrated to be within the allowable limits, the contractor shall remove such
wires.
b. Air Test: An air test in accordance with "Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois", section 31-1.11. (Ord. 89-08-
335, 8-21-1989)
10-6-7: WATER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM:
A. Connection Required; Standards:
1. Policy: The board of trustees hereby finds that the protection of the public health, safety and general welfare requires a continuous and dependable
supply of safe, clean potable water. The village has, and shall continue to maintain, such a water supply, which supply is available to every potable
water user within the village's corporate limits. It is the policy of the village therefor that all users of potable water shall be connected to the village's
water supply system. (Ord. 94-06-669, 6-6-1994)
2. Connection Required: Every development and structure in the village that uses potable water for any purpose shall be connected to the village's
water supply system if: a) any portion of the village's water supply system intended to serve that development or structure is within two hundred fifty
feet (250') of any point of the subject property of that development or structure, or b) if any point of the subject property of that development lies
within one thousand feet (1,000') of any point of the property located at 351 Lions Drive and commonly known as the former village public works site.
This connection requirement shall apply to any and all uses of potable water, including, without limitation, water for consumption, for landscape
sprinkling and irrigation, for manufacturing and processing, and for fire protection; provided, however, that a property served as of January 1, 1994,
with a private well used only for landscape sprinkling and irrigation and not for any potable water purpose may continue to be so served for such
purposes only, but only under the condition stated in subsection A3 of this section. All nonresidential connections to the village's water supply system
shall be at least two inches (2") in diameter.
3. Potable Water Wells Prohibited: Notwithstanding any other provision of this code or of any other village code, ordinance, or regulation, and subject
only to the next sentence of this subsection A3, no potable water wells shall be constructed or used in the village except only by the village for
village-related public purposes. A private well existing as of January 1, 1994, may be maintained provided that such well is used only for landscape
sprinkling and irrigation and not for any potable water purpose and provided, further, that no such well shall be substantially repaired or renovated. If
any such well requires such substantial repair or renovation, then such well shall be properly abandoned and an appropriate connection shall be
made to the village's water supply system. The determination of whether a repair or renovation is "substantial" shall be made by the village engineer
in the exercise of his or her sound judgment based on the condition of the well, the scope of the repair or renovation, the cost of such repair or
renovation compared to the value of the well before such repair or renovation and other factors the village engineer reasonably determines are
appropriate. (Ord. 2001-02-93, 2-20-2001)
4. Minimum Standards: Every development in the village shall include a water distribution system, connected to the village's water supply system, that
provides adequate potable water to the development for all required uses, including, without limitation, consumption and fire suppression purposes.
Every water distribution system shall include a service connection or connections at the approximate midpoint of the front property line of each lot or
parcel in the development. If a lot includes, or is intended to include, more than one building, or if water main construction is required for fire
suppression purposes, then the development shall include all water main construction and appurtenances within the lot or parcel except service
lines.
5. References To Specifications: Specification references made in this section for manufactured materials such as pipe, hydrants, valve, and fittings
refer to designations of the American water works association (the AWWA) or of the American national standard institute (ANSI). All water
distribution systems shall be constructed in accordance with the "Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois", latest
edition, unless otherwise specifically provided in this section. (Ord. 94-06-669, 6-6-1994)
B. Design Standards:
1. The layout of the water distribution system shall be designed to serve the entire development. All water mains shall be of an adequate size to supply
the required domestic consumption needs, as well as the necessary fire flow requirements. It shall be the responsibility of the design engineer to
verify, by calculation, that these flow demands are met with a required minimum of twenty (20) psi residual pressure. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-1989)
2. Design Flow: For the purpose of designing the water distribution system, the following design formula shall be used:
DF=( C )(O)(X+P)
Where DF is needed fire flow, DF in gal per min (L/min); C is a construction factor that depends upon the construction of the structure under
consideration; O is an occupancy factor that depends upon the combustibility of the occupancy; and (X+P) is an exposure factor that depends upon
the extent of exposure from and to adjacent structures.
The coefficients in the formula indicate that, where portions of a building have differing characteristics, a factor can be calculated for each section
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 429/524
and multiplied by the percentage it represents of the effective area to obtain a weighted factor. The weighted C factor should not be less than the
individual factor required for any individual section.
a. Construction Factor: The construction factor, C is calculated from the following formula:
C=18F.A
Where:
F = Coefficient related to the class of construction,
= 1.5 for construction class 1 (frame),
= 1.0 for construction class 2 (joisted masonry)
= 0.8 for construction class 3 (noncombustible) or construction class 4 (masonry, noncombustible),
= 0.6 for construction class 5 (modified fire-resistant) or construction class 6 (fire-resistive), and
A = effective building area.
(1) The effective building area is the total square foot (m) area of the largest floor plus:
(A) Construction classes 1 through 4: fifty percent (50%) of all other floors.
(B) Construction classes 5 and 6: twenty five percent (25%) of the area not exceeding the two (2) largest floors when all of the vertical openings
have at least one and one-half (11/2) hour rated protection, or fifty percent (50%) of the area not exceeding eight (8) floors when vertical
openings are unprotected or have less than one and one-half (11/2) hour protection.
The value of C should not be less than five hundred (500) gpm (1,893 L/min) nor greater than eight thousand (8,000) gpm (30,280 L/min) for
construction classes 1 and 2, and six thousand (6,000) gpm (22,710 L/min) for construction classes 3, 4, 5, and 6, or any single, one story
building, regardless of construction.
b. Occupancy Factor: The occupancy factor, O, reflects the combustibility of the occupancy on the needed fire flow and is determined from the
occupancy combustibility class. Occupancy factors can be found in table 6-5A of this section. Typical occupancies and their classification can be
found in table 6-5B of this section.
c. Exposure And Communication [(X+P)] Factors: The exposure and communication factors are determined as:
(X+P) = (1+n) (X+P)
Where:
n = number of sides of subject building exposed to adjacent buildings, and
(X+P) has a maximum value of 1.75.
(1) The exposure factor, X, reflects the need for additional water to reduce the exposure to adjacent buildings. It depends on the separation
distance, the construction of the exposed building wall in feet (m) multiplied by the height in stories. Values can be obtained from table 6-5C of
this section.
(2) The communication factor, P, reflects the potential fire spread through open or enclosed communicating passageways between buildings and is
taken from table 6-5D of this section. Where there is more than one connection, only the one with the largest factor is used. Where there are no
openings, P=O.
d. Design Flow (DF): The needed fire flow is calculated from the formula given previously and from the above factors. The DF calculated from the
formula should be rounded to the nearest two hundred fifty (250) gpm (946 L/min) for flows under two thousand five hundred (2,500) gpm (9463
L/min) and to the nearest five hundred (500) gpm (1893 L/min) for larger flows and then adjusted by the following:
(1) For buildings with a wood roof, add five hundred (500) gpm (1893 L/min).
(2) When calculating the required fire flow using the provided formula, the calculated fire flow may be reduced by twenty five percent (25%) if the
building is equipped with a complete fire suppression system. An additional twenty five percent (25%) may be taken if the building is a type 1,
type 2A, or type 2B construction.

3. Pipe Size: The minimum water main pipe shall be eight inches (8") in diameter. Six inch (6") diameter pipe shall only be used as a service line to a
fire hydrant or as the last run of piping to a fire hydrant on a dead-end water main.
The following minimum diameters of water mains shall be used based upon the determined fire flow requirements:
*Flow 2,000 GPM = 8 inch water main
*Flow 2,000 GPM to 3,000 GPM = 10 inch water main
*Flow 3,000 GPM to 4,000 GPM = 12 inch water main
*Flow >4,000 GPM = subject to review and approval of village engineer
4. Water Main Layout: All water distribution mains shall be installed in such a manner as to create a balanced loop. In those cases where looping of the
water distribution mains, as determined by the village director of public works or the fire chief, is not feasible, then single directional feed resulting in
a dead end may be permitted. Water service to a fixed fire suppression system shall not be permitted from a dead-end water distribution main. (Ord.
2001-02-91, 2-20-2001)
5. Fire Hydrants:
a. Fire hydrants shall be installed at all street intersections, both public and private.
b. Fire hydrants shall be installed along public streets at a maximum spacing of three hundred feet (300'), in addition to the fire hydrants required at
all street intersections. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-1989)
c. When any portion of a structure or building is more than two hundred fifty feet (250') from the nearest fire hydrant, then additional fire hydrants
shall be installed. One fire hydrant shall be installed no closer than fifty feet (50') and no further than two hundred feet (200') from the fire
department connection to any fixed fire suppression system.
Any water distribution mains installed in connection with these fire hydrants shall comply with all other provisions of this code.
Subject to the prior approval of the village director of public works and the fire chief, fire hydrants installed upon adjacent properties may be used
to satisfy these requirements. (Ord. 2001-02-91, 2-20-2001)
d. In the center of the street, directly in front of the fire hydrant, a reflective street marker shall be securely attached to the pavement. This device
shall be colored blue and comply with all applicable department of transportation (DOT) standards. The specific type of reflective device must be
approved by the village engineer and/or director of public works, prior to installation by the developer.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 433/524
e. At a point which is three feet (3') directly behind each fire hydrant, a rigid metal post topped with a piece of rigid metal plate coated with a reflective
paint shall be installed. The rigid metal post shall project a minimum of five feet (5'), but not more than eight feet (8') straight up from finished
grade. The rigid metal post shall be of sufficient length to permit adequate depth for support of the entire unit. The rigid metal plate coated with
reflective paint shall be a minimum of twenty (20) square inches in size and shall be coated with OSHA safety yellow reflective paint. The entire
assembly shall be constructed and/or coated in such a manner as to be resistant to corrosion and need for maintenance. The specific type of
assembly and its construction shall be approved by the village engineer and/or director of public works, prior to installation by the developer.
f. All fire hydrants shall have a minimum of seven (7) cubic feet of one inch (1") to one and one-half inch (11/2") stone placed at the base of the
hydrant to permit proper drainage of the barrel.
g. All fire hydrants shall be placed a minimum of three feet (3'), but no more than five feet (5') from the back of the street curb.
h. The break line flange of each fire hydrant shall not be less than one inch (1") nor more than three inches (3") above finished grade.
i. Each fire hydrant shall be a Mueller centurian A423, dry barrel type with break line flange and auxiliary gate valve. Each fire hydrant shall have two
(2) 21/2-inch hose outlets and one 41/2-inch hose outlet. All threads shall be national standard thread (NST). Each fire hydrant shall have a main
valve opening of five and one-quarter inches (51/4").
6. Valves And Vaults:
a. Valves shall be located on all water distribution mains to permit isolation of specific sections of the main from the entire system with minimal
disruption of service.
b. Valves shall be installed at every six hundred feet (600') or less along all water distribution mains. Additional valves shall be installed, as needed,
so that no more than two (2) fire hydrants and/or twenty five (25) dwelling units are affected by isolation of any section of water distribution main.
c. Valves shall be arranged in such a manner that it will require no more than four (4) valves to be closed in order to isolate a section of water
distribution main.
d. Valve vaults shall be required on all valves two and one-half inches (21/2") in size or larger. The specific size of each vault shall be determined by
the village engineer.
7. Thrust Blocks: Thrust blocks shall be required at all fire hydrants and fittings, where stress due to water hammers may occur. Specific design of each
thrust block shall be approved by the village engineer and/or director of public works, prior to installation by the developer.
8. Depth Of Water Distribution Mains: All water distribution mains shall be installed at five feet six inches (5'6") below final grade, unless approved
otherwise by the village engineer and/or director of public works. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-1989)
C. Materials: All water distribution system elements shall conform to exhibit no. 13 in section 10-8-1 of this title and to the following specifications: (Ord.
2001-02-91, 2-20-2001)
1. Pipe for water main and for service connections larger than two inches (2") in diameter shall be minimum thickness class 52 (ANSI A21.50) ductile
iron pipe (DIP) manufactured in accordance with ANSI A21.51 with cement lining conforming to ANSI A21.4. Fittings for DIP shall conform to ANSI
A21.10. Joints for DIP shall be mechanical or push-on joints conforming to ANSI A21.11.
Pipe for water service connections two inches (2") or less in diameter, with one inch (1") being the minimum diameter, shall be type K copper pipe
conforming to ASTM B88.
Lead pipe shall not be allowed. Solder containing lead shall not be allowed in making joints or repairs.
If the soil report for the development indicates the possibility of corrosive soils, a manufacturer-approved polyethylene wrap shall be specified for all
ductile iron pipe. Installation shall be in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations.
2. All valves shall turn counterclockwise to open. Valves for pipes up to sixteen inches (16") in diameter shall be Mueller resilient wedge gate valves of
iron body construction with bronze-mounted seats, nonrising stems, mechanical joints and A-2380-20 O-ring seals.
Corporation stops shall be Mueller H-15000, one inch (1") in size.
Roundway for copper pipe service connections shall be Mueller H-15150, one inch (1") stop, Minneapolis pattern.
Curb box shall be Mueller H-10300. Upper section shall have an inside diameter of one and one-quarter inch (11/4"). The size of the Minneapolis
thread in hose shall be two inches (2").
Curb stops for ductile iron pipe service connections shall conform to the specifications given above for valves for pipe up to sixteen inches (16") in
diameter.
3. Fire hydrants shall be Mueller centurion, A-423 model dry barrel, break-flange hydrants conforming to AWWA C502. They shall be painted yellow
aboveground and shall include a waterous corporation six inch (6") resilient wedge auxiliary gate valve with six inch (6") to twenty four inch (24") long
spacer. See exhibit no. 17 in section 10-8-1 of this title.
The main valve shall have a diameter of five and one-quarter inches (51/4") and shall open in a counter-clockwise direction.
The hydrant shall have two (2) 21/2-inch and one 41/2-inch nozzles each with national standard threads.
The joints shall be mechanical or flange, six inches (6") in diameter.
4. Valve boxes for fire hydrant auxiliary valves and for DIP water service connection valves with diameters larger than two inches (2") but no greater
than ten inches (10") shall have the equivalent of Mueller cast iron valve boxes no. 664-S (in pavement) or H-1303-1 (not in pavement) with
"WATER" embossed in lid.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 434/524
Valve boxes for copper water service connections shall be Minneapolis type with a plugged lid.
5. Any valves larger than four inches (4") in diameter, except fire hydrant auxiliary valves, shall be placed in valve vaults.
Valve vaults shall be precast, reinforced concrete conforming to ASTM C478 with preformed bituminous joints and a concentric cone. Vaults for
valves eight inches (8") or less in diameter shall be forty eight inches (48") in diameter; vaults for valves larger than eight inches (8") in diameter shall
be sixty inches (60") in diameter. No steps are required. See exhibit no. 16 in section 10-8-1 of this title.
No more than two (2) adjusting rings shall be allowed for a total possible adjustment of eight inches (8").
In paved areas, Neenah Foundry Company R-1712 frames and closed lids with "WATER" embossed thereon shall be used and chimney seals shall
be installed. Where vaults fall in nonpaved areas, Neenah Foundry Company R-1772-A frames and closed lids may be used. All lids shall be
watertight with machined horizontal bearing surfaces.
6. Air release valves shall be Apco type 200A or as approved by the Lake Zurich Department of Public Works.
7. Casting pipes shall be five-sixteenths inch (5/16") minimum thickness steel conforming to ASTM A120.
8. Bedding shall be well compacted crushed stone or crushed gravel conforming to IDOT CA-6, 100% crushed.
9. Blocking shall be constructed of poured or precast Class X concrete against undisturbed earth. See Exhibit No. 15.
D. Construction:
1. No construction permit(s) shall be issued until copies of all the required permits from the pertinent public agencies are reviewed by the Village
Engineer and filed with the Village Building Department.
2. No construction shall begin until at least forty eight (48) hours after the Village Engineer has been notified of the intention to begin construction.
3. The trench shall be excavated so that the water main will have at least five and one-half feet (51/2') of cover over all winter seasons.
4. Bedding shall be placed as shown in Exhibit No. 1. The bedding surface shall be adjusted to support the bottom of the pipe at all points.
5. If a significant amount of water enters the trench during pipe laying, it shall be removed before operations may continue. No trench water shall be
allowed entry into the newly laid pipe.
6. If soft, spongy or other unsuitable soils are encountered at the bottom of the trench, all such material shall be removed and replaced with well
compacted crushed limestone bedding material. If rock is encountered, it shall be removed to at least six inches (6") below the bottom of the pipe to
allow the proper thickness of bedding to be installed.
7. Adequate provision shall be made for the safety, storage and protection of all water pipe prior to actual installation in the trench. Care shall be taken
to prevent damage to the pipe castings, both inside and out. The inside of the pipe shall be kept clean throughout its storage period. All pipe shall be
thoroughly cleaned on the inside before laying of the pipe. Proper equipment shall be used for the safe handling, conveying and laying of the pipe.
All pipe shall be carefully lowered into the trench, piece by piece, by means of suitable tools or equipment so as to prevent damage to water main
materials and protective coatings and linings. Under no circumstances shall water main materials be dropped into the trench.
8. All portions of the joining materials, the socket and the spigot of the joining pipes shall be wiped clean of all foreign materials at the time the joints
are assembled. Assembly shall be in accordance with the manufacturer's installation instructions and as instructed in writing by the Village Engineer.
The open end of the installed pipe shall be sealed with a watertight plug until the next pipe is added.
9. Cutting of pipe for any purpose shall be done in a neat, workmanlike manner without damage to the cement mortar lining. Such cuts shall result in a
smooth end at a right angle to the axis of the pipe. A bevel shall be neatly filed or ground around the outside circumference of the pipe to minimize
damage to the gasket material at that joint. All debris from the cutting operation shall be removed from the inside of the pipe and from the joint area.
Flame cutting of pipe shall not be allowed.
Structures shall not be broken to provide holes for pipe but shall be neatly saw-cut using the proper equipment.
10. All joints requiring the use of a fitting shall be blocked as shown in Exhibit No. 15 where undisturbed earth is available to spread the reaction forces.
Where undisturbed earth is not available, the plans shall include a detail of a tie-rod system to absorb reaction forces and to transmit them to
undisturbed earth or to concrete anchors. The tie-rod system shall be subject to the approval of the Village Engineer.
Blocking of fittings shall not interfere with access to the adjacent joints. Care shall also be taken to avoid interfering with fire hydrant drainage.
11. Repaired sleeves shall not be used to effect connections with other portions of the water distribution system. Instead, fittings and/or short-cut
lengths shall be used to properly connect new water main components.
12. The trench shall be carefully backfilled with the excavated material except as follows:
a. Trenches in or within two feet (2') of a roadway, parking area, curb, sidewalk or any other paved area shall be backfilled with trench backfill in
accordance with the pertinent sections of the "Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction". See Exhibit No. 2.
b. At locations where it is known other pipe utilities are to cross above the water main, the water main pipe shall be encased with standard bedding
material to a level of one foot (1') above the top of the pipe for a distance of five feet (5') in either direction from the point of crossing, measured at
the top of such encasement.
13. The trench shall be backfilled and compacted in accordance with section 502.11 of the "Standard Specification for Road and Bridge Construction",
except the backfill material shall be compacted everywhere, not just near and under pavements or sidewalks. Density requirements may be relaxed
somewhat away from pavements or sidewalks.
If jetting is used as a compaction method, the jetting tube shall not be allowed within two feet (2') of the pipe. The jetting tube shall be inserted along
the trench at six foot (6') intervals.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 435/524
14. All connections to existing water distribution elements shall be made under full water system pressure unless the Lake Zurich Department of Public
Works and the Village Engineer approve otherwise. Such variant connections shall be made only where and when approved by the Village Engineer.
15. When making a connection to existing water distribution elements, it is mandatory that a representative from the Lake Zurich Department of Public
Works or the Village Engineer be present.
16. Fire hydrants shall be installed plumb with the pumper nozzle oriented perpendicularly to the roadway or pavement edge. Barrel extension sections
shall be provided and installed as necessary to leave the nozzle eighteen inches (18") to twenty four inches (24") (absolute limits) above finished
grade.
A drainage pit two feet (2') in diameter shall be excavated below each hydrant and filled completely with one inch (1") washed stone to a level six
inches (6") above the hydrant drainage opening. The drainage pit shall not be connected in any way to the storm sewerage system.
E. Inspection:
1. The developer or owner shall have an employee in charge on-site at all times that construction of the water distribution system is under way. The
developer or owner shall be fully responsible for the quality of the materials and methods of the construction work and shall bear full responsibility for
insuring that the water distribution system shall meet the requirements of the Village in every way.
The Village Engineer shall inspect the water distribution system under construction during construction as they deem necessary. The Village
Engineer shall be responsible only to assess the acceptability of the improvement as constructed. In no case shall the Village Engineer be
responsible for day-to-day quality control at the site of construction.
2. Testing: The completed water mains and appurtenances of the water distribution system improvement shall be tested to the satisfaction of the Lake
Zurich Department of Public Works and the Village Engineer. All newly laid water main shall be subjected to a hydrostatic pressure of one hundred
fifty (150) p.s.i. maintained for not less than two (2) hours. Each valved section of pipe shall be filled with water to the specified test pressure, all air
shall be expelled from the pipe. All leaks shall be repaired until tight. Any cracked or defective pipes, fittings, valves or hydrants discovered shall be
replaced and the test repeated until satisfactory results are obtained.
Suitable means shall be provided for determining the amount of water lost to leakage under the specified test pressure. Allowable leakage shall not
exceed that computed as follows:
(N) (D) VP
L =
7400
L = Allowable leakage in gallons per hour
N = Number of joints in test section
D = Nominal diameter of pipe in inches
P = Average pressure at lowest point in the line under test corrected to gauge elevation
Leakage is defined as the quantity of water required to be supplied to the newly laid pipe per hour to maintain the test pressure. Water shall be
added each time pressure in the main drops to one hundred forty (140) pounds to bring line pressure back up to one hundred fifty (150) pounds.
Gauge readings shall take into account any difference in elevation between gauge and water main under test.
F. Preliminary Flushing: After the pressure test is passed but prior to chlorination, the main shall be thoroughly flushed. If there is no hydrant at the end of a
main, a tap shall be provided large enough to effect a velocity in the main of at least two and one-half feet (21/2') per second.
G. Disinfection: All water mains shall be disinfected and tested according to the requirements of the "Standards for Disinfecting Water Mains", AWWA
C601, and as required in this Section. All disinfection shall be performed by an independent firm with experience in the methods and techniques of this
operation. The choice of firm shall be subject to the approval of the Village Engineer and Public Works.
The chlorinating agent shall be introduced at the beginning of the pipeline extension or any valved section of it through a corporation stop in the top of
the newly laid pipe. The water injector for delivering the chlorine gas into the pipe shall be supplied from a tap on the pressure side of the gate valve
controlling the flow of water into the pipeline extension.
Water from the existing distribution system or other source of supply shall be controlled so it flows slowly into the newly laid pipe during the application
of chlorine gas. The rate of chlorine mixture flow shall be in such proportion to the rate of water entering the pipe that the chlorine dose applied to the
water entering the newly laid pipe shall be at least forty (40) ppm, or enough to meet the requirements during the retention period. This may require as
much as one hundred (100) ppm of chlorine in the water in the line at time of chlorination.
The valves shall be adjusted so that the chlorine solution in the line being treated will not flow back into the line supplying the water.
Treated water shall remain in the pipe for at least twenty four (24) hours. The chlorine residual at the pipe extremities and at other representative points
shall then be measured to be twenty five (25) ppm or more. If the amount of residual chlorine is too low, the pipeline extension shall be rechlorinated.
All valves or other appurtenances in the newly laid pipe shall be operated while the pipe is full of chlorinating agent.
After chlorination, the pipeline extension shall be thoroughly flushed until the replacement water is approved as safe by the village engineer and the
Lake Zurich department of public works. The water shall be tested over a period of two (2) days. Test samples shall be drawn by the Lake Zurich
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 436/524
department of public works from taps located as directed by the Lake Zurich department of public works and installed by the contractor. The samples
shall be tested by the Lake Zurich department of public works. Chlorination and testing shall continue until satisfactory results are obtained.
The cost of flushing, disinfection, sampling and testing shall be borne by the owner or developer. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-1989)
10-6-8: STREETS AND PAVEMENTS:
A. Intent: It is the intent of this standard to provide for the construction of roadways that are safe to use, easy to maintain, conductive to the efficient flow of
vehicular and pedestrian traffic, complementary to the existing roadway system of the village, and sturdy enough to last without major repairs or
resurfacing for the design life of the pavement.
B. Design References: All pavements shall be designed and constructed in accordance with one or more of the following references as they apply:
1. "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction", Illinois department of transportation.
2. "Manual For Structural Design Of Portland Cement Concrete Pavement", Illinois department of transportation.
3. "Manual Of Instructions For The Structural Design Of Flexible Pavements On Projects Involving MFT, FAS And FAUS Funds", Illinois department of
transportation.
4. "Design Manual", Illinois department of transportation.
5. "Manual On Uniform Traffic Control Devices For Streets And Highways", Illinois department of transportation.
6. "Minimum Standards For Street Design", village of Lake Zurich, exhibit 19.
C. Street Arrangement: Where such is not shown on the comprehensive plan and/or official map, the arrangement of streets within subdivisions shall
either:
1. Continuity: Provide for the continuation or projection of existing principal streets in adjacent areas; or
2. Conformity With Plan: Conform to a plan for the area or neighborhood approved or adopted by the village to meet a particular situation where
topographical or other conditions make continuance or conformance to existing streets impractical.
D. Street Design: All required street right of way width, and pavement widths, curves, gradients and site distances shall be as shown in the appendix and
in accordance with the following:
1. Street Jogs: Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than one hundred twenty five feet (125') shall be avoided.
2. Intersections: It must be evidenced that all street intersections and confluences encourage safe and efficient traffic flow and, in general, be at or near
right angles, and in no case shall a street intersect any other street at less than sixty degrees (60o). An intersection of more than two (2) streets shall
not be permitted.
3. Cul-De-Sac Streets: A cul-de-sac street, in single-family residential districts, shall be not more than six hundred feet (600') in length, measured along
its centerline from the point of origin to the end of its right of way. Cul-de-sac streets shall not be permitted in multi-family residential, commercial or
industrial areas.
Each cul-de-sac street shall have a terminus of nearly circular shape with a minimum right of way diameter of one hundred twenty feet (120') and
pavement outside diameter of not less than eighty eight feet (88').
4. Median Strips: Median strips other than raised center curb separating lanes of traffic within a single right of way shall not be allowed. However,
where a parkway exists on a new street which is an extension of the existing street, a median strip may be constructed not more than five hundred
feet (500') in length to provide the transition to no median strip. All such median strips as described above shall have barrier curbs and gutters.
5. Access From Major Streets: Provisions shall be made for vehicular and pedestrian access to residential property abutting a major street either by
providing: a) a marginal access road, or b) by backing lots to the thoroughfare and providing access by a collector, minor or cul-de-sac street one lot
depth removed and with a no access strip at least twelve feet (12') wide along the rear lot line. These standards are established for the purpose of
providing protection for the residential properties and to provide for traffic safety and the efficient use of the major street for its intended function of
accommodating through traffic.
6. Frontage Roads: Where a subdivision borders on or contains a railroad or highway, the plan commission may require a street approximately parallel
to and on each side of such railroad or highway, at a distance suitable for the appropriate use of the intervening land, as for park purposes in
residential districts, or for commercial or industrial purposes in appropriate districts. Such distances shall also be determined with due regard for the
requirements of approach grades and future grade separations.
7. Reserve Strips: Reserve strips controlling access to public utilities, streets or alleys shall be prohibited.
8. Street Levels: Street levels shall provide proper relation between the street and the elevation of the houses to assure positive drainage from the
building to the street.
E. Alleys: Alleys shall not be permitted.
F. Private Access Streets; Planned Developments:
1. Design Approval: The completed design for access streets, including specifications and designation of traffic ways, driving lanes, paving widths,
thickness, materials, etc., shall be submitted to the plan commission for review and approval prior to the issuance of building permits or the sale or
lease of buildings or land in planned developments as defined in section 10-2-3 of this title. The minimum number of off street parking spaces shall
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 437/524
be in accordance with the requirements of the zoning ordinance of the village. Where more than one owner or lessee are to use the same private
marginal access road or parking lot, a trust indenture shall be recorded before approval of the multi-family, commercial or industrial subdivision as
defined herein.
2. Ingress And Egress: A minimum distance may be recommended by the plan commission and required by the village board where deemed
necessary between points of ingress and egress where all property to be subdivided is under one ownership on the effective date hereof. Where
property has frontage on a state or federal highway, the spacing and design of the points of ingress and egress to the major highway shall be subject
to approval of the IDOT division of highways. Where property has frontage on a Lake County roadway, the spacing and design of the points of
ingress and egress to that roadway shall be subject to approval by the Lake County department of highways.
3. Conventional Development: A paved accessway from the property line to the street shall be provided as wide as the driveway for the dwelling to be
served; except, that no access driveway shall exceed twenty five feet (25') in width. In the case of property zoned for other than single-family
dwelling units, the requirements for access driveways shall conform as closely as possible therewith. Pavement shall be of concrete.
a. Sidewalks: Sidewalks located along expressways, major or collector type or designated streets shall be located so that a parkway separates the
curb from the sidewalk. Such sidewalk shall not be less than five feet (5') wide.
b. Pedestrianways Required: Pedestrianways or crosswalks, not less than ten feet (10') in the right of way with a paved walkway in accordance with
section 10-6-14 of this chapter, shall be provided near the center of any block in excess of one thousand feet (1,000') in length or in any other
block as recommended by the plan commission and approved by the village board. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-1989)
G. Fire Lanes: Fire lanes shall be installed as required in subsection 8-9-2H of this code. (Ord. 2005-06-357, 6-20-2005)
H. Materials: Pavement materials shall comply with the minimum requirements shown in the following table. Listed with these materials are the coefficients
to be used for computing the pavement structural number. The sum of the products of the coefficients and the course thickness is the calculated
structural number.

All aggregate material for subbase and base courses shall be crushed stone or crushed gravel. Where stone is required for undercut areas, it shall be
crushed stone; no round or subangular material shall be used.
I. Subgrade Preparation:
1. Subgrade material shall have a minimum Illinois Bearing Ratio (IBR) of 3.0 in all areas to be paved. The IBR of the subgrade shall be shown in the
plans.
If subgrade is undercut and replaced with angular stone three inches (3") in diameter or larger, the depth of undercut shall be at least twelve inches
(12"). In addition, a well graded aggregate shall be included with the larger aggregate to fill the voids.
Undercutting shall be done very carefully to avoid damage to shallow improvements. The Village Engineer shall carefully inspect shallow
improvements for damage. The contractor responsible for any damage and the developer or owner shall effect the proper and timely repair of
damaged improvements.
2. The subgrade of all paved areas shall be graded and rolled in accordance with the State Standard Specifications, section 212. Embankment shall be
placed and compacted in accordance with section 207 of the State Standard Specifications except as modified in these Standards and
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 438/524
Specifications.
3. At least one moisture and density test shall be taken in each embankment section, with the maximum distance between tests of three hundred feet
(300'). The method of testing shall be subject to the approval of the Village Engineer. The density tests must be submitted for review to the Village
Engineer, and a report of acceptable subgrade preparation must be submitted to the Village Engineer before proof-rolling of the subgrade may take
place.
4. The subgrade shall be proof-rolled in the presence of the Village Engineer. All deficiencies shall be repaired before the subbase or the base course
is placed.
Proof-rolling shall be done using a three-axle dump truck together with load weighing at least twenty five (25) tons. The tires shall be designed for
highway use and shall be properly inflated. The load shall be uniformly placed in the dump body.
Subgrade allowing deflection of more than one-fourth inch (1/4") at any wheel shall be either recompacted to meet this standard or shall be undercut
as directed by the Village Engineer and replaced with suitable compacted replacement material.
The intent of this provision is to ensure that the subgrade is everywhere adequate to support the pavement structure and the loads it is designed to
carry.
Proof-rolling shall be clearly specified in each set of plans and specifications.
J. Flexible Pavement Construction:
1. Flexible pavement materials may not be installed until March 1, weather permitting. Any work done after November 1 shall require written
authorization from the Village Engineer. This authorization will in no way void the contractor's and the developer's or owner's guarantee of work done.
(Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-89)
2. All bituminous pavement installation shall be done in accordance with sections 406.13, 406.14 and 406.15 of the latest revised edition of the IDOT
Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction. All testing shall be furnished at the owner's expense. In the event that minimum
compaction is not achieved as determined by nuclear density testing methods, the owner will be required to perform additional testing subject to the
Village Engineer's approval. (Letter of 1-10-90)
3. The developer or owner shall notify the Village Engineer at least forty eight (48) hours prior to the installation of a bituminous surface course. All
deficiencies shall be repaired and the binder shall be primed as deemed necessary by the Village Engineer prior to the installation of the final surface
course. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-89)
4. Within four (4) months but not earlier than two (2) months after the final installation of the bituminous surface course, an asphalt rejuvenating agent
shall be applied. The product shall be "Reclamite", a petroleum hydrocarbon in water emulsion. The product shall be applied per the manufacturer's
recommendations and specifications. (Ord. 93-10-615, 10-4-93)
K. Rigid Pavement Construction:
1. Rigid pavements shall be constructed in conformance with all applicable Illinois Department of Transportation standards and specifications. Materials
testing shall be done as specified in the State Standard Specifications.
2. The developer or owner shall notify the Village Engineer forty eight (48) hours prior to the placement of any course and when the street is ready for
final inspection. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-89)
L. Curb and Gutter:
1. Except for Village-owned park parking lots, State "B" series combination concrete curb and gutter shall be constructed on both sides of all full street
pavements and in all parking or loading areas where runoff waters run parallel to the curb. Concrete curb and gutter shall be installed in Villageowned
park parking lots at the Village Engineer's discretion. Concrete barrier curb shall be constructed along all edges of all commercial or industrial
parking or loading areas except as noted above. If curbs are to be cast integrally with a rigid pavement, then they shall be reinforced in the same
manner as the pavement itself. In general, combination curb and gutter and barrier curb shall be designed in accordance with Exhibit No. 248. (Ord.
92-09-551, 9-21-92)
2. Depressed curb or driveway entrances (see Exhibit No. 309) shall be provided at each known driveway entrance. Depressed curb as detailed shall
be provided at each sidewalk intersecting the curb line. State type M-4.XX combination curb and gutter shall be required at mailbox turnouts.
3. Expansion joints shall be installed in all curb and in all combination curb and gutter at intervals not to exceed sixty feet (60') in length. In addition,
expansion joints shall be installed:
a. Five feet (5') on either side of any casting falling in curb or combination curb and gutter;
b. At all changes in horizontal curvature;
c. At all junctions with existing curb or combination curb and gutter;
d. To match expansion joints in abutting rigid pavement or sidewalk.
Expansion joints shall not be installed within ten feet (10') of the center line of a trench crossing the curb.
4. Steel reinforcement consisting of at least two (2) No. 5 steel bars shall be installed in all concrete curbs and gutters at all trench crossings. The
reinforcement shall be continuous in the ten feet (10') (minimum) centered over the trench.
5. Control joints shall be installed in all curb and in all combination curb and gutter at intervals not to exceed fifteen feet (15') in length. They shall be
sawcut to a depth of not less than one and one-half inches (11/2"). They shall also be located so as to match any control joints in abutting pavement
or sidewalk.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 439/524
6. All combination concrete curb and gutter shall be constructed atop at least four inches (4") of well compacted aggregate subbase course material.
Generally, any required aggregate subbase course material or the first four inches (4") of aggregate base course material shall be placed and
compacted to just beyond the back of the curb. It is the intent of this provision that the curb and gutter not block drainage of the subgrade, subbase
or base courses.
