A mid-block crosswalk shall be required where a block abutting a local or collector street is longer than one thousand feet (1,000') measured along the
longest continuous right of way.
2. All turn lanes, crosswalks, etc., shall be marked as shown in the "Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways".
3. All pavement markings shall be thermoplastic pavement marking in conformance with the appropriate material specifications of the "Standard
Specifications for Traffic Control Items," except parking areas and edge lines, which may be painted.
4. All pavement marking lines parallel to the direction of travel shall be six inches (6") in width except edge markings which shall be four inches (4") in
width. Miscellaneous pavement markings, such as that for parking areas, may be four inches (4") in width. Markings not basically parallel to the
direction of travel shall be at least twelve inches (12") in width but shall in no case be less than the width required in the "Manual on Uniform Traffic
Control Devices for Streets and Highways".
5. Immediately after the binder course is placed and compacted, pavement marking tape shall be installed and maintained until the surface course is to
be placed. The pavement marking tape shall be substantially removed before the surface course is placed.
N. Signage: Locations for traffic-control signs ("Stop", "Slow", "One-way", etc.) shall be shown on the plans, and State standard signs shall be provided
and installed by the developer or owner. Required "No-Parking" signs, street name signs and posts shall be provided and installed by the developer or
owner. The size, color and sign materials shall meet the approval of the Public Works Department.
10-6-9: EASEMENTS:
A. Easement Design and Location: Utility distribution or transmission installations serving the subdivision, and when required, storm water drainage ways
shall be located in the easements as designated on the subdivision plat of record. Such easements shall be located along the rear lot lines or side lot
lines at locations and extensions of utility installation between blocks, or continuity of drainage way. They shall occupy not less than the rear five feet
(5') of lot depth or five feet (5') of each lot width adjoining the applicable side lot line, or may be of greater width if recommended by the Village
Engineer and approved by the Board of Trustees. Additional easements at other locations may be recommended for specific conditions by the Village
Engineer and required by the Board of Trustees.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 440/524
B. Continuity of Easements: Easements shall be designed to provide continuity from block to block.
C. Drainage Easements: Where a subdivision is traversed by a natural drainage way, channel or stream, there shall be provided a drainage easement,
conforming substantially with the areas bordering such watercourse that are subject to flooding. The easement width shall be determined by the Village
Engineer.
10-6-10: BLOCKS:
A. Configuration of Blocks: The shape of blocks shall be determined by topographical features, the basic street system and traffic pattern, lot depth and
areas designated for public and other nonresidential land uses. In addition to these, the lengths, widths, and shapes of blocks shall be determined with
due regard to:
1. Site Adequacy: Provision of adequate building sites suitable to the special needs of the type of use contemplated.
2. Zoning: Zoning requirements as to lot sizes and dimensions within the corporate limits of the Village10.
3. Convenience: Needs for convenient access, circulation, control and safety of street traffic.
B. Lengths of Blocks:
1. Residential: In residential subdivisions, the maximum length of blocks shall not exceed one thousand five hundred (1,500) lineal feet. No blocks shall
be less than one thousand (1,000) lineal feet in length unless recommended by the Plan Commission and approved by the Board of Trustees.
2. Nonresidential: In manufacturing and business subdivisions, maximum lengths of blocks shall be as recommended by the Plan Commission and
approved by the Board of Trustees.
C. Nonresidential Blocks: Blocks or portions thereof intended for commercial or industrial use shall be designated as such, and the plan shall show
adequate off-street areas to provide for parking, loading docks and other such facilities.
10-6-11: LOTS:
A. Nonresidential Lots: Width, area and depth of lots in a manufacturing or business subdivision shall be as recommended by the Plan Commission and
approved by the Board of Trustees.
B. Side Lot Lines: Side lot lines of lots shall be at right angles or radial to the street line, or reasonably close.
1. Access to Lots: Each lot within the subdivision must have access to a public or private street unless otherwise provided by local ordinance.
2. Separation from Major Streets: Double frontage and reverse frontage lots shall be avoided except where essential to provide separation of
residential development from major streets or highways or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation. A planting screen
easement of at least ten feet (10'), and across which there shall be no right of vehicular access shall be provided along the rear lot lines of lots
abutting such highways and major thoroughfares.
3. Double Frontage Lots: Double frontage lots are not permitted, except where lots back upon a major street, upon a body of water in separate or
undivided ownership, or in manufacturing and business subdivisions when specifically recommended by the Plan Commission and approved by the
Board of Trustees.
4. Lots Abutting a Watercourse: Lots abutting upon a watercourse, drainageway, channel or stream shall have an additional depth or width as
recommended by the Plan Commission and approved by the Board of Trustees in order to provide acceptable building sites.
5. Preservation of Natural Features: In the developing or subdividing of any land, due regard shall be given to the preservation of natural features, such
as trees, watercourses, historical landmarks, and similar community assets, which, if preserved, would add to the attractiveness and value of the
subdivision, neighborhood or the community as a whole. The Plan Commission shall include in its report its conclusions as to the compliance
herewith.
10-6-12: BUILDING SETBACK LINES:
Building setback lines in all new developments and subdivisions shall conform to the provisions of the Lake Zurich Zoning Ordinance11.
10-6-13: PARKS, SCHOOL SITES AND PUBLIC AREAS:
Whenever required by this Title, or any other ordinance of the Village, parks, school sites and/or other public areas shall be shown on all plans and plats
and shall be of such configuration as to be acceptable to the Plan Commission, Village Board and concerned public agency.
10-6-14: SIDEWALKS:
A. In order to provide a coherent and comprehensive system of pedestrian and bicycle routes, sidewalks shall be required in all streets (1) abutting new
developments, or (2) created by new developments as follows:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 441/524
1. Major Streets: Eight foot (8') wide sidewalk on one side and five foot (5') wide sidewalk on the other. The Village Engineer shall decide which side of
the street is to get which size sidewalk based primarily on providing a relatively coherent bikeway system throughout the Village.
2. Collector Streets: Five foot (5') wide sidewalks on both sides except where the Village Engineer may require an eight foot (8') wide sidewalk to
provide a segment of the bikeway system as noted in subsection A1 above.
3. Local Streets: Five foot (5') wide sidewalk on both sides.
4. Office/Industrial Streets: No sidewalk required except as noted below.
5. Retail/Business Streets: Same as subsection A1 above.
6. Frontage Streets: Five foot (5') wide sidewalk on the side away from street fronted on except where eight foot (8') wide sidewalk may be required to
provide a segment of the bikeway system as noted in subsection A1 above.
7. Mid-block Crosswalks: To serve mid-block crosswalks as required in subsection 10-6-8M1 of this Chapter.
Sidewalks in easements may be required to traverse large parcels of land away from the streets so as to tie together the pedestrian sidewalk system
of the Village. The Village Engineer may require that such sidewalks be eight feet (8') in width to provide a segment of the bikeway system as noted
in subsection A1 above. The Village Engineer may allow the use of bituminous materials rather than concrete for the construction of these easement
sidewalks. Maintenance driveways required along drainage easements may fulfill the requirements of this provision.
In addition, sidewalks shall be required across nonpavement areas between any habitable building entrance or exit meant for normal use and a
paved area or other sidewalk. This provision does not apply to patio door entrances, secondary basement accessways, or emergency exits not used
for everyday access.
B. Design Standards (See Exhibit No. 25):
1. All sidewalks in a public right-of-way or easement or in the portions of parcels fronting on a public right of way or easement shall be concrete with a
minimum thickness of five inches (5"). Six inches (6") of thickness shall be required over improvement trenches and across driveways, except that
sidewalks crossing pavements shall not be of less strength than that of the pavement crossed.
2. All sidewalks in public right of way or easements shall be constructed on a four inch (4") thick (minimum) base course composed of compacted
crushed store or crushed gravel aggregate, gradation CA-6.
3. Sidewalks shall not end at the edges of a driveway but shall be built across in a smooth, continuous manner. At the discretion of the Village
Engineer, this provision may be waived for large commercial or industrial entrances.
4. Sidewalks ending at the curb shall include a handicap ramp of a design functionally similar to those of Exhibit No. 26.
5. Wherever possible, sidewalks shall drain to an edge rather than longitudinally. Sidewalks shall everywhere have a slope compatible with area
drainage of from one percent (1%) to eight percent (8%) measured in the direction of slope. Generally, a cross slope of two percent (2%) shall be
required. Sidewalk slopes in excess of eight percent (8%) in any direction shall require the approval of the Village Engineer. Sidewalk slopes shall
never exceed twelve and one-half percent (12.50%) in any direction.
6. Three-quarter inch (3/4") expansion joints shall be required as follows:
a. Transverse joints at fifty foot (50') intervals longitudinally.
b. Transverse joints to match existing expansion joints in abutting curb or pavement.
c. Transverse or longitudinal joints, as appropriate, between pavements or curbs and sidewalk.
d. Transverse joints at points where placement of concrete is interrupted for thirty (30) minutes or more.
Spacing of transverse expansion joints shall be adjusted at increments equal to the control joint spacing without exceeding the fifty foot (50')
maximum interval to avoid placing such joints in driveway crossings.
7. One-half inch (1/2") expansion joints shall be required at all structures built in or abutting the sidewalk except storm sewerage, sanitary sewerage,
water distribution or underground utility improvement casings.
8. Control joints at least one-fourth (1/4) of the sidewalk thickness deep shall be constructed at right angles to the center line of the sidewalk. Control
joints shall be uniformly spaced at an interval approximately equal to the sidewalk width but not greater than eight feet (8').
Sidewalks more than eight feet (8') wide shall include longitudinal control joints at some convenient interval and shall have a transverse control joint
spacing approximately equal to the distance between longitudinal joints or between the longitudinal joint and the edge.
Control joint slots shall be between one-eighth inch (1/8") and one-fourth inch (1/4") in width and shall have one-fourth inch (1/4") radius edges.
9. Sidewalks abutting curb where both are new construction shall be tied to the curb with smooth, clean No. 4 steel bars eighteen inches (18") long
bent so that six inches (6"), minimum, protrudes from the back of curb into the mid-depth of the sidewalk. The support bars shall be installed on thirty
inch (30") centers, through the expansion joint material, and the portion to be embedded in the sidewalk shall be heavily greased.
C. Materials:
1. Base course for sidewalk shall be well compacted crushed stone or crushed gravel, IDOT grade CA-6.
2. Concrete for use in sidewalks shall meet or exceed the requirements of article 504.08, Composition of Concrete, of the "Standard Specification for
Road and Bridge Construction" for Class X concrete except that the entrained air shall be between five percent (5%) and seven percent (7%).
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 442/524
3. Reinforcing steel shall meet or exceed the requirements of article 710.13, Concrete Reinforcement Bars, Fabric and Strand, of the "Standard
Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction".
4. Expansion joint material shall conform to article 715.05, Preformed Fibre (sid) Joint Filler, of the "Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge
Construction".
5. Side forms shall be steel or two inch (2") (nominal) lumber. Forms shall have a depth equal to or greater than the thickness of the sidewalk. No twoby-
four lumber shall be allowed as forms.
D. Construction:
1. In fill areas, the topsoil shall be removed and the proper grade achieved by filling and compacting in lifts not to exceed six inches (6") loose
thickness. In cut areas, the topsoil shall be removed and the proper grade achieved by excavation. Over-excavated areas shall be filled with select fill
material or crushed stone or crushed gravel aggregate, gradation CA-6 in six inch (6") or less lifts and shall be compacted and brought to correct
grade. Subgrade preparation shall extend to at least six inches (6") beyond the edge of the sidewalk.
2. The contractor for the sidewalk work shall inform the Village Engineer at least forty eight (48) hours before placement of the base material.
3. The granular base material shall be placed and compacted so that the top surface is at least as wide as the sidewalk.
4. Framework shall be constructed in conformance with article 504.06, Forms, of the "Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction". The
forms shall be securely held to line and grade with stakes or braces. The top of the form shall be at the plan grade for the appropriate edge of the
sidewalk.
Base material disturbed by the placement of the forms shall be repaired and recompacted by hand prior to the placement of the concrete.
5. The contractor for the sidewalk work shall inform the Village Engineer at least forty eight (48) hours before the placement of any concrete for
sidewalk.
6. The Village Engineer may require the contractor to provide a test report from a commercial testing laboratory for the first twenty five (25) yards of
concrete delivered and one test report for each additional fifty (50) yards delivered. Each test shall include a slump test, an air content test, two (2)
seven (7) day compression tests, and two (2) twenty eight (28) day compression tests.
7. Concrete for sidewalk shall be placed and compacted in conformance with article 504.12, Placing and Compacting, of the "Standard Specifications
for Road and Bridge Construction".
8. Generally, concrete sidewalks shall have a transverse broomed finished. At handicap ramps, however, the center panel shall be given a different
texture. For example, a distinctively patterned expanded steel screen may be pressed into the surface after the water sheen is gone to impart a
shallow pattern to the concrete. The pattern shall not collect water. On private property, the concrete at handicap ramps shall be given a different
color, either with a colored admixture or with a nonskid concrete paint.
The intent of these provisions is to provide additional visual and tactile evidence of the presence of a ramp-to-pavement transition.
9. During extremes in the temperature, the proper construction techniques as given in the "Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction"
shall be used to protect the integrity of the sidewalk concrete.
10. The edges of sidewalk shall be carefully backfilled as soon as possible after the forms are removed. The intent of this provision is to maintain the
aggregate base course in position. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-89)
10-6-15: STREET LIGHTING SYSTEM:
A. It is the intent of this standard to provide for the installation of a safe, attractive, coherent and easily maintained street lighting system throughout the
Village. It is also the intent of this standard to provide for adequate lighting in off-street areas accessible to the driving public to promote the safe use of
such areas and to promote more efficient public services such as police protection to the properties in and around such areas.
Lighting systems shall be installed in streets and parking areas in all developments. Developments abutting a street with substandard lighting shall be
required to provide a street lighting system for the abutting street that meets the requirements of this Standard.
B. Design References:
1. All residential street lighting systems shall be designed, constructed, owned and maintained by Commonwealth Edison Company.
2. It shall be the responsibility of the developer to coordinate Commonwealth Edison's activities with that of the other subdivision work.
3. Street lights in residential subdivisions shall be placed at least at the following locations: all intersections, center of street curve and the end of a culde-
sac.
4. Commercial street, parking, plaza and pedestrian lighting systems will be a designed system which should define the circulation hierarchy of the
commercial development, expose traffic conditions and provide visual orientation to help both pedestrians and drivers find their way at night. During
the daytime, the repetitive lighting standards should also contribute to this hierarchy and sense of order. The lighting plan will be designed by a
qualified engineer and approved by the Village Engineer.
C. Testing and Acceptance:
1. The Village Engineer shall test the luminaries for distribution. If necessary, the contractor shall adjust the luminaries to attain the design lighting
pattern.
2. After the foregoing has been completed, as-built plans submitted and proof of Commonwealth Edison's acceptance of the work, the street lighting
system shall be considered accepted by the Village. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-89)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 443/524
10-6-16: LOT GRADING:
A. All developments shall provide for the grading of all lots. Lots that are not to be built upon within six (6) months after the time the rest of the
improvements are completed shall be rough-graded to drain and the top three inches (3") disked to provide a bed for turf crop.
B. Lot Grading:
1. Maximum depth of ponding in the event of a storm sewerage system failure shall not exceed twelve inches (12") except in detention and retention
areas. That is, the difference in elevation between the lowest point in a depression and an overland spillway for that depression shall not exceed
twelve inches (12"). (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-89)
2. The finished ground surface shall everywhere (except at high points and low points) have a gradient of between two percent (2%) and eight percent
(8%). Swales may have a minimum longitudinal gradient of two percent (2%). Proposed gradients outside those ranges shall require the approval of
the Village Engineer. At no time will a gradient greater than three to one (3:1) be allowed. Additionally, the use of retaining walls, sandbags,
engineered structures or some similar treatment shall not be allowed in order to effect desired gradient changes. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-89; amd.
Ord. 93-10-615, 10-4-93)
C. Grading Certification: Before public improvements are accepted by the village, the developer's or owner's engineer shall prepare an as built set of
plans. As part of these plans, actual elevations at critical points shall be shown alongside the planned elevations and the planned elevations shall be
neatly crossed out so that the planned elevation is still legible. The developer's or owner's engineer shall attach a certificate to the as built plans
certifying that the elevations as finally built substantially conform to those in the originally approved grading plan. In addition, the developer's or owner's
engineer shall certify that all the lots drain properly in conformance with these standards and specifications. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-1989)
10-6-17: CONSERVANCY DISTRICTS:
(Rep. by Ord. 91-04-444, 4-15-1991)
10-6-18: LANDSCAPING:
A. Landscaping Plan: A landscape plan shall be required with application for all commercial, office, institutional and industrial buildings and all residential
uses (of 6 or more homes or units, unless covered in a previously approved PUD, special use or annexation agreement). The plan shall:
1. Be developed and implemented by a qualified landscape architect.
2. Be drawn at a scale not smaller than the following:
For areas of less than 2 acres, at a scale of 1" = 10'; for areas of 2 to 10 acres, at a scale of 1" = 30'; for areas of more than 10 acres, at a scale of 1"
= 50'.
Reduced copies may also be required by the village. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-1989)
3. Show all proposed grading including final grades from the site plan and including such detail as plant species and tree species and varieties (using
both botanical and common names), size, and quantities to be installed. (Ord. 2003-10-243, 10-6-2003)
B. Trees:
1. Intent And Purpose: This subsection B establishes requirements to protect and preserve existing trees throughout the village. The requirements
apply to all public and private new construction, enlargements or expansion of any structure, building, or parking lot, service areas, all undeveloped
property and other construction. Existing developed or contiguous single-family subdivided residential lots and public rights of way shall be excluded
from the requirements of this subsection B except that a single-family lot large enough in area to be subdivided shall comply with these requirements.
2. Tree Removal: No tree of living quality having a trunk size of four inches (4") or greater in diameter, as measured six inches (6") above the
established ground level, shall be removed from unimproved or partially improved land prior to receiving approval of a tree survey and land
preservation plan supplied by the property owner. (Ord. 2000-05-29, 5-1-2000)
3. Protection Of Existing Trees:
a. Tree Survey And Conditions:
(1) Tree Survey: A tree survey shall be submitted by anyone planning any site development to the village's director of public works and the village
arborist for review, regardless of whether any other development plan is required by this code. The tree survey shall indicate the location, size,
species, and condition of each trunk with a trunk diameter of four inches (4") or more measured six inches (6") about the existing grade. The tree
species shall be stated with both the scientific name and the common name.
(2) Tree Condition: The condition of each tree shall be stated as "poor", "fair", or "good". The following point system, based on a determination of
tree defects or deficiencies, shall be used to determine tree condition:
Poor: 3 or more points
Fair: 1 or 2 points
Good: 0 points
Defect categories (each category represents 1 point):
Cankers
Cavities
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 444/524
Deadwood
Disease
Insect problems
Poor tree architecture
Root problem
Splits/cracks
Weak unions
(Ord. 2003-10-243, 10-6-2003)
b. Landscape Plan: Subject to determination of the village arborist, a reasonable effort shall be made to retain existing trees on the tree survey
through the integration of those trees into the site and landscaping plan for a proposed development. If a reasonable integration into the
development plan is not possible, the developer may choose to mitigate the trees in dispute based upon the exchange rate set forth in subsection
B5 of this section. Removal of trees designated for preservation shall be allowed only pursuant to the provisions of this subsection B.
c. Tree Preservation Plan: A tree preservation plan indicating the location and species of those trees to be preserved, and the methods which are to
be used to preserve such trees, shall be submitted to the village arborist.
4. Preservation Techniques:
a. Grading And Construction Equipment: All grading and construction equipment shall be forbidden from encroaching within the drip line of any tree.
b. Material Detrimental To Trees: Crushed limestone and other materials detrimental to trees shall not be dumped within the drip line of any tree nor
at any higher location where drainage toward the tree could conceivably affect the health of the tree.
c. Installation Of Snow Fencing: Snow fencing shall be installed during construction at the periphery of the drip line of every tree. In an area where a
tree is in the construction zone and fencing the drip line is not possible, two by six inch by eight foot (2 x 6" x 8') long boards banded or wired
around the trunk of that tree shall be provided as protection to adequately prevent scarring.
d. During Construction: If a tree has its roots exposed, the roots are to be pruned. If exposed roots are greater than two inches (2"), the tree crown is
to be pruned to compensate for the root loss. Also, the tree shall be watered and fertilized.
e. Preservation Methodology: The methods which are to be used to preserve those trees shall be clearly specified on the preservation plan. These
shall, at a minimum, include the preservation techniques listed above, although alternative methods may be considered. If, in the opinion of the
village arborist, the necessary precautions as specified in the preservation plan for the development were not undertaken before or during
construction to ensure the preservation of those trees, the building permit for the parcel shall not be issued, or, if previously issued, may be
suspended until such time as these precautions have been complied with.
5. Removal Of Trees Designated For Preservation: If a tree designated for preservation on the preservation plan is destroyed or razed or removed
without receiving prior approval from the village arborist, such tree shall be replaced with a new tree in accordance with the following:
a. Exchange Rate:
Size Of Existing Tree1

Note:
1.Trunk size as measured 6 inches above the established ground level. Every fraction of an inch shall be rounded up to the next highest full number.
b. Minimum Size Of Replacement Trees: All replacement trees shall have a minimum trunk size of four inches (4") in diameter, as measured six
inches (6") above the established ground level, upon installation.
c. Species Of Replacement Trees: Permitted species of replacement trees are set forth in section 7-6-2-2 of this code.
d. Amended Landscape Plan: Removal of trees designated for preservation shall be allowed only by amending the landscape plan and with the
approval of the village arborist and inspection by the village arborist. The amended landscape plan shall indicate the location, species and size of
all replacement trees in accordance with the recommendation of the village arborist.
6. In The Field Adjustments: In the field adjustments to trees designated for preservation on the preservation plan may be necessary during the course
of construction. In such instances, the developer or property owner shall not remove any trees designated for preservation prior to site inspection
and/or consultation with the village arborist. If a tree designated for preservation substantially impedes the development then, but only then, an in the
field adjustment may be approved by the village arborist.
7. Tree Survival Guarantee: Any relocated or replaced tree shall be guaranteed survival for not less than one growing season. In the event a relocated
or replaced tree dies or is in declining condition, the tree shall be replaced with a four inch (4") diameter tree. The requirement of four inch (4") trees
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 445/524
set forth in this code may be modified by the village arborist, if a four inch (4") tree is not suitable for that location, or unavailable, or available but of
poor quality. In such cases, the village arborist may accept either a smaller tree or a greater quantity of smaller trees in accordance with the
exchange rate set forth in subsection B5a of this section.
8. Compliance Bonds: Upon application for a building permit, the owner shall furnish a cash bond to guarantee compliance with the tree preservation
plan and tree replacement requirements. The bond shall be in the amount of three hundred dollars ($300.00) for each tree designated to remain or
be transplanted on the approved tree preservation plan. The bond shall remain in effect for a period of eighteen (18) months after the final
completion of such work. The bond shall be held for the purpose of guaranteeing and securing the correction of any defect or death of plant material
furnished, transplanted, or preserved on site. If such defects have developed, then the cash bond may be applied by the village for any amounts
incurred in correcting such defects; and the balance of such deposit, if any, held at the end of such eighteen (18) month period shall be returned by
the village to the developer, or paid to the order of the depositor, without interest. (Ord. 2000-05-29, 5-1-2000)
C. Areas To Be Final Graded And Sodded:
1. All swales, drainageways subject to immediate erosion, and parkways shall be graded and sodded. The minimum width of sodding in swales shall be
ten feet (10') and shall be centered along the centerline of the swale or to the flow line, whichever is smaller.
2. Areas to be sodded shall be cleared of stumps, badly damaged streets, boulders and other debris. The areas shall then be graded smooth and
compacted. A minimum of six inches (6") of topsoil shall be spread on top of the prepared ground surface.
3. All sodding shall be done in conformance with the applicable sections of the "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction".
4. Sodded areas shall be maintained and repaired as necessary until the growth is uniformly well established.
D. Areas To Be Final Graded And Seeded:
1. All open ground not to be sodded shall be graded, seeded and fertilized.
2. Areas to be seeded shall be cleared of stumps, badly damaged trees, boulders and other debris. The areas shall then be graded smooth and
compacted. For residential development, all topsoil shall be retained on site. No topsoil shall be removed from the site without the written approval of
the village engineer. A minimum of twelve inches (12") of topsoil shall be otherwise prepared for seed. For nonresidential development, all seeded or
sodded areas shall have a minimum of twelve inches (12") of topsoil.
3. All seeding and fertilizing shall be done in conformance with the applicable sections of the "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge
Construction". If straw is used as mulch, it must be applied so that it will not be scattered by the wind.
4. Seeded areas shall be maintained and repaired as necessary until the growth is uniformly well established.
E. Other Landscaping Requirements:
1. Wood chips shall not be used in areas designed to detain storm runoff waters, in areas less than fifteen inches (15") above the bottom of a local
depression or in areas less than fifteen inches (15") above the bottom of a swale serving more than one acre or serving more than two (2) lots.
2. Decorative curbing or retaining walls more than two feet (2') in height, as measured from the original designed and approved ground elevation, shall
not be allowed. All materials used to create such curbing or walls shall be inert and permanent in nature and not subject to rapid corrosion or
deterioration as would be the case with wood or untreated steel. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-1989)
F. Parking Lot Landscaping:
1. Intent And Purpose: This subsection F establishes landscaping standards for certain parking lots, with the goal of protecting and enhancing the
public's health, safety, and welfare by reducing air pollution, reducing noise pollution, and improving the appearance of the village.
2. Applicability: The requirements of this subsection F shall apply on and after October 1, 2003, to:
a. A new parking lot constructed with fifteen (15) parking spaces or more;
b. A reconstructed parking lot containing fifteen (15) parking spaces or more;
c. A parking lot whose number of parking spaces is increased by thirty percent (30%) or more and the resulting number of parking spaces is fifteen
(15) or more, and
d. A parking lot that contains fifteen (15) parking spaces or more and that serves only one building with only one occupancy, if that occupancy
changes; and
e. A parking lot that serves a single retail use of sixty thousand (60,000) gross square feet in area or more, regardless of whether such parking lot
also serves other uses, when the tenancy of that retail use changes.
For purposes of this subsection F, the term "reconstructed" shall mean removal of subbase over, or the grinding of, more than fifty percent (50%) of
the parking lot area or removal of one hundred percent (100%) of the asphalt of a parking lot to expose the subbase.
The provisions of this subsection F shall not apply to the parking lots identified in subsections F2a and F2b of this section if, but only to the extent
that, the installation of any additional landscaping shall cause a reduction of the number of parking spaces in the parking lot to fall below the
minimum number of parking spaces required for that parking lot by the Lake Zurich zoning code.
3. Minimum Landscaped Surface Area: A minimum of fifteen percent (15%) of the gross area of the parking lot, including, without limitation, driving
aisles, shall be landscaped areas. These landscaped areas shall be included in the calculation of the total landscaped area required for the property.
4. General Landscaping Standards:
a. The required landscaping shall be dispersed throughout the parking lot.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 446/524
b. The minimum size for a planting area shall be equivalent to one parking space.
c. In each planting area, a minimum of one 4-inch diameter salt tolerant shade tree shall be planted, and at least one shade tree for every forty (40)
linear feet of continuous islands shall be planted.
d. Each type of tree shall be approved by the village's director of public works prior to planting.
e. The soil in each planting area shall have a drainage rate of not less than two inches (2") of water drop within one hour.
f. All landscaped areas shall be served by a permanent means of irrigation.
g. A minimum of fifty percent (50%) of every interior parking lot landscaping area shall be comprised of live landscaping such as ground cover or
shrubs. The remaining area may be mulched with bark chips or shredded bark mulch to a minimum depth of three inches (3") over a landscaped
fabric.
5. Installation Standards: All landscaping material shall be installed in accordance with the planting procedures established by the "Illinois EPA Urban
Manual".
6. Maintenance: All landscaping shall be maintained in a good condition at all times. All damaged, dead, and diseased plant material shall be replaced
promptly with plant material in good condition.
7. Responsibility For Compliance: The owner of the parking lot, and all of the owner's successors and assigns, shall be responsible for the
maintenance of all landscaped materials. (Ord. 2003-10-243, 10-6-2003)
10-6-19: PUBLIC UTILITIES:
A. All public utility transmission lines of an electrical, electronic or optical nature except radio frequency transmission or reception antennas shall be placed
entirely underground in dedicated easements or in the right of way. Those placed in the right of way or in a multiuse easement shall be located so as to
avoid conflicts with other improvements or utilities located in the right of way easement.
B. All gas mains shall be placed in dedicated easements or in the right of way. They shall be located so as to avoid conflicts with other improvements or
utilities.
C. The village engineer shall be notified at least forty eight (48) hours in advance of any utility installation work.
D. Public utilities shall be installed in accordance with the applicable franchise agreement.
E. Plans for the installation of public utilities shall be submitted to the village plan commission for review and approval.
F. If utility company wording or a utility company sticker is used on the plans, wording shall be added if it is not already there to the effect that all utilities
are to be installed underground. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-1989)
10-6-20: DRIVEWAY ENTRANCES, DRIVEWAYS AND OFF STREET PARKING:
A. Intent: The intent for the design of driveway entrances, driveways and off street parking are threefold: 1) to provide for safe, efficient, easily maintained
and attractive off street parking; 2) to limit the number of access points to off street parking areas in major and collector streets; and 3) to provide
convenient access and safety for the handicapped. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-1989)
B. Design: All parking lots and driving aisles shall be designed to promote safe movement of pedestrians and shall be designed and constructed in
accordance with all of the following standards of the Illinois department of transportation, as applicable: (Ord. 2003-10-243, 10-6-2003)
1. "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction".
2. "Manual For Structural Design Of Portland Cement Concrete Pavement".
3. "Manual On Uniform Traffic Control Devices For Streets And Highways".
C. Definition Of Terms:
COMMERCIAL OFF STREET PARKING AREA: A parking area serving more than four (4) residential units or serving educations, religious,
commercial, medical, industrial or similar concerns.
DRIVEWAY: An accessway constructed primarily outside the street right of way between the driveway entrance and an off street parking area. Where
no sidewalk is present, a driveway shall begin at the right of way line; where a sidewalk is present, a driveway shall begin at the right of way line side of
the sidewalk.
DRIVEWAY ENTRANCE: A paved way from the roadway to the driveway over the parkway. A driveway entrance shall include the curb cut and the
driveway entrance pavement (driveway apron) itself but not the sidewalk.
RESIDENTIAL OFF STREET PARKING AREA: A parking area serving no more than four (4) residential units with a maximum of four (4) individual
parking spaces including garage spaces per residential unit.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 447/524
D. Location And Layout Of Driveway Entrances:
1. Residential lots or sites with less than one hundred feet (100') street frontage shall have no more than one driveway entrance. Residential lots or
sites with one hundred feet (100') or more of street frontage shall have no more than two (2) driveway entrances except as noted below.
2. Commercial lots or sites shall have no more than two (2) driveway entrances on each abutting street except as noted below.
3. Additional driveway entrances shall be permitted as follows:
a. One additional driveway entrance shall be permitted per six hundred feet (600') of continuous frontage on a street.
b. One additional driveway entrance shall be permitted on each abutting street if the additional entrance is for use solely as a service entrance to a
commercial site and is physically separated to the satisfaction of the village engineer from customer or client driveways and entrances.
c. Additional driveway entrances may be permitted to serve multi-unit housing or condominiums from local streets only. The number of additional
permitted entrances shall not exceed one per four (4) residential units.
4. Driveway entrances for individual lots of a multilot residential development shall not be constructed in a major or collector street except with the
permission of the village engineer.
5. No part of a driveway entrance shall be closer to the near right of way line extended of an intersecting street than as follows:

The village engineer may require longer or shorter distances than those shown in accordance with the intent of this subsection.
6. No part of a residential driveway entrance shall overlap an adjacent lot line extended radially to the street centerline. The edge of an uncurbed
residential driveway entrance at the right of way line shall not be closer than five feet (5') to an adjacent property line; the edge of a concrete curbed
residential driveway entrance at the right of way line shall not be closer than ten feet (10') to an adjacent property line.
7. The edges of any two (2) adjacent driveway entrances at the right of way line shall be no less than ten feet (10') apart. No part of two (2) adjacent
driveway entrances shall overlap. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-1989)
8. Driveway entrances for residential off street parking must be a minimum of eight feet (8') in width at the right of way line, and may not exceed a width
of twenty feet (20') at the right of way line, except as provided in this subsection D8. An existing residential driveway entrance that exceeds twenty
feet (20') in width at the right of way line may be maintained, repaired, and replaced at its current width if, but only if, the driveway entrance complied
at the time of its original installation with applicable provisions of this code and the Lake Zurich zoning code. If scavenger services are required to
use the driveway, then the driveway entrance at the right of way must be twenty feet (20') in width.
Driveway entrances for commercial off street parking and for service driveways must be a minimum of twelve feet (12') in width at the right of way
line and may not exceed a width of forty feet (40') at the right of way line. If the commercial or service driveway is meant for simultaneous two-way
traffic, then the minimum required width of the driveway entrance at the right of way line is twenty feet (20'). (Ord. 2008-10-579, 10-6-2008)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 448/524
9. Residential driveway entrances shall be designed as shown in exhibit no. 3012, except that the back of an existing curb may be neatly sawcut to
provide a depressed curb as a substitute for the detailed depressed curb. (Ord. 91-06-452; amd. Ord. 93-10-615, 10-4-1993)
All residential driveway entrances shall be constructed of Portland cement concrete or bituminous asphalt.
Single-family residential driveway entrances shall be allowed only in local or frontage streets in new construction.
Driveways serving village owned or leased facilities in Kuechmann park may be constructed of gravel or other material as determined by the village
to be appropriate. (Ord. 91-06-452, 6-3-1991)
10. Commercial driveway entrances shall be laid out in accordance with generally accepted engineering practices. Commercial driveway entrances
shall include curbs with a flag radius of at least fifteen feet (15'). Larger radii may be required to accommodate larger vehicles expected to use the
driveway entrance.
Commercial driveway entrances serving large commercial, business, or industrial centers may be required to be designed in accordance with street
standards13. Generally commercial driveways supporting two hundred fifty (250) or more nonemployee daily vehicle movements into and out of the
parking area shall require an intersecting street design at the driveway entrance.
Commercial driveway entrances may be rigid or flexible pavements.
11. Driveway entrance locations shall take sightline distances into account. Required stopping sight distances for the roadway involved shall be
increased by fifty feet (50') when used in figuring the location for a driveway entrance.
12. Innovative driveway entrance designs are encouraged but are subject to review by the village engineer.
13. Driveway entrances shall intersect the edge of the roadway as near to perpendicular as possible. A driveway entrance shall not intersect the edge
of the roadway at less than a sixty degree (60°) angle except in the case of a one-way, right turn ramp entrance where allowed or required by the
village engineer.
14. The village engineer shall require the replacement of any street lighting electrical cable damaged during construction of a driveway entrance.
The developer or owner shall notify the village engineer at least twenty four (24) hours before driveway entrance construction is to begin.
15. Driveway entrance slope shall be between two percent (2%) and eight percent (8%). Where practical, the driveway entrance shall drain to the
roadway. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-1989)
E. Parking Area Location And Layout:
1. The minimum aisle width for two-way traffic shall be twenty four feet (24').
2. Each off street parking space shall be a minimum nine feet (9') wide by twenty feet (20') long and not less than one hundred eighty (180) square feet;
provided, however, that the minimum length of a perimeter space or space perpendicular to a landscape area shall be eighteen feet (18'). (Ord. 93-
10-615, 10-4-1993)
F. Driveway And Parking Area Pavement Design: It is the intent of this subsection to provide for the construction of parking area pavements that are
durable, easily maintained and well drained, both on the surface and at the level of the subgrade.
1. Parking and pavements shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the provisions of section 10-6-8, "Streets And Pavements", of this
chapter, except provisions of this section shall govern over any conflicting provisions of section 10-6-8 of this chapter.
2. Minimum driveway and parking area pavement structural numbers shall be as follows:
Not Visible From Public Areas
Commercial Residential
Parking area 2.30 1.90
Fire lane/primary driveway 2.50 1.90
Heavy truck lane 4.00 N/A
Visible From Public Areas
Parking area 2.30 1.90
Fire lane/primary driveway 2.75 1.90
Heavy truck lane 3.15 N/A
3. The subgrade shall everywhere have a minimum slope of one percent (1.00%) draining to a subsurface drainage system of design approved by the
village engineer. A means of draining low spots at inlets or catch basins shall be devised that prevents subgrade fines from entering the storm
sewerage system. The village will require the extensive use of geotextile filter fabrics in and around inlets and catch basins. A means of draining
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 449/524
undercut areas filled with stone or granular backfill shall be devised where other soil conditions indicate it is likely a shallow subsurface water pocket
may form and remain for a significant period of time. The intent of this provision is to ensure that water does not remain in the base, subbase or
subgrade for any significant length of time and to ensure that the integrity of the subgrade is maintained for the life of the pavement.
4. The parking area surface shall everywhere have a slope of at least one percent (1.00%) except at local crests or sags.
5. Where surface runoff waters in the parking areas are to run parallel with and adjacent to the curb, a combination concrete curb and gutter of
standard design shall be used.
6. Maximum slope in an off street parking area or driveway shall be ten percent (10%).
7. Full depth bituminous or concrete pavements shall be placed on a well compacted subbase course at least four inches (4") thick of approved
crushed granular material. The intent of this provision is to provide for a sure drainage path for subsurface water reaching the subgrade.
8. All pavement shall be designed in accordance with street standards14. In no case, however, shall granular base course be less than eight inches (8")
thick after compacted, and asphalt surface and binder courses be less than three inches (3") placed in two (2) lifts.
9. Manholes, valves, vaults and other underground structures primarily for access to underground improvements shall be constructed with chimney
seals or functional equivalents in off street parking areas.
G. Commercial Off Street Parking Area Lighting:
1. Retail parking areas shall be provided with an average illuminance of one foot-candle at times they are in use (active). The average illuminance
divided by the minimum illuminance shall not exceed three (3).
2. Parking area lighting shall be arranged to direct as little light into residential windows as possible.
3. Retail parking areas shall be provided with an average illuminance of two-tenths (0.2) foot-candle at times they are not in use (inactive). The average
illuminance divided by the minimum illuminance shall not exceed ten (10). (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-1989)
Chapter 7
ADMINISTRATION, ENFORCEMENT, FEES
10-7-1: ORGANIZATION:
The following offices of the government of the village are concerned with the administration of this title.
A. The Village Board: The village board is vested with the following responsibilities in regard to subdivision control:
1. Plans And Plats: Approval or disapproval of all preliminary plans and final plats referred to it by the plan commission.
2. Variations: Approval or disapproval of all variations and exceptions recommended by the plan commission.
3. Amendments: Amendments of the regulations of this title when found necessary and desirable after review by the plan commission.
4. Enforcement: Initiation of appropriate proceedings to enforce the provisions of this title.
B. The Village Plan Commission: The plan commission shall administer the provisions of this title and in furtherance of said authority shall:
1. Maintain Title: Maintain permanent and current records of this title, including amendments thereto.
2. File Plans And Plats: Receive and file all preliminary plans and final plats (together with applications).
3. Liaison With Concerned Agencies: Forward copies of the preliminary plan to other appropriate offices and agencies for their recommendations and
report.
4. Liaison With Village Board: Forward with recommendations to the village board all preliminary plans.
5. File All Checked Plats: Receive and file all final plats, and check their compliance with the preliminary plan.
6. Forward Plats To Village Board: Forward with recommendations to the village board all final plats.
7. Other Determinations: Make all other determinations required by the regulations herein.
C. The Village Engineer:
1. Review Of Plans: The village engineer shall review all preliminary subdivision plans and make determinations in the areas of design standards and
engineering specifications, as stipulated herein.
2. Inspection Of Work: The village engineer shall inspect all improvements required by this title both during construction and after completion to ensure
compliance with this title and with good construction practice.
3. Conflict Of Interest: The village engineer shall not be retained by a subdivider or other interested party to perform engineering work in any
subdivision subject to the application of this title. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-1989)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 450/524
10-7-2: ENFORCEMENT:
A. Village Manager To Administer Title: It shall be the duty of the village manager to administer this title and to bring any violations or lack of compliance
herewith to the attention of the village attorney. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-1989; amd. Ord. 2012-10-861, 10-1-2012)
B. Compliance Required Before Sale of Lots or Issuance of Building Permit: No owner, or agent of the owner, of any parcel of land located in a proposed
subdivision shall transfer or sell such parcel, nor shall any public official issue a building permit for the construction of buildings or structures within a
proposed subdivision, before the final plat of the subdivision has been approved by the Village Board, in accordance with the provisions of this Title,
and filed with the Recorder of Deeds of Lake County, Illinois.
C. Use of Metes and Bounds Measured Prohibited: The subdivision of any lot or any parcel of land by the use of metes and bounds for the purpose of
sale, transfer, or lease with the intent of evading this Title will not be permitted. All such described subdivisions shall be subject to all of the
requirements and regulations contained in this Title.
D. Compliance Required Before Plat Approval: No final plat of subdivision shall be approved which does not comply with all the provisions of this Title.
10-7-3: VARIATIONS AND EXCEPTIONS:
A. Hardships: Where the Plan Commissions finds that extraordinary hardships or particular difficulties regarding the physical development of land may
result from strict compliance with these regulations, it may recommend variations or exceptions of the regulations so that substantial justice may be
done and the public interest secured; provided, that such variation or exception shall not have the effect of nullifying the intent and purpose of this Title;
and, further provided the Plan Commission shall not recommend variations or exceptions to the regulations of this Title unless it shall make findings
based upon the evidence presented to it in each specific case that:
1. Public Welfare Protected: The granting of the variation will not be detrimental to the public safety, health or welfare or injurious to nearby properties;
2. Unique Conditions: The conditions upon which the request for a variation is based are unique to the property for which the variation is sought and
are not applicable, generally, to other property;
3. Particular Physical Conditions: Because of the particular physical surroundings, shape or topographical conditions of the specific property involved, a
particular hardship to the owner would result, as distinguished from a mere inconvenience, if the strict letter of the regulations were carried out.
B. Conditions: In recommending variations and exceptions, the Plan Commission may require such conditions as will, in its judgement, secure
substantially the objectives of the standards or requirements of this Title.
C. Procedure: A petition for any such variance shall be submitted in writing by the subdivider at the time the preliminary plan is filed for consideration by
the Plan Commission. The petition shall state fully the grounds for the application and all of the facts relied upon by the petitioner.
D. Recommendations: Such variations and exceptions as may be recommended by the Plan Commission shall be forwarded to the Village Board in
writing, substantially the recommended variations and/or exceptions. The Village Board may approve such variations or exceptions from the
requirements of this Title in specific cases as listed on the final plat, which in its opinion do not adversely affect the adopted Comprehensive Plan or the
intent and purpose of this Title.
10-7-4: RECORD OF PLATS:
All of such plats of subdivision, after the same have been submitted and approved as provided in this Title, shall be copied upon a book of plats of said
Village and shall be filed and kept by the Village.
10-7-5: VALIDITY:
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this Title is adjudged to be void, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining
portions of this Title.
10-7-6: APPEALS:
Any person may appeal within sixty (60) days to the Village Board of Trustees any final action taken by the Plan Commission. The Board of Trustees shall
act as a Board of Appeals and shall hear and decide appeals from and review any final order, requirement, decision or determination made by the Plan
Commission, under this Subdivision Control Ordinance. The concurring vote of four (4) members of the Board of Trustees shall be necessary to reverse
any final order of the Plan Commission under this Title.
10-7-7: REPEAL:
All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with the provisions of this title are, to the extent that such conflict exists, hereby repealed. (Ord. 89-08-335,
8-21-1989)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=373 451/524
10-7-8: EXCEPTION FOR VILLAGE DEVELOPMENT:
Notwithstanding the provisions of sections 10-1-4, 10-3-1, 10-5-2, 10-5-9 of this title and section 10-7-3 of this chapter or any other provision of this title,
the Board of Trustees may waive the application of any procedural or substantive regulation of this title to any project or development undertaken by the
Village for public purposes. (Ord. 92-03-507, 3-2-1992)
10-7-9: VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES:
Any person who fails to comply with, or violates, any of the provisions of this title, shall be subject to a fine pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule",
of this Code, and each day the violation continues shall be considered a separate offense.
Whoever shall sell or offer for sale, lease or offer for lease, while this title is in effect, any lot or lots or block or blocks, within the incorporated limits of the
Village, or any resubdivision of any lot or block therein, or within contiguous territory and not more than one and one-half (11/2) miles beyond the
incorporated boundary of the Village before a final plat of subdivision has been approved by the Plan Commission and the Village Board of Trustees as
required by this title, shall be fined pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of this Code for each lot, block or part thereof so disposed of, offered for
sale or leased. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-1989; amd. Ord. 2018-12-279, 12-3-2018)
10-7-10: FEES:
A. Conditions: (Rep. by 97-06-859, 6-16-1997)
B. Amount: Refer to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of this Code. (Ord. 2018-12-279, 12-3-2018)
All such fees shall be payable to the Village by certified check or money order.
C. Recording Fees: In addition to the fees listed in subsection B of this section, the subdivider shall also bear the cost of recording the plat. (Ord. 89-08-
335, 8-21-1989)
10-7-11: FILING OF ENGINEERING PLANS AND REVIEW FEE:
A. Four (4) complete sets of engineering plans and specifications of required land improvements shall be filed, together with an estimate of the cost of
improvements, the plans and specifications to bear the seal of an Illinois registered professional engineer along with his signed statement that such
plans and specifications have been prepared in compliance with this title and with good engineering practice. The plans shall be drawn to a minimum
horizontal scale of fifty feet to the inch (50' = 1") and a minimum vertical scale of five feet to the inch (5' = 1"). Plans shall show profiles of all utility and
street improvements, with elevations referred to United States Geological Survey datum. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-1989)
B. Plan review fees passed shall be paid by the developer to the Village pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of this Code.
C. A charge for inspection of facilities to be constructed for land under consideration within this title shall be based on cost to the Village for having such
inspection performed by the Village Engineer or designate of the Village Board. A deposit pursuant to title 13, chapter 1, "Fee Schedule", of this Code
shall be placed on deposit with the Village. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-1989; amd. Ord. 2018-12-279, 12-3-2018)
D. Engineering review and inspection charges set out above are in the form of deposits. The amount due the Village shall be equivalent to the cost to the
Village for their services and shall be paid prior to any final acceptance. (Ord. 89-08-335, 8-21-1989)

WATERMAIN INSTALLATION SPECIFICATIONS
1.Watermains shall not be exposed for any reason without the approval of the Operations Supervisor _ Utilities.
2.Filling mains, pressure connections, pressure tests, tie-ins, and chlorinations require 48 Hour notification to the Operations Supervisor _ Utilities.
3.Pressure connections and tie-ins to the Village systems will be scheduled and witnessed by the Utilities Division personnel.
4.Once mains are tied to the Village system, no valves or hydrants shall be operated by anyone other than Utility Division personnel.
5.Filling and flushing will be done by the Utilities Division only.
6.Water for pressure tests will be supplied by the Utilities Division, but it is the responsibility of the contractor to provide a backflow preventer or an
approved anti-siphon method before the pump.
7.Corporation Stops and 1" copper lines for the chlorination and sampling shall be installed at locations determined by the Utilities Division.
8.Chlorination will not be performed on service lines until all first permanent water valves are installed.
Water vaults for 8" valves and larger must have an inside diameter of 60".
(Ord. 2001-02-91, 2-20-2001) EXHIBIT NO. 14

Notes:

manholes only.
2. The bedding under the wye fitting and stub shall be particularly carefully compacted to prevent the wye fitting from rotating.
3. The sanitary service connection pipe shall be laid in a straight line and at a uniform gradient from the top of the rise from the main line to three (3) feet
beyond the right-of-way line.
4. Securely plug the end of the service connection.

(b)Forty (40) feet for each one (1) percent algebraic difference of grade but in no case less than one hundred (100) feet. EXHIBIT NO. 20
